name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on Marc Tarabella's report on behalf of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality on progress in gender equality in the European Union in 2013 (A8-0015/2015) (2014/2217(INI)).

name: Marc Tarabella
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, it is with great pride that I come to present this report on equality between women and men, or rather, the reduction of inequality.   Indeed, this report is the result of a long work and intense collaboration with the shadow rapporteurs whom I would like to welcome: Mrs Gabriel for the EPP Group, Mrs Bilbao Barandica for the ALDE Group, Mrs Vallina for the GUE/NGL group, Mrs Lunacek and Mr Urtasun for the Greens/EFA group, Mrs Aiuto for the EFDD group and Mrs von Storch for the EC Group.  In fact, it is through their work that this report is effective, concise and structured.   It starts from a very simple observation: while we are in the aftermath of International Women's Rights Day, equality is still a long way off. Indeed, at the rate we are going to Europe, we would have to wait until 2038 to reach the target of a 75% women's employment rate, and 2084 for equal pay. But let us rejoice, parity in national parliaments, in European institutions and in the boards of European companies should be possible in 20 years!   It is high time to go beyond the good words to take concrete action. This report calls for a set of measures to be taken to achieve real equality much faster. We therefore urge the European institutions and the Member States to include the gender dimension in policy-making, particularly in the context of the European semester, the budget and the allocation of funds. This is a prerequisite for achieving the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy, from which we are still a long way off. The second point I would like to stress is that Member States and the European institutions need to implement more effective inclusion strategies to address the gap between pension rates and reduce the risk of poverty that affects women much more, and single mothers in particular. Real action against poverty requires promoting women's participation in the labour market through quality jobs. I would like to point out here that equal participation of men and women in the labour market would result in an increase of more than 12% in gross domestic product by 2030. This is an economic argument to take into account at a time when we are still struggling in times of crisis. Employment is fundamental, but it's not just work in life. Promoting work-life balance for men and women must be a priority, including investing in nurseries, reception centres, as well as supporting the updating of the maternity leave directive and the creation of paternity leave. Real equality between women and men requires respect and non-violence, including non-violence in the domestic environment. That is why I urge the Member States to ratify the Istanbul Convention as soon as possible. Only eight Member States of the European Union have already done so. What are the others waiting for? It is also essential to create a European Year solely dedicated to the fight against violence against women. I have, in fact,, together with other colleagues, including many shadow rapporteurs, launched a written initiative on this subject, which I invite all my colleagues here and those who have left the Chamber to sign. We must also combat gender stereotypes, because it is from childhood that inequality develops, rekindles, in all aspects of our society. The proliferation of laws will be of no use if they are not supported by a public opinion that is aware of the issue of gender. Finally, this report recalls the right of women to dispose of their bodies. I know, ladies and gentlemen, that many of you have received messages from some lobbyists that go against our values and women's rights. But this report is not just about that. It is equality and reducing inequality that we really need to focus on. I therefore call on all colleagues to support this report, which is a strong signal to the European institutions, to national governments but also and above all to the citizens, especially since the report last year, remember, had been rejected. This had been a bad signal given by Parliament. In conclusion, I would like to thank the collaborators who have been very valuable to me in this matter: Marie Ramot, my assistant, and Emmanuelle le Texier, of the group S and D, who have really ensured that this work is well supported. (Applause)

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I am grateful to the European Parliament for the organisation of the plenary debate on progress towards equality between women and men. I would also like to thank Mr Tarabella and other Members of Parliament for the report, which clearly identifies remaining challenges and future priorities. Before outlining my priorities for the coming years, I would like to mention the achievements so far. Equality between women and men has progressed over the last years in the EU. Women have entered the labour market in large numbers and contributed to the EU’s economic growth and competitiveness. Changes have not happened automatically, but are a result of strategic policy initiatives at European, national and local levels. In line with its obligations under the Treaties, the EU promotes gender equality in all its activities, from education to work, and from research to external policy. It has combined legislation, policy measures and funding. I dare to say that the EU is now a good address for women. Despite progress, however, gender equality still remains very much unfinished business. It is necessary to recall the scale of gender inequalities and the unacceptably high levels of violence against women in Europe. Gender inequalities affect our society. They can have a damaging effect on employment and growth rates, on well—being and on social cohesion. Therefore, I share Mr Tarabella’s concerns, and gender equality will be a priority of my mandate. In particular, I agree that we will have to pursue our efforts to facilitate work-life balance and to close the gaps in pay, employment, pensions and decision-making. These are still very valid objectives. The proposed directive on improving gender balance on the boards of listed companies remains a priority for me and for the Commission. I am delighted that the European Parliament, as well as more and more Member States, support this initiative, and I am confident that we will see this directive adopted this year. I also welcome the recent German Bundestag decision adopting the law on gender balance, and I hope this will lead also to Germany taking a more welcoming approach towards the EU Commission proposal. We might also need to take a fresh look at the way we promote gender equality. The report mentions issues such as the increasing poverty of men and women, the very difficult situation of single mothers, and gender stereotypes.  The Commission is ready to help Member States to advance in these fields. I also very much appreciate Mr Tarabella’s vision on work-life balance policies. These policies are not only a women’s issue. They should help both men and women to reconcile family and work throughout their lifetime. I am strongly encouraged by the news that there is movement on the proposal to improve the Maternity Leave Directive. I am aware of significant efforts in this House to build consensus around a fresh approach. This seems to me to be a very good and reasonable basis for discussions with the Council. I will be happy to facilitate fast progress on this file in cooperation with the Latvian Presidency, the Parliament and the Commission. The Parliament has repeatedly asked the Commission to step up its efforts to combat gender-based violence. I am convinced that the Council of Europe Convention on preventing and combating violence against women and domestic violence provides a good legal framework for all of us. I also agree with the rapporteur that the EU needs to grant sufficient resources for awareness-raising activities. A European Year on violence against women could be one way of achieving this. To be of clear added value, such a year would require appropriate funding, consultation of relevant stakeholders and clear preparation. I am not ruling out this possibility but I think it is too optimistic to launch such a year in less than ten months. Gender equality is a long-lasting commitment for the EU. The results of a recent Eurobarometer show that nearly all Europeans agree that equality between women and men is a fundamental right, and a large majority of citizens believe that tackling inequality between women and men should be a priority for the EU.

name: Mariya Gabriel
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like, first of all, to thank my colleague Marc Tarabella for his excellent work, as rapporteur, both in substance and in form. A fruitful collaboration is all the more important because this report allows us, once a year, to take stock of the progress made, but also on the challenges that remain. I hope that tomorrow we can all, as an institution, vote in favour of this very good report. From 2013, we will note among others the following progress: we have seen that legislative pressure works, with the draft Women on Boards directive. Since the directive has been on the table, there have been more women on boards. The Commission provided an update on the application of the 2006 Equal Treatment Directive in the labour market and made recommendations. Finally, the Fundamental Rights Agency carried out the European study on violence against women. We have a database now. Focus on the stock! So we're seeing positive momentum, but the challenges remain great. In this report, we propose new ideas.  First, women's participation in the science sector as well as in the information and communication sector. We must also focus on using the digital strategy as a lever to promote gender equality. Secondly, to encourage women's entrepreneurship to fully realize the economic potential they represent, noting that it can contribute to the renewal of structures and the functioning of the labour market in favour of a better balance between work and family life. Beyond the European Social Fund, the proposal to consider the use of European funds as a lever to improve women's participation in the economic and political decision-making process. And finally, the eternal fight against gender stereotypes, especially the role of education and the media.  I hope that these proposals will be given special attention by the other institutions and member states. In this regard, I would add that, in order to achieve real progress on gender equality, it is crucial that action is taken at the most appropriate level. The competences of Member States must also be respected. That is the meaning of my group's amendments, but I am counting on the will of all of us to vote in favour of equality between men and women.  (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: question asked by raising a "blue card". – She spoke of stereotypes, of the need to combat stereotypes. I wanted to ask what stereotypes are involved? Do you think it is about family rights or is the family a stereotype? And what tools do you propose for this fight. I will admit that I ask this with concern, because whenever such general terms are used, there is a threat to human freedom and the rights of the family.

name: Mariya Gabriel (PPE)
text: "blue card" answer. The stereotypes I refer to are the stereotypes that really prevent women's potential from realizing. Stereotypes that still distribute male and female roles in our society. Stereotypes still refer to school, where girls are taught that there are trades for them and others that are for men. That is the kind of stereotype I am referring to. It is clear that today it is necessary to tackle it in order to enable equality between men and women.

name: Anna Hedh
text: On the other: And on the S&D Group. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for First of all, I would like to thank Marc Tarabella for a fantastic job. In recent days on international women's day, I have heard many people say that we have made such tremendous progress in the field of gender equality. It has made me very uncomfortable, because even though we women have been given the right to vote, and we are allowed to drive and we get work, we have not caught up with our rights. Yes, we get to work – but preferably part-time. The employment rate for women has only increased by 4% in 13 years. Women are paid 16.4% less than men. A few women are in positions of power and decision-making positions. In this house, we're only 33 percent women. There are nine female Commissioners out of 28, and only 5% are women of the Presidents of the Board of Directors of the European Union. One in two women has been the victim of sexual harassment and violence. In addition, women do not have the right to decide about their own body. I'm sure if it were the men who gave birth, it would have been natural long ago for them to have to decide on their bodies themselves. Do I sound pessimistic? Yes, we have raised the same problems that exist in the Tarabella report year after year since I became a Member in 2004, without major changes from us in this House. Now, however, I hope that the Tarabella report will go through tomorrow. Anything else would be shameful. (The speaker agreed to answer a question (blue card) in accordance with Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr President, Mrs Hedh, I would like to thank Mrs Hedh for her work on this What we have here is a report on equality between men and women. But you are sifting away at issues such as a woman's right to have her own body, and link that to abortion. Do you not think that it is inappropriate to raise quite different issues in the context of a report that is actually devoted to equality between men and women, such as a woman's completely controversial right to have an abortion? And do you not agree that it is contrary to fundamental human rights to be able to kill the unborn life when there is indeed a right to life and integrity?

name: Anna Hedh (S&D)
text: answer ("blue card"). "It's about women having the right to control their bodies, to decide over their own personality and what she wants to do in her life. I have not mentioned the word abortion, but it is about the right to be able to have contraception, for example, and the right to work. I think that is incredibly important to address this report.

name: Beatrix von Storch
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. Unfortunately, I cannot add myself to the great praise for this report. Firstly, the European Parliament is calling for measures to be taken to ensure that social media does not use sexist language. Is the EU language police coming now? Is the offence of insult no longer sufficient? Are compliments now banned? Can a man say to a strange woman "You look wonderful!" or "I like your dirndl extraordinarily well!"? Can he still tell her to carry her suitcase, or is it the gender stereotype sexism that is now to be persecuted? Secondly, the European Parliament calls on men and women to share professional, family and social responsibilities in a more balanced way. Are we here in Parliament being paid to dictate to adult men and women in Europe how they should do their housework better, who should do the washing up and who is bringing the rubbish down? Are we being paid 750 men and 70 interpreters to talk about and translate this nonsense here? There is no state in the world or parliament in the world, whether my husband or I hangs up the laundry! Thirdly, the European Parliament notes – literally – that traditional gender roles restrict the development of women and therefore cannot fulfil their potential as human beings. The traditional gender role of women is probably traditionally that of mother and family man. So a mother and a family man can no longer fulfil their potential as human beings? This is in a way inhumane that it scares me. I cannot imagine that we can agree to this. However, I am glad that we have a roll-call vote so that we can determine exactly who supports this nonsense. The name Mischief in Europe was last called Estrela, from now on it is called Tarabella. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Mr. President, although Mrs. Mp said a lot at the end of her speech, I want to ask the question do you really think we need sexist outbursts on the Internet? Do you really think these things on the Internet can't be corrected? I just don't understand you when you perform like that.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I don't think we need sexism at all. But we have criminal offences that already regulate this. In Germany, this is the criminal offence of insulting. However, we do not need further persecution of expressions of opinion that may be wrong and stupid. It is not the task of the state to pursue such stupid, stupid, stupid and, in my view, somehow inaccurate and stupid statements.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, I would like to thank Marc for his work, his conviction and his enthusiasm in this report. Eskerrik asko, Marc. Thank you for proving that you know that being different doesn't mean being unequal. Europe cannot wait until 2038 for 75% of women to have jobs or equal pay until 2084. Nor that in 2034 they feel here, or on the advice of big companies, as many women as men. Hopefully, in 2054 we will distribute household chores to 50%. Meanwhile, one in four women will continue to be ill-treated. That's how we lose competitiveness, because our economy gives up the talent of millions of women. We lose the ability to innovate and finance our social protection system, because precariousness slows our birth and ages us. Democracy suffers because inequality is a violation of a more widespread basic right in Europe. And justice suffers, because inequality is the source of violence against women and all the deficits described in this report that are reflected and accentuated, every day, with a very improved treatment of the female image in the media. That is why I support this report. That is why I encourage the European Institute for Gender Equality to obtain approved data across Europe to learn more and better evaluate.  That is why I propose a work that details what and how much women and women's management contribute to the economy. This will certify that equality is an investment. And that is why I stress that defending freedom of access to sexual and reproductive health is not a campaign for abortion: it is part of the United Nations post-2015 goals for smart and sustainable development.  Let us encourage governments to bet on conciliation, stereotype-free education and a commitment to women's entrepreneurship and gender-based violence. We should all be concerned that violations of marital domicile in Lithuania, Estonia, Hungary or Poland are still a private matter. We should all be concerned that the alleged crimes of mistreatment committed by a goal scorer will be celebrated in a football field. This is happening today in Europe and they are symptoms of all that remains to be done. (She agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Janice Atkinson (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Do you know what? I listen to so much rubbish in this place, but this time it is actually coming from the mouths of women. We are equal. In my country we have had equality for the past 40 years. In UKIP we do not need gender quotas because the 25% of our cohort here are one member, one vote, and that is more than any of the other parties. And you will not impose gender quotas on British companies. We are getting there without it. We absolutely refuse this and it will not happen on UKIP’s watch.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: "blue card" response. – First of all, I would ask you, in your speeches, to be respectful of the interventions of the rest of the members of this Parliament. I don't share your opinion, but I'll never say that what you're saying is nonsense. So, start there. Secondly, I was the first president of a regional parliament, the Basque Parliament. And I had the honor of presiding over a parliament with 53% women. And I can tell you that today the Basque Country is better than before it had that representation. Learn, which I think also has another problem, to identify the inequality in which you live, because I have learned it too.

name: Ángela Vallina
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, first of all I would also like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Tarabella, for this report, as approved by the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, — although everything is improveable in this life — is a rigorous and critical report with the policy carried out in the European Union.  But I would also like to say that to this day, with the amendments that have been tabled, there are certain dangers in our view: and one is to dilute the responsibility of the European Commission and its failure to develop the Strategy for Equality between Women and Men 2010-2015.  Moreover, from the People's Group they want to eliminate the report of the lack of promotion of conciliation policies, and there is also a strategy, especially from the PPE Group, which aims to eliminate all paragraphs requiring the European Union to take some form of action, such as the accession of the European Union to the Istanbul Convention on action measures against sexist violence, measures to combat gender stereotypes or the inclusion of gender equality between women's rights in agreements with third countries.  It is also intended to mention Article 168 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union and a Parliament Resolution of 10 December 2013 to make it clear that public health policy falls within the competence of the Member States, which on the subject of abortion would leave the situation as is, which is of genuine vulnerability in certain Member States. It is intended to impose restrictions on the right to easy access to contraception and abortion, which would affect freedom and the right to decide, which are provided for in the Treaties in the form of the European Union's respect for fundamental rights, including the right to health and reproductive health.  We, on the other hand, defend the protection of reproductive and sexual rights; maternity protection; maternal and paternal leave; work-life balance; equality policies and prevention policies as a fundamental pillar of affective-sexual education. We should take advantage of the moment when we find ourselves to change the rules of the game and to play all of them. And we should change the old politics with all the vices and inequalities that we are seeing that exist and start playing on an equal footing.

name: Ernest Urtasun
text: verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, working on the next strategy from 2015 on out of 2015 is extremely important, because we do not live in a normal situation. We are living in a serious situation, in which rising inequality—inequality between men and women, in terms of work and professional matters—is also leading us to growing inequality in many fields of life. Today, moreover, we must point out that the withdrawal of public services is causing women to have the bulk of the adjustment, the bulk of the burden of reproduction tasks. And that is leading us to reproduce again, in some Member States, some trends in patriarchy that we thought were forgotten. Therefore, the new strategy must be ambitious, coherent and very brave to reverse this situation. I would like to join in congratulating Mr Tarabella's report, with which we have worked well and with which we have been able to define a good position of Parliament in relation to the strategy in many things: in the implementation of gender equality within the framework of the Europe 2020 Strategy, emphasizing to promote more equality between men and women at the labour level, in decision-making, in the need to reconcile working and personal life, and in the fight against gender-based violence. And also — and this is an essential point of the report also for my group — that sexual and reproductive rights could have been included in the report, recognizing the right of women to decide on their own reproduction and health, while calling for more measures and actions to ensure women's access to these services, while informing them of their choices and rights. I have to tell you that, as a thirty-year-old man, I cannot understand certain positions at this point. Women's freedom to decide on their own bodies is a fundamental right. A fundamental human right. And it would be very bad news if this European Parliament did not recognise it as such and that is why I would like to explicitly support paragraphs 44 and 45 of this report, which I believe are extremely important. I would also like to point out that the report calls very clearly for the Commission to help unblock the legislation which the Council is currently blocked. The Maternity and Paternity Leave Directive is not a luxury in times of crisis. You cannot have it in REFIT and I am glad that the report will point it out in a very clear way, as well as the Directive as regards quotas in large companies. I also end by pointing out the importance of a reference to the need to incorporate the gender perspective in the semester cycle and, of course, congratulating the rapporteur, Mr Tarabella, on his excellent work.

name: Louise Bours
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, as usual, we have another lengthy report calling for the EU to do absolutely everything under the sun. These numerous EU initiatives and campaigns have not done one thing to help gender equality. But, of course, MEPs calling for gender equality, to stop violence against women and demanding tougher legislation on discrimination is great public relations, is it not? No one would, or could, argue with that. But the reality is that none of us here have the power to initiate anything. So what about the report in front of us? You called for positive discrimination in respect of listed companies. This is demeaning to women. We are perfectly capable of competing for positions of responsibility in business. We do not need the EU making us look inferior or weaker. Then you state you want gender clauses for public procurement contracts: classic EU bureaucracy. If I want a job doing, I want it done well; I want the best company with the best plan for the best price, irrespective of how many men and women work in that company. Once again, it is the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality (FEMM) and the EU justifying their own existence with reports that are nothing more than pie in the sky, offering no practical help to women whatsoever. (Applause from the EFDD Group)

name: President. –
text: Could I ask if you will take a blue card question from Ms Jaakonsaari? (Ms Bours did not wish to take a blue-card question)

name: Georg Mayer (NI).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I think it would be good for the issue if we take back a little bit of emotion, because the issue is an important one and in this case it is damaging. Equal treatment between men and women and equality is an important issue. And this issue must be a concern of all of us. There are massive differences of opinion on the way in which we want to get there – as I am following this discussion here. This report is full of ideological nonsense. And it is also primarily the task of the individual Member States to enshrine in national law frameworks for equality. Equal treatment must also be practised in practice at the end of the day. Contrary to the style and tone of this report, this socio-political change can only be made if it is done without coercion and without quotas. This change can only be brought about with incentives and gradually. It is very important – and I have said this for a long time – to promote the approximation of the salaries of men and women. Equal pay for equal work is one of the highest commandments and must be our goal. However, we also see in Austria, in a socialist and ÖVP-influenced government, that we have not been able to achieve this for decades. And, as experience shows, it is not simply through laws that such inequalities can be eliminated. One thing remains clear: on the other hand, positive discrimination always means negative discrimination at the same time. That will not happen with us!

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE).
text: Madam President, yesterday, 8 March, we were celebrating International Women's Day. Today we are debating the European Parliament's report on the progress of gender equality in the European Union in 2013. The observation is clear: much remains to be done, for we are far, too far away, from the full emancipation, in all areas, of women in our societies.  This emancipation must be achieved through education, training, access to employment and the implementation of proactive policies in this area. Reducing wage gaps and pay gaps at all stages of life, eliminating gender stereotypes and discrimination, strengthening our fight against violence - all violence - against women, breaking glass ceilings, these must be our priorities.  Women expect us, MEPs, to make a strong commitment, and indeed, for example, to declare 2016 the European Year of Combating All Violence Against Women would be a very significant sign in this regard. I thank Mr Tarabella for his report and for the spirit in which he conducted his work. Too often, this annual report of our chamber was the occasion of unnecessary and sterile polemics which, in reality, harmed the cause of equality between men and women. Last year, for example, I was unable, like a majority of the members of this house, to vote in favour of Mrs Zuber's report. I believe that the Tarabella report avoids many of the pitfalls of the previous report, and I welcome this work. I also welcome the work of our shadow rapporteur on behalf of the EPP Group, Mrs Gabriel, who has been able to defend our positions as EPPs with strength and discernment and who has made a very decisive contribution to this work. As the epp Group coordinator in the Committee on Women's Rights, I will vote in favour of the Tarabella report. I invite all my colleagues to do the same. I believe that the members of the French delegation in the EPP group will also be keen to show that they are in favour of equality between men and women. Once again - and this will be the position of the EPP Group which is resolutely in favour of this equality, but in respect of the prerogatives, the competences of the Member States, respecting the principle of subsidiarity... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker) (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Blue card question. Thank you very much, Madam President. I was pleased with what the Member of the People's Party had said in the previous moments. I'm a very belligerent member of the S&D caucus who favors women's equality.  That is why I would like to ask you what you think of the fact that just last week, a few days ago, in Hungary, the FIDESZ in your group and the far right voted together in the Hungarian Parliament to ratify the Istanbul Convention, the Council of Europe Convention, which is astonishing to me, because it is an agreement against violence against women. Thank you very much!

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: "blue card" answer. Madam President, I am not sure I have heard a question, it may have been more of an inquiry than a real one.  I would just like to point out that, both personally and as coordinator of the EPP group in the Committee on Women's Rights, I am in favour of the ratification of the Istanbul Convention, of course. But I do not want this debate to be used or to become the place of a stigmatization process, practices among those which, in my opinion, too often undermine the need to unite and come together to send a strong, unifying, unifying message and thus make a strong contribution from our chamber to the cause of equality between men and women.

name: Илияна Йотова (S&D).
text: – I would like to congratulate all the colleagues in this chamber who worked on this report and address my colleague Mr Tarabella and say to him: "Mark, you have done a great job because you have not only presented a photographic picture of this problem, but you are also looking for solutions." However, I will add one more thing, because this is not about third world countries, but about Member States. We are talking about black labour, about the informal economy, which in countries like Bulgaria, for example, reaches 32%, and in the tourism sector even exceeds 60%. The vast majority of those forced to work in this way are women – no employment contracts, no right to motherhood, no sick days to raise children, without any basic assistance. We need legislation that criminalises employers who exploit social dumping and exploit women's work. And one more thing, Commissioner, today's discussion would sound rather false if you did not help unblock the Maternity Directive and put it back on the agenda of the European institutions.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab This report contains many elements with which I absolutely cannot agree and which are at odds with the values of millions of Europeans. The first caveat concerns the promotion of abortion. Abortion is evil and cannot be regarded as a woman's fundamental right. Our task should be to empower women, inter alia, by supporting parenthood, motherhood and ensuring a family-promoting policy that supports motherhood and parenthood.  Secondly, I call on the States of the European Union not to ratify this harmful, ideological Istanbul Convention, because this convention does not solve the problems of violence, but introduces a socio-cultural notion of gender, obliges states to fight stereotypes, and considers the role of a woman as a mother, a man as a father, to be a stereotypical role. In addition, it identifies tradition, family, religion as sources of violence. The proper sources of violence lie, inter alia, in alcoholism, drug addiction, increasing violence and sexualisation of the image of a woman. Unfortunately, these issues completely omit the convention. Thus, under the guise of fighting violence, new ideological content is introduced that undermines what is valuable in our culture and civilizations rooted in Christian roots. It is a pity that you forget about it. Please read the convention, then you will know what we are talking about.  (The speaker agreed to answer the question asked by raising the blue card (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Miapetra Kumpula-Natri (S&D)
text: blue card question. – Mr President, I speak Finnish. I'm sure we have something in common when you wanted to take action against violence, and that's a good thing. Personally, I see the importance of women's own bodies, the body, the powers of termination, and, by way, correctly managed abortions. The Istanbul Convention must be part of European values, but I will try to start from the common ground that we could find, how do you see the involvement of men in childcare?  You wanted to support families, and at the moment only one man out of 100 is involved in caring for the children of the family from parental leave.

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: answer to the question asked by raising the "blue card". " How do I see the role of men? Ladies and gentlemen, I profess conservative, traditional values. My husband cleans at home, my husband, like me, cooks. And we have absolutely no problem or trouble with it. We share roles: when one of us has time, he performs household chores. I have the impression that you have unfortunately not read the Istanbul Convention and are duplicating some stereotypical thinking about this convention. If you think that the source of violence is religion, culture, family, then I think this is to some extent a distorted picture of reality.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, thank you, Mr Tarabella, for undertaking a very difficult bus task with as much courage as a consensus will: to make a diagnosis of the situation of equality between men and women and to establish a political position of this Parliament on the issues affecting the majority of its citizens. It is unquestionable that we can improve the accuracy of the terms used, and that certain aspects addressed continue to drag an ideological ballast that sometimes clouds our mission of public representatives in the service of the general interest.  But let me highlight what I consider to be the three pillars that vertebrate this analysis.  The first is equality in the workplace: the growing wage gap is an unsustainable injustice, we cannot wait seventy years to guarantee the same wage for the same job. Board of directors and administration cannot continue to dispense with half of talent and competence. Nothing changes if something doesn't change, and that something is the law. If the demand for parity quotas seems to us to be a great achievement in the electoral lists that make up democratic parliaments and governments; How can it not be good to set quotas in the corporate governments of the companies that govern our economy? The second is equality in girls' and women's access to quality comprehensive education, as an essential tool for sustainable development that makes equal benefits for men and women. I would like to stress the importance of a lay sex and reproductive education that guarantees girls and women the knowledge and control of their bodies as a sine qua non condition to ensure their independence and autonomy. It is up to us to ensure the legal and health means to do so. And, lastly, equality in family, social and media development. We have to ratify the Istanbul Convention: the European Union and all Member States; and, please, we ask the Council to put the Maternity Leave Directive on the table. We need to respond to the reality and demand of European families who need our legislation. (She agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: Question the task by picking up a blue card. – Firstly, I would like to ask you how you understand, understand and define the socio-cultural understanding of gender? Secondly, do you think that early sexualisation of young children makes sense? How do you define the sources of violence against women? Do you agree with what is contained in the Convention that the source of violence against women is family, religion and tradition?

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: "blue card" response. – Excuse me, it will be difficult for you in thirty seconds to answer so many questions, but I believe that the Istanbul Convention is an essential tool, because it is the first legally binding tool to prevent, to protect and also to prosecute those guilty of domestic violence, which is something that goes further. And there is another issue which is indeed essential for social equality: the visibility of women in the media in an equal way. And break with stereotypes ranging from curriculum programs to advertising and, of course, everything to do with the media.

name: Malin Björk (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr This is the first first vote on equality. An extremely important report that addresses women's right to financial independence, calls for a crackdown on wage discrimination, calls for increased childcare facilities and calls for women to live a life free from violence. Much of this was also mentioned by my colleague, Mr Zuber, in last year's report. Then the right brought it down. It is good to hear that Mr Tarabella's report has not been set up. This report also calls for us women to have the right to our bodies and sexuality, with access to contraception and safe abortions. Some amendments have been tabled, and we should be honest: they refer to subsidiarity, but what they want is to weaken the wording of the Committee on Gender Equality on sexual and reproductive health and rights and the right to abortion and contraception. We have our eyes on us when we vote tomorrow and rightly so. Gender equality work at European level: Although Jourová says that progress has been made, this is not the case. The statistics speak against it. We must take a stand in favour of gender equality, vote in favour of the Tarabella report without weakening it tomorrow and say yes to women's right to decide over our own bodies.

name: Terry Reintke (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, yesterday we celebrated International Women’s Day, and with it many years of the struggle for gender equality and against patriarchal oppression. Women died. They were tortured, they faced repression, they were made invisible or simply laughed about when fighting for equal rights. One thing all of these women that were fighting for equal rights had in common: they had to overcome massive opposition in order to change society. But they did not stay silent. They did not accept the injustices that were imposed on them. They stood up and changed history.  When we are fighting for gender equality in this Parliament today, we are facing opposition too – a loud and aggressive opposition that tells us to shut up about women’s rights. This reactionary opposition tells us not to continue the struggle for full democratic representation, for equal pay, against violence against women and for the right of women to decide about their own bodies. We could shut up and stay silent; we could give in, but I myself would not be standing in this Parliament alongside many of you if there had not been these brave women that fought for our rights to stand here and to speak as equals. How could we stay silent now? How could we not act according to our beliefs and speak up for many millions of women in our societies? If women 100 years ago had listened to the reactionary opposition, we would still not have the right to vote. If women over the last decades had listened to their opponents, violence against women would still be considered acceptable and part of our culture. But these women – these brave women – did not give up. They fought for freedom, justice and dignity. Each Member of this Parliament should have these women, and also men, in the back of their heads when they vote on the Tarabella report tomorrow. I will vote in favour.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Tarabella's report is a compilation of proposals that fall under the total off-topic. It all started from a common sense principle to Western philosophy and our Christian roots, that of equality between men and women. I have long worked for this equality of treatment and justice, and I will continue to fight this fight. However, ladies and gentlemen, you are on the wrong ground. You mix in your text the theory of gender and its procession of intellectual wanderings: paternity leave, abortion or even a reform of taxation. You describe to us a grossly false view of the family, proving that you chose the fight for its destruction. And it is above all women and children who will suffer attacks on this basic cell of European societies that is the family and which some here perceive as retrograde or oppressive for women, when it is their best protection. On the other hand, not a word, not a single one, about the structural changes taking place that threaten equality between women and men in Europe today, starting with cultural practices that are foreign to our civilization and nurtured by communitarianism and multiculturalism. You want to take stock of the progress that has been made in terms of equality and dignity for women. Defend these women who are forcibly married to men so they can get papers! Protect these women sequestered in their burqas, a real mobile prison! Rescue young girls who are prostitutes and used as objects by pimps and mafia networks that mainly take advantage of the absence of borders and judicial laxity that the parties of the system have promoted.  Obviously you are more interested in an ideology than in the treatment of women in Europe.  (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Sophia in ‘t Veld (ALDE)
text: blue-card question. – I would just like to understand this because I hear your argument a lot. You are speaking about attacks on the family and attacks on the things that you care about, but I fail to understand how giving more freedom, more choice, equal treatment to others, could possibly attack anything in your life. Is it not by giving freedom to more women that you too have more freedom?

name: Mireille D'Ornano (NI)
text: "blue card" answer. "In fact, what I would like is for women to have more freedoms, that is true, but good freedoms. In other words, the freedoms of being a father or a mother, a family, and not what you are looking for at the moment, namely the explosion of society, by your proposals, and which does not correspond to our Christian values.

name: Barbara Matera (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to congratulate Mr Tarabella, all the shadow rapporteurs and, in particular, Mr Gabriel, for their work in directing a text that we can support across the board, which deals with the issue of gender equality in an appropriate and balanced way. I must say with satisfaction that this Parliament has shown, in the past too, that it is forward-looking and that it is far-sighted among the various European institutions. However, if the female employment rate is struggling to rise, if women continue to experience difficulties in reconciling work and family life, if the rate of feminicides continues to rise and if it is true that we will have to wait another sixty years to achieve equal pay and social security for men and women, then that means that we have not been able to make a difference. Those who are content with illusory gender equality, based on rhetorical considerations and political problems, cannot grasp the crucial nature of Mr Tarabella's report, a document that takes account of past defeats, of lost battles, but reminds public opinion and the other European institutions of what action should actually be taken, with the aim of guaranteeing women the right to play a leading role in our societies. Ladies and gentlemen, I call on you to give strong support to this report, and I am also aware that the political and value background of certain political groups runs counter to some elements of this report. Brief hints that, in my opinion, do not compromise the quality of this report, which instead focuses on the inclusion of women in contributing much more dynamism to the European economy. I would therefore ask you to leave the prejudices outside the Chamber tomorrow and, above all, to ensure that the desire to break down stereotypes and cultural backwardness prevails.

name: Mary Honeyball (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank Marc Tarabella for this excellent report. I would also like to welcome the statement from Madam Jourová that the Commission is going to give gender equality a priority. While I am on this subject, I think we must, all of us, the decent majority in this Chamber, condemn those who have called this report rubbish – because it quite clearly is not rubbish – and those who have also called it irrelevant. This is a vital and necessary report, something that we do every year, and we really do need to make sure that we take stock every year about what is going on. Let us just take women’s employment. We still have, across the EU, a gender pay gap of over 16%. On pensions, older women really suffer – women’s pensions are 39% lower than those of men and there are many other economic examples. This is not only bad for women, it is bad for Europe. It is bad for our economy because we miss out on that talent. For our sake, and for the sake of Europe and for the sake of women, all the decent people in this House, I know the vast majority will support Mr Tarabella’s report.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: – I have to say that for me, the subject of real equality between men and women is very important, because there are still too many women, just because they are women, experience discrimination, underestimation, humiliation or violence. It is unacceptable to me that, in 21st-century Europe, one in three women is a victim of violence, it is unacceptable to me that it is still common practice in job interviews to ask women whether, when and the mother of how many children they plan to become, it is unacceptable to me that a woman who has spent years on maternity leave or a lifetime caring for her severely disabled child or dependent relative , receives a lousy pension and basically faces poverty all his life. I believe that all women, whether or not they become mothers, and regardless of whether they choose to work or take care of their family, deserve decent living conditions. And we should all strive to create such conditions.  (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: Jadwiga Wiśniewska (ECR)
text: question asked by raising a "blue card". – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Madam President, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. I would like to ask you, because you said that women earn less, have smaller pensions, of course that is true. You are the source of discrimination when women are focused on fulfilling the role of mothers. Do you not therefore consider that it is the lack of proper family policy of the Member States that is the source of discrimination against women?

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the Blue Card – I believe that raising children is one responsible and difficult task, and our society, our states should also appreciate it more in that maternity leave or parental allowance should be substantially higher than it is at present, when it does not really fully cover the needs of that family and the family often finds itself in poverty , when a mother stays at home with and cares for children, and I therefore think that the Member States – because it is the responsibility of the Member States – should also consider this direction, appreciate the work of mothers.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri (S&D).
text: Mr President, this is a point of order, because blue cards should be distributed to a person who speaks only once. The honourable Member has already spoken three times: in the end he risks talking more about the rapporteur. So, it would be nice to have a lot of thrift about this.

name: Presidente. –
text: It was decided at the beginning of the debate to allow a blue card to the speaker. I appeal, let us say, to the benevolence of all Members because it is clear that, in this way, the debate will take a very long time. Let's make good use of it.

name: Sophia in ’t Veld (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, congratulations to the rapporteur, Mr Tarabella, and thanks to Commissioner Jourová for her statement and her personal engagement. Colleagues, what we are discussing today and voting tomorrow is a political resolution; it is not legislation. But it makes it even more important, and I think the debate we are having today underlines that. Now I may not agree with every single paragraph in the resolution, but I do think it is extremely important that this Parliament send a signal tomorrow, a signal to women. What kind of Europe will we be shaping in the next five years? Is it the kind of Europe that people on that side of the House want: going back to the past, putting women back in the virtual burka? Or is it a Europe that guarantees women’s freedom, the freedom to choose and decide even over their own bodies and freedom from violence, with equality, equal rights, equal opportunities and equal pay? Colleagues, tomorrow we will choose – and again we may not like every sentence in the resolution – but I will vote wholeheartedly for the report and for women tomorrow.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL).
text: – The Tarabella report makes a good diagnosis of the setbacks that women's rights have had in recent years, although we do not agree with some issues, such as trying to get the European Semester to meet social objectives, which, in our opinion, is to try to mix water with olive oil.  We still need to be clearer and hold policies and their implementers accountable. It was the Guidelines of the European Commission and the policy of several governments that ordered the destruction of various social functions of the State, which ordered the lowering of wages, pushing women into poverty, exploitation and, in dramatic cases, prostitution. Yes, working hours today are more deregulated and more intense, but that was only the european commission's guidelines. The same European Commission which, saying that it defends women's rights a lot, has no problem putting the review of the maternity directive on the REFIT list, an essential tool for achieving greater equality between men and women. We need to be clear whether we want to be consistent and therefore we invite them to adopt the amendments we have proposed to this report tomorrow.

name: Ulrike Lunacek (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank Mr Tarabella for this good report and I also thank Commissioner Jourová for her encouraging words and for her commitment to the issue of equality. The gender pay gap, the glass ceiling, an informal effective quota for men, violence against women, gender stereotypes, a lack of self—determination, the freedom of choice for women and a lack of economic independence – we feminists have been struggling against all these and many other things for decades already, and although some things have improved it is still not good. That is why we need reports like this, and I hope there will be a good vote tomorrow. Let me say to all of you on the other side of the House: equality includes sexual and reproductive health and rights and it is not a new term invented by anybody here. It is the language of the United Nations of twenty years ago in Beijing and of 21 years ago in Cairo – and yes, it includes the right of women to have access to safe abortion because if it is not safe women risk dying and for no woman is an abortion easy. It would be better to have contraceptives but that is why we also need more eduation about contraceptives for boys and for girls and this report is about that as well. So I wish a Happy Women’s Day to all supporters of this report.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, once again hell is paved with good intentions. The original objective of protecting women's rights is misguided here for ideological and economic purposes. Ideological, because Mr. Tarabella forgets what men and women have specific and makes them complementary. Economic, because the objective is to have more and more people in a constrained labour market that is weighing down wages.  The reality is that the first of the violence against women is to deny their otherness. It is to want to create, for example, a non-transferable paternity leave, paternity leave which will de facto take time off maternity leave, because it is obvious that in the long run, the two leaves will have to be of the same duration - a matter of equality, of course. Violence means forgetting that a baby needs its mother first. Violence is to take it away from him and send him into work that is often underpaid. As for the Commission, it is directly contributing to the deterioration of the plight of women with its "violence without borders" policy.  The mass arrival of people, who have neither the same values nor the same customs, contributes greatly to the plight of women. I would like to take as an example my last speech, right here, on excisions now practised in Europe. What has happened since then to expel those responsible for such barbarities? Of course, nothing! On the other hand, creating a real parental income to enable women to really choose how to balance motherhood and career would have been an interesting lead. Of this, not a word. Your will, Mr Tarabella, and that of the Commission come together: to make all women interchangeable with all men, ignoring individuals and differences. Your goal is to create generic beings alienated from an increasingly deregulated labour market.  So making women a man like any other is not my ideal.

name: Angelika Niebler (PPE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I think it is good that we in the European Parliament are honestly dealing with the issue of equality between men and women. What has been achieved, last year, in recent years? What progress is being made in each Member State? I think it is good that we are discussing this here. I say this also to the right-wing populists in this House: of course we still have problems! Without end! Violence against women, forced prostitution has increased, old-age poverty, the pay gap between men and women – everything has been given. First and foremost, it is up to the Member States to remedy this situation and to draw up proposals. But it is also an issue that we in the European Parliament must deal with. I would like to pick up on one issue, namely why, tomorrow, when paragraph 45 passes through, I will find it difficult to vote in favour of the report. It provides for easier access to abortion. Ladies and gentlemen, I reject this passage! Nor do I think it is right to take this good equality report back to take up the issue of abortion. Abortion issues are a matter for the Member States, they are not a European issue. We have had this discussion in our country, in Germany, for many years and have carefully weighed it up in the German Bundestag: on the one hand, the right of women to physical integrity, and on the other hand, the protection of unborn life. Many, many debates and discussions have been held on this subject. I believe that this value decision made by the German Bundestag must also be respected here in this House. Therefore, if paragraph 45 were to come through tomorrow, if it were to find a majority, then unfortunately, with all sympathy for all the other issues, I cannot vote in favour of this report and many colleagues in my group will join in. I am sorry, but it is a matter of the heart for me to speak also for the protection of unborn life here in this House. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: question asked by raising a "blue card". – Honourable Member, I would like to thank you for your excellent work. I would like to ask you about this passage of the resolution, which concerns education. As far as I know, both in your country and in my country, education is a reserved area for a Member State. It is part of Germany's constitutional identity Polish. Are you not concerned that this resolution is completely contrary to the principle of subsidiarity and interferes with the sphere that a Member State has reserved, both in Poland and in Germany?

name: Angelika Niebler (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is a very Thank you for the question. If Rule 45 is not accepted, I would vote in favour of the report tomorrow, because I think it is important to make a recommendation here in the direction of the Member States as well. Like you, I believe that several issues are a matter for the Member States. However, this is also the case in the resolution. Education is, of course, a core competence that falls within the competence of the Member States. Nevertheless, I believe that this far less ideological report by Mr Tarabella – we have already adopted the Estrela report and other reports on this subject – would actually be a good report. I would like to see me vote in favour tomorrow. But then I also ask that we respect the value decision that is being made on the subject of abortion in the Member States. And if there is no majority in favour of Article 45, then I can agree with that.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I am not going to go into why Marc Tarabella's report is so good and so important. Thank God, many of my fellow Members have already said this across all political groups. I would particularly like to address those Members who are very critical and hostile to this report. I say to you: do not hide behind the sham arguments, such as the supposed problem of subsidiarity or behind moral concerns. Be open and honest: you do not want equality between women and men! You want women to continue to be disadvantaged and you want to continue to exercise control over women's bodies! They talk about protecting unborn life and accept that thousands of women die every year from unsafe abortions because they are denied the necessary health care. But perhaps I am wrong, and you are in agreement and then tomorrow you will vote in favour of this excellent report by Marc Tarabella. Hello, we live in 2015! Equality policy should be more relevant than ever.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: – The European Union subscribes to the values of equality and dignity of every person, and this report should be based on this, but unfortunately this is not the case. Among other things, the report talks about the rights of women-mothers and men-fathers. However, why is the most basic right of every woman and every man, namely the right to life, neglected. Where the report talks about the dignity and rights of unborn children is my question. I would like to point out that here we have repeatedly tried to decide on matters that fall exclusively within the competence of the Member States, and this House has clearly and correctly declared that sexual and reproductive health issues are the responsibility of the Member States. So how is it possible that efforts to interfere with them from the european Union's position are emerging again? These efforts concern not only the area of health, but also education and the most ridiculous are the efforts to monitor and correct social networks.

name: António Marinho e Pinto (ALDE).
text: – Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, in 30 years we will achieve the goal of having 75 % of women employed. It will take seventy years before equal pay can be a reality, more than 20 years to achieve parity in national parliaments and in the management of europe's largest companies and almost forty years to ensure that work at home is equally shared. Even here in the European Parliament, where we are discussing and taking these decisions, only a third of its members are women. Effective action must be taken to end this reality. Quotas need to be set up in so that companies are obliged to hire a number of women that are fit for reality. The stereotypes that dominate many institutions, particularly in the Catholic Church, where women cannot access the priesthood, must be tackled. That is why I call on Pope Francis to take a public position on this. The Catholic religion cannot be a male religion, a macho religion. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162(8)).

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – You speak in favour of quotas. I am personally in favour of recruiting the best person for the job, be they male or female, and whatever their ethnic origin. Those things do not matter to me. My concern here is this: if you end up with a quota system, what happens then with the person who does not know whether they have got their job because of their gender or whether they have got their job because of a quota? Is that not the most demeaning thing of all to women?

name: António Marinho e Pinto (ALDE)
text: Response according to the "blue card" procedure. – Dear Colleague, Mr President, I answer you with a question: do you think that women are inferior to men to be in the position where they are in the leadership positions of companies? Do you think that men are there just because they are better than women or because, behind this, there is a centuries-old culture that unduly subalters women and does not recognize her role as a human being in the fullness of her dignity as a human being? That is the reality, which we have to change and which we have to fight, of course we should look for the best, but at the moment that is not the rule that prevails. Right now, it's the men who dominate, just because they're men, and women don't have access, just because they're women.

name: Κωνσταντίνα Κούνεβα (
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, allow me to remain seated because of my situation. The austerity imposed by governments in Europe has made the situation of women inequality worse. Women have become the queens of part-time work and unemployment, as shown by the data contained in the report. Full-time women in Europe are 54%, while men are 72%. In contrast, part-time women are 76%, while men are only 24%.  Women's unemployment in Greece is 31%, while men's unemployment is 23%. Why is this happening? Firstly, because austerity has destroyed the scarce state childcare benefits, the elderly, the family. On women's backs is the burden of closing the holes in the social state and secondly because flexibility policies push women into poor quality jobs with reduced pay and rights. Policies are in place that re-imprison women at home and that is a huge setback.  I hope once again that we do not stand by the sad findings of the report. We need to change these policies immediately.

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Tarabella report is just another expression of the materialism, utilitarianism and egalitarianism that are rampant here. The report urges women who have chosen to work part-time to do so full-time. Too bad for those who have made the free choice to focus on the future of their children, they clearly do not fit the definition of female dignity according to Mr. Tarabella. Worse, this report is a praise of the culture of death by the explicit support it gives to abortion, a real weapon of mass destruction against European demographics.  Her vision of women is a thousand miles away from what European women are in the long running of history: a strong woman who is one of the keys to the rapid progress of our civilization. So here she is, this strong woman of European civilization, according to Mr Tarabella's miserly vision, suddenly reduced to victim status, to a woman who would need quotas to arrive at responsibilities as if she could not, by her intrinsic qualities, rise to the same rank as man.  Mr Tarabella, European women did not wait for your quotas to weigh in on the great political choices of our history, to show courage, to fight against totalitarianism as much as men. Women don't need you to secure their future because they wear it in their womb.  And finally, Mr Tarabella - since you are French like me - if you want to fight against stigma and stereotypes, start educating Mr Valls who carries the culture of hatred and stigma against his political opponents.  (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Give me the impression, dear colleague, that you have not read the Tarabella Report. Can you tell me which article requires a woman to work full time?

name: Aymeric Chauprade (NI)
text: "blue card" answer. "Madam, it is a clear eulogy... Just read the report. As for abortion, it is simply section 45 that praises it. Of course, this report has good intentions with regard to equality between men and women, and then it derives very quickly towards the praise of abortion against, moreover, the sovereignty of the Member States in this area.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE).
text: – Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, several speakers have already recalled that yesterday we celebrated International Women's Day. The world does not celebrate only on March 8 the woman. As human beings, we all have the same rights and duties, equal before the law, we all have to be respected in our dignity, every day, every moment, under any circumstances.  So on March 8th, we remember – that's right – the hard work that, unfortunately, we still have ahead of us. We recall the inequalities that still persist in the workplace and in access to education; we recall the struggle for the survival of the poor workers in the European Union, 80 % of them women; we remember the suffering that still plagues genital mutilation and domestic violence; we remember the girls and women who are victims of trafficking and pimping; we remember the ideologies and obediences that degrade women and subordinate her to man. Fighting for equal rights and opportunities for men and women must therefore be a cause that unites us all. In order for us to act, it is essential to know impartially the reality that surrounds us. This is the function of this report: to assess what was done or ceased to be done in 2013 in the European Union.   Despite some developments, 2013 proved to be another year of weak improvements. There are still many challenges ahead and this House must use all its efforts to ensure that all instruments already approved are actually implemented. I am fully aware that much depends on the Member States and, much more so, depends on an effective ability to change mentalities. However, I am sure that we will not fail to do our part, which begins by coming together around this idea that men and women do have the same rights and opportunities.  Mr President, I congratulate Marc Tarabella on his report. Fundamental rights are one of the most visible faces of our work. We have here a good document to guide our action. It is time to get to work and tomorrow we must clearly approve the Tarabella report.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D).
text: – (I thank Mr Tarabella) for the final document presented to us, but I would like to reflect and tell you that, while gender equality is discussed in Europe, the problem of women training who has no return in professional terms for not accessing the labour market and equal pay, while discussing this problem, we have, for example, a European Commission which is not exemplary in terms of parity. And a Parliament, this one, with a third of women. A Europe that pretends to be liberal when it comes to gay rights, which is shaded or always destiture, to discuss my right to decide on my body. A Europe that shrinks in the face of openness to the issue, for example, of the transgender. Who finds no effective ways to combat domestic violence. But in the meantime, I would like to remind you, it has already been spoken here by another Colleague, the trafficking of women. Trafficking in women because they're women. It's the trafficking of poverty. It's tragic! And the biggest tragedy is knowing that we, Europe, have business, more or less creased, with these countries.

name: Rikke Karlsson (ECR).
text: Mr President! When you read this report, it falls to my chest that you are doing exactly what you are accusing the Member States of, namely to discriminate! It is very clear that what has been done so far is to try to set out guidelines for the whole of Europe, and that is completely misguided. The fact is that the reality is as different as there are. It should be realised now that it was better to let the Member States decide for themselves where they want to take action against equality. Because in reality, European countries have a very fine tradition of creating equal rights for both sexes. The change of a culture goes through man himself, and it doesn't change just because someone says it should. Instead, move outside Europe towards the poor parts of the world, where women are still kept out of the education system and outside the labour market, where women's bodies are used as weapons of terror and war, to places where circumcision and violence against women are entirely accepted by the surrounding communities. This is where the main concern should lie. I recognise that violence against women is still a problem that we must work hard to bring to life worldwide. But free me from more legislation on mandatory gender quotas, on a lack of education for women and this kind of rhetoric, which I believe helps to produce and demean....

name: Anneli Jäätteenmäki (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, thanks to Mr Tarabella, he has done a good job and raised important issues. In fact, however, it has to be said that it is regrettable that, as recently as 2015, we are going to have to have a debate about why equality has not been achieved. So this debate takes place once a year. Important issues have been raised in this report, and I will raise three of them. Wage equality has still not materialised, but an even worse maladministration is reflected in pensions between men and women, because there is no pension accruing during maternity leave, during maternity leave. This leads to women's pensions in Europe being almost 40% lower than men's. This is a clear indication that equality has not been achieved.  15% of women of European pension age also do not receive any pension, so we still have a lot of work to do. Thanks.

name: Pablo Echenique (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, this report speaks of half the population of Europe. That half that does a lot more than half the job. Of that half he has yet to add to his career and his studies reproduction and care work that is little recognized and less remunerated. That half, however, have much lower wages and pensions, much lower working conditions and, in general, much higher levels of exploitation and misery than the other half.  That other half representing 63% of this House and nineteen of Mr Juncker's twenty-eight Commissioners and who will therefore have to decide what he is doing with the conclusions and proposals in this report: whether to repair a historical injustice and build a more equal and richer Europe or whether to turn this excellent report into wet paper and continue to impoverish and never bring our best half together.  It's time for bravery, it's now and with us.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. Mr. Nagy, you mentioned ethics and politics. I wonder if the issue of abortion and reproductive rights in your opinion is a matter of ethics or politics? Do you think subsidiarity is just an excuse, or is that an attitude for you? You haven't made that clear, is that a value issue for you?

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Blue card answer. "Look, I am in the thres of free choice, and I would like to say that everyone should have a balanced professional and personal life at their own choice. But the worst thing we can do, and I have said this, is that if we mix ethical and political issues at a time when we can make very important progress in balancing women's rights, and if we are going to break this up in political battles, we will never be able to move forward. Thank you very much!

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the promotion of the principle of equal opportunities between women and men, together with ensuring greater participation of women in economic and social life as a full protagonist, must become a reality at European level. I believe that the European Executive and the Member States must work closely together to promote a coherent strategy that will improve access to education for women in rural areas, social protection and vocational training, lifelong learning, effective local public health services. We must not forget that many rural women live in precarious conditions and do not receive pensions or their level is very low and, as such, they need increased attention from competent for a. I want to congratulate the rapporteur and the rapporteurs in the shadows and move from declarations to a genuine support for gender equality. We have to vote on the Tarabella Report.

name: Helga Stevens (ECR).
text: Mr President, tarabella's report certainly has its merits. Broadly speaking, the N-VA can agree to this, especially in the area of abortion, reproductive health and sexual rights for women, areas in which Belgium nevertheless plays a leading role. I am also very pleased with the specific attention in the report on women with disabilities and the reference to the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. Women with disabilities have far fewer opportunities in the labour market and, moreover, because girls with disabilities have fewer opportunities to study, they often end up in low-paid jobs as women.  Although employment figures are not the only factor in gender inequality, they can give an indication of the risk of poverty or social exclusion for women and girls with disabilities. With 40 million vulnerable women and girls in the EU, we need to tackle structural inequalities vigorously at all levels of policy.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Colleagues, I am a little sorry that part of the discussion is confrontational. I think that all of us should have a common goal, and that is the fulfilment of the principle of gender equality.  I would like to stick to the European Commission's 2013 monitoring, which provides clear data that the gender pay gap has still only minimally decreased by 1%, that the employment gap remains large by around 5%. Progress in increasing the proportion of women in political office is also insufficient, with only 27% of women in parliaments and governments taking part in decision-making on matters that concern everyone, including, of course, women.  The pension gap has not improved at all, 39%, that is an alarming number and I think it clearly shows how women in socio-economic positions are doing. I mention these figures because we must be concerned about changes in these areas, in which the European Union also has competences.  I want society, including the European Parliament, to appreciate the irreplaceable role of women in their motherhood and to support women in carrying out this mission. Don't get penalized for it.
