The report contains unacceptable recommendations for me on the right to abortion. Even today, much of the debate here focuses on this reference, which I do not think is part of the resolution. I am concerned that we should not miss a chance today to talk about what really leads to women's empowerment. This is a recognition of their responsibility and the creation of better conditions for the recognising of their parental and professional role.

name: Maria Arena (S&D).
text: Mr President, I thank our colleague Marc Tarabella for the excellent report he has made, also with other colleagues, with all the compromises that have been incorporated into this report.  This report shows us, indeed, that in the twenty-first century, we women are still victims of a great deal of inequality today. I use the word "victim" because, yes, when these inequalities are due to discrimination, well yes, we have to say that we are victims of these discriminations. Does that mean that we are unable to fight? Of course not. We are in the process of doing that today as part of this report.  This report makes a number of recommendations, which are voluntary policy recommendations, and I see that here in this House we all agree that there is inequality and that it is unfair, but there is a part of this Parliament that says , 'We must act' and there is another side that says: 'Let it happen' , it's going to work itself out." No, this is not going to be solved on its own, we need voluntary policies on quotas and the Istanbul Convention on Combating Violence against Women and the right to dispose of one's body so that we can decide when we want our motherhood.  And I will just return to this motherhood to say that it is a source of discrimination at the moment. It discriminates against young girls who want to go to work, it discriminates at the time of protection of pregnant women in employment, it makes them vulnerable because they can fall into poverty when they do not have a proper salary. All of this now means that we have poor employment rates for women and we have a drop in the birth rate.  All those who want to increase the birth rate in Europe, I encourage them to support the maternity leave directive. And it is not by putting the maternity leave directive in the REFIT scheme that we will solve all these problems. On the contrary, we need this maternity leave directive: I am once again sending the message to the Commission and I am also sending it to the Council.

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE).
text: – Mr President, indeed, the crisis has significantly hit the whole of Europe and especially groups such as women and other vulnerable groups. After this period of budgetary adjustment, a recovery has begun and it is also time to revive growth, as envisaged by the Europe 2020 Strategy when it spoke of employment, when it talked about education, innovation and, ultimately, smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. In this context, the Tarabella report is very timely and I will highlight from this report what unies us, and not what separates us. Paragraph 45, which deals with abortion, is one of the issues that could separate us, but indeed this report addresses others such as employment or equal pay, issues on which we have fought and legislate in Europe for fifty years and, although there have been achievements, they are not yet how effective they should be. There is a pay gap that can go in The Member States from 3% to 30% for work of equal value. And, therefore, we will have to continue working in this field. It also addresses quality employment, so that there is true equal opportunities in this field. And also everything related to co-education, with educating in equality. I've heard some comments here about stereotypes. When there are stereotypes, it's because you don't co-educate on equal opportunities. That's why it's important to break stereotypes and educate on values, which is to educate on equality. Another challenge is conciliation. Much has been legislate on this subject, but it is one of our outstanding subjects. And it also addresses everything related to gender-based violence, against which, I repeat, the best tool is education. I would also like to tell you that vulnerable groups, single mothers, immigrant women, women with disabilities, have special place in this report. It is worth noting all that the United Nations Convention proposes for women with disabilities. In short, the report deals with very important areas and I therefore highlight in capital letters what unies us and not what separates us. Congratulations!

name: Jutta Steinruck (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I would like to thank Marc Tarabella. I am sure that the majority of women in Europe would like to thank Marc Tarabella. I would like to make my point to the perpetual yesterdays here in this House: the main initiatives for the progress of women's equality in Europe came from The European level. There is still a lot of work to be done. My focus is on the labour market. Women are still disadvantaged. It has been said that 17% less pay for equal work. The participation rate of women is lower, women are much more likely to work part-time with forced work, women are under-represented when it comes to filling management positions, and the issue of old-age poverty is also a consequence of women's non-equal rights. A major step towards reducing these inequalities is the reconciliation of work and family life. To do this, we need the Maternity Leave Directive. I call on the Council to abandon its blockade, because women need protection just like newborn children. This would take equality in Europe a long way.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: – Mr. President, as a person advocating for the rule of law, I ask that the documents adopted by this Parliament respect the principle of subsidiarity which dictates that the area of reproductive health is under Article 168 TSR. treaty on the functioning of the European Union under the competence of the Member States.  The report on equality between men and women is problematic because it wants to put the European Parliament in a position as a promoter of abortion under women's sexual and reproductive rights as a means of achieving equality between women and men, which is unacceptable. By directly promoting abortion, the report falls outside the competence of the EU and internationally agreed definitions of the term 'reproductive health'. The European Union uses the official definition of "reproductive health" agreed at a 1994 UN conference in Cairo that explicitly excludes abortion from the term sexual and reproductive health. If the European Parliament accepts such a report, it violates the principle of subsidiarity and encroaches on the rights of the Member States of the European Union to decide independently on these issues to which over 153 000 citizens responded in just a few days in the petition and asked members to have abortions expelled from this report. The report does not support men and women who choose to start a family and have children, nor does it sufficiently problematize women's unpaid work at home; women and men who work for several weeks without a day's rest are also not taken into account. Therefore, I would like to draw renewed attention that the right to life is a basic human right that has been challenged around the world today and I once again call on you, respected colleagues and colleagues, to protect human life.  We will not achieve right-by-law by taking away someone else's rights, but to ensure equal starting positions and chances for everyone. If we don't even allow someone to be born, then we're promoters of inequality. As a person who advocates equal opportunities for all, I urge you to respect the Golden Rule and to protect your life. (The Speaker agreed to answer the question by raising the blue card on the basis of Article 162(8) of the Code of Health. Rules of procedure.)

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. Mrs. Petir, thank you for accepting the blue card. I cannot possibly accept your statement that the European Parliament is in the service of promoting abortion. I ask you if you are aware that many women have to have an abortion for health reasons, are you aware that many women have had unwanted conceptions? Just think of everything that was happening in Bosnia and Herzegovina. I'm asking you, will you vote for Tarabella's report tomorrow?

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – Mr. Jakovcic, if abortion remains within this report and the European Parliament adopts it, then the European Parliament is putting itself in the role of Member States and thus undermining the principle of subsidiarity, which I believe none of the members who advocate the rule of law can accept.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank Marc Tarabella and all colleagues for their excellent work on this report. Women’s rights are a cause the EU has always advanced over the years, and it continues to be important for my country, the UK, and my constituency, the North West of England – important for both men and for women. The issue I want to highlight is empowering women in entrepreneurship. As a woman entrepreneur and a women’s rights activist, I know first hand that this is an important way to foster women’s leadership in society. The role of women in small to medium enterprises – and especially in social enterprises – is crucial for the EU 2020 goal of smart, sustainable and inclusive growth, for example, in respect of new green technologies.  The need for action to empower women is clear. Only 31% of entrepreneurs in the EU are women, so from this Chamber we must call on the Commission and Member States to pursue innovative policies to promote women in entrepreneurship.

name: Inés Ayala Sender (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to congratulate Marc Tarabella on a measured and balanced report which is very useful for us to move forward and which deserves to be approved tomorrow by a large majority and without any section being amputated — because no one is obliged to have an abortion, it is only a question of women in Europe being treated as adults and in accordance with the advances of the 21st century and not as in the Middle Ages. On this day after March 8, the annual balance of progress in equality casts lights and shadows: lights because progress is made very slowly, and shadows because these advances are threatened as soon as the situation changes. Thus, the economic crisis and austerity have hit women much harder, impoverishing them to despair. Nor is progress being made in all sectors: courageous women who must overcome double discrimination and harassment in highly masculinized sectors, such as the armed forces. That's how it happened to Commander Zaida Cantera, whom I want to pay tribute to from here. Nor is progress being made in all countries.  I deeply regret that Spain, which with the Socialist Government was a model in progress and legislation on equality, must now be criticised by the European Union because budget cuts have seriously affected and improved the availability and quality of childcare services. That is the hypocrisy on the right: the garments are torn by paragraph 45 in the name of life and children, but at the first crisis they cut and impoverish the care of children. It turns out, actually, grotesque.

name: Clare Moody (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank Mr Tarabella for this very important report. As a member of the Committee on Budgets I welcome the recommendation that gender be put at the heart of our considerations on this committee. In addition, it is the case that women in the UK and the EU more widely have paid a very high price for policies since the financial crash. In the UK a study of revenue raised from tax and benefit changes showed 85% of the total of these cuts have been taken from the pockets of women. This is on top of the stagnation of the gender pay gap that pushes the goal of equal pay decades into the future. Finally I am very glad that Marc has emphasised the importance of addressing violence against women. Fahma Mohamed from Bristol in my constituency, at the age of 14, has led a campaign against FGM. Women across the UK and the EU have bravely fought against this practice. This is just one, severe, example of violence against women that we must stand up against. Yet the UK Government has failed to ratify the Istanbul Convention. For all these reasons we must vote for this important report tomorrow.

name: Elly Schlein (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too would like to thank Marc Tarabella for this report, which is strong and balanced but also very painful, because it gives us back the glimpse of a Europe that is still a long way from equality between women and men. Women are paying even higher the price of the crisis, reduced to living welfare, with increasingly precarious jobs and the incomprehensible scandal of the wage gap at 16 %. There is no reason in the world why, for the same work, a woman must take less than a man. This is medieval. We therefore need strong answers, such as those called for in the report, and we need conciliation policies. Discrimination involves many areas, the report approaches them all courageously: the right, for example, of women to decide on their own bodies, because that too is where true equality passes, and the need to ensure the full participation of women in decision-making processes because, if they are so under-represented both on the boards of large companies and in politics, should we think that we are inadequate or uninterested in politics? Or recognise the devious discrimination that is taking place? Well, I believe that we cannot continue to look at reality with one eye closed, that of women, because in the long run we all become blind. So let us begin to open it tomorrow by voting on this report.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D).
text: Mr. President, I thank my colleague Marc Tarabella for a job well done. I believe that economic equality is a basic precondition for gender equality. By holding back proposals concerning gender equality, the Council and the Commission tell half the population of the European Union that their fundamental human rights to equality can wait. It is the same as claiming that women want to be unemployed, do the whole of January and February for free compared to male counterparts, and in old age remain without a pension. Since in relation to men as many as 20% of women gain even higher education more, to pretend that the current situation is satisfactory is absolutely insane. At this rate, equal pay for equal work will not be achieved until 2084. That is why I am proud that women's entrepreneurship is on the rise in Croatia, I am proud that we bring gender quotas into parliament, because active and mandatory measures are the key to good changes. Let's not repeat last year's disgrace, let's show those who, by trying to overthrow computer systems and disabling the work of Europarlamentaries, want to take Europe back to the Middle Ages. That's not going to work. Support fundamental rights tomorrow, for the women's cause. We need to show them we're here for them.

name: Edouard Martin (S&D).
text: Mr President, "My name is Pauline, I have just graduated. This is my first job. On a professional appointment, I am easily kissed and kissed, while one wants and shakes the hand of my fellow men. But I'm lucky because I'm often not looked me in the eye. In a way, I know I have to do more than they do to be taken seriously. Do I also have to masculinize myself?" " My name is Marion. I'm a young mom. Returning from maternity leave, I was lucky enough to have a place in a nursery for my son. At work, I applied for a promotion because I have the required experience and skills recognized by all. Unfortunately, it was my male colleague who was chosen because he will be "more available" than me. I will go to court but without my employer's obligation to inform, I know it will be difficult to prove discrimination." "My name is Chantal. I'm retired. Strangely, my pension is lower than that of my former factory colleagues for the same number of years of contributions. Wage inequality reverberates even after working life."  So, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, do we think we have achieved equality between men and women in Europe?  (Applause)

name: Jens Nilsson (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Thank you Mr Tarabella for an excellent report. Not least because it also highlights violence against women. It is completely incomprehensible that there are still people who think that a man can abuse a woman as much as possible if it is within the walls of the house. However, I would also like to take part in that debate as a member of the Committee on Transport. Research shows that travel patterns between men and women are very different across Europe – men travel more cars, women travel more public transport and bicycles – and it is men who make decisions about transport systems. In my role as gender coordinator in the Committee on Transport and Tourism, I am looking at how we can work with transport systems that respond equally to the transport needs of women and men. We need a transport policy that actively highlights gender equality. A functioning and effective transport policy is of great economic importance to Europe, and if we are to increase the sector's potential, we must also have a feminist transport policy.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank Marc Tarabella for his report. In gender equality the widest gaps tend to be in the areas of time and power. We see this every day; women are still under-represented in politics. While 36.9% of MEPs are women, every day we see male-dominated committees and meetings. In the UK, the Labour Party has pledged that half of the cabinet will be women. Meanwhile, the Tory-Liberal Democrat front bench is a sea of suits and ties, vastly dominated by men. It is Labour leading the way in gender equality and political parity in the UK. UKIP has announced that it intends to abolish the position of Minister for Women and Equalities and halve maternity pay. We need to strive for gender equality right across Europe, to tackle the many problems faced by women on equal pay and pensions, under-representation of women in decision-making positions, violence and in—work poverty. I urge you to support – for all women and girls and their aspirations – Marc Tarabella’s report. (Applause)

name: Sergio Gaetano Cofferati (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I wanted to draw your attention to a novelty that has been created in the labour market ... (inaudible sound) that can be imagined between man and woman and that risks becoming a real emergency. In his fine report Marc Tarabella refers to the OECD's projections on equal participation, saying what the possible margin for European GDP growth is if this difference is resolved. And right after that, not coincidentally, he talks about poverty.  There are traditional forms of female poverty, but there is also a new one: the one concerning 'poor work'. At one time the poor were predominantly a person without a job and therefore without a salary. Today there are millions of people who work and with what they earn do not cross the poverty line. The vast majority of them are women. So we must have active policies in the labour market, not only to create opportunities, but to use training in such a way that this does not once again fall on women's shoulders. That is why it is very important to approve Mr Tarabella's report and then to work towards policies that are consistent with its content.

name: Pier Antonio Panzeri (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the positive work carried out by Marc Tarabella is part of the more general path to extend the rights of people, and women in particular, and points to the decisive points so that the distances that still separate from the objective of equality are bridged as soon as possible.  I am convinced that this resolution must highlight – and I say this to the Commission – the important task that is certainly to be entrusted to the European Parliament but above all to the European Commission when it comes to rights: to show coherence in all the policies we develop and to commit individual States to comply with best practices in the field of gender equality. , overcoming this alibi – constantly recalled and behind which we often hide – of the legislative autonomy of the individual States. I would like to remind you that a society that is afraid of rights and their extension is simply afraid of its own future and the European Union, I believe, cannot be the continent of fear.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: – I am the last to speak in this debate and I wanted to say an awful lot, but I will limit I to at least a few such important things. First of all, I am in this House for the third period and I have had some really big debates here, and the report tabled by Marc Tarabella is, from my point of view, just like Marc Tarabella. She's good, she's balanced, she's progressive and she has a big heart – and that's the message we women need. We do not need it for us who are in the European Parliament, nor even for those of us who are in politics. We need it for women who get up every morning and have to think about how to make money so they can raise their children. We need it for women who are still underpaid in our democratic countries than men. We need it for our grandmothers, who have lower pensions than their grandfathers. We need it so that women can do quality work. That is the report presented by Marc Tarabella, which is why I have great respect for him and am glad that he is my colleague.

name: Alessandra Mussolini (PPE).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, after all the shocking things I have heard in this House – and this is 2015 – I am not only voting in favour of the Tarabella report and also of Article 45, but I would like us to be able to vote next year on a report that enshrines women's superiority over men, because that is the truth. So let us also do something else for equality – and I am not going to dwell on what my fellow Members have said and I agree with them – these blue cards too, let us begin to provide for pink cards too, Mr President: blue card and pink card, that is equality.

name: José Blanco López (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I have been part of a government which drafted a law against gender-based violence, of a unitary government. From a government that pushed for a law so that women could decide on their motherhood. From a government that pushed for women to be on board and reduce the pay gap. And I say this because today, fortunately three years after that government ceased to exist, women are already threatened to be able to decide on their motherhood, there are fewer resources for gender-based violence, the pay gap has already increased, fewer women are already on the board of directors of companies. That is why I think this report is very important. Because the struggle for women's equality is not a struggle that ends with a norm or a law. Here's an example. What I just demonstrated is that the laws, the rules, were not enough. Equality must be conquered every day. Equality has to be worked on every day, because there is still a big difference. It is not possible that we have to wait, I do not know how many years the report says, so that there is real equality. So that the woman, working the same, doing the same job as the man, has the same salary. Until we achieve that equality, of course, until we get women for the same job to take the same thing, there will be no real equality.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, the economic crisis, austerity and the memoranda experienced by the countries of the European south have a serious impact on societies and on the achievement of equality between men and women. In Greece the memorandum led women to poverty and social marginalisation. Thus, according to official data, 60% of the registered unemployed in the OAED are women and amount to 518,000. At the same time, however, only 15% of these unemployed women receive unemployment benefit. Also, while women's unemployment in 2009, before the memorandum, was 14.4% in 2014 the rate has risen to 29.3% well above the unemployment rate of men reaching 23.4%.  At the same time, the pay gap between men and women has increased and, with the disintegration of the public sector by the troika and the imposition of flexible forms of employment, Greek women are now in an unfavourable position and motherhood has been undermined.

name: Bill Etheridge (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, back in Britain people often ask: ‘How could things have changed so much? How have things become different? We never voted for any of this’. But now I can see, and I will be able to explain it better. Hidden behind a very serious issue such as women’s rights – which is absolutely important – we have another statist or super-state power grab telling companies how many people they can employ and what kind, saying what you can do in the household and who does the chores.  Maybe we will have a European arrest warrant if you do not put the toilet seat down properly. This is the kind of thing that drives people mad. Behind a very serious issue you paint on a bleeding heart, but behind it you are grabbing more and more power. Dr Martin Luther King wanted to see, in his dream, people treated on the merits of their character, not on quotas. He was a true fighter for freedom, not like the weasels of the British Labour Party who have been here today and sold the same tissue of lies that they continue to sell constantly. They are a disgrace and they will be defeated.

name: Diane Dodds (NI).
text: – Mr President, while I agree that there is an onus on legislators to encourage women to enter the labour market in greater numbers, I stand fully behind the principle of merit and – importantly in the European context – the principle of subsidiarity in terms of legislation, and not the federalism that we have seen here today. We should focus on helping grassroots organisations to build capacity and skills and foster personal development. I reject completely the encroachment of this report on the right to life of the unborn child. However, I welcome the focus on the serious issue of violence against women. It is estimated by Women’s Aid in Northern Ireland that 25% of women will have suffered from violence at some stage in their life. They further estimate that 30% of these cases start during pregnancy – a truly shocking statistic. I am encouraged to hear the Commission respond positively to a call for a European Year on Combating Violence Against Women, but dismayed to hear of a potential delay. We must hurry to combat this abhorrent practice.

name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by It is very good that every year we talk about the extent to which we are able to implement the provisions of the European Treaty when it comes to equality between women and men. Today, there have been determinations that quotas in companies are a humiliation for women. I think the 39% pension gap in Europe is much more humiliating. This is a shame for every Member State and it is clear that we must do something about it. The pension gap accumulates inequalities from the labour market throughout life and shows an uneven, unbalanced division of roles in homes. So it is clear that gender mainstreaming must be implemented not only by the Ministry of Labour, but also by the Ministry of Justice, the Ministry of Infrastructure and the Ministry of Education, and in the end it must be taken seriously in order for us to overcome these embarrassing inequalities in Europe.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like, first of all, to underline one very important fact. In reality, the female unemployment rate is underestimated when you take into consideration that many women are not registered as unemployed, particularly, for example, those women living in remote areas or in rural areas, and women who also devote themselves to their families, to childcare and to looking after their houses. I would like to raise another issue concerning the situation of small and medium—sized enterprises in Europe, which provide about 70% of private sector jobs, where the rate of entrepreneurship among women in the European Union is about 10%, which is half the rate among men. Only about 30% of entrepreneurs in the European Union are women. I therefore suggest, Madam Commissioner, that we should introduce and promote new programmes at European Union level, in order to increase entrepreneurship among women.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: Mr. President, I cannot possibly support this report. While it should focus on progress in the area of equality between women and men according to its title, I believe it does the exact opposite and most recommendations put women back in a position before emancipation. Here's an example. The report asks Member States to include strategies in rural development programmes aimed at increasing the number of jobs in rural areas for women. Shouldn't we be fighting such a division of jobs into male and female? Haven't women been fighting such discrimination for decades? As a police officer in Canada, I myself, about thirty years ago, I redefined a position that was intended for only one gender, and with my persistence I became the first policewoman on a motorcycle in that country. Therefore, it is not even in my mind today to start representing the views that I once abhorned with loathing.  Colleagues, if we really care about respecting the laws of gender equality, let's first fight to enforce laws that already exist. Because just proposing new laws for political points doesn't benefit anyone, especially women.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the issue of women and the support that the community must dutifully give them in all the challenges it faces can no longer be postponed, not only in order to achieve the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy but also to re-establish a principle of nature, which requires definitive and total gender equality. I congratulate Marc Tarabella on the important and excellent work he has done and I hope that the motion for a resolution, with which I fully agree, will lead to progress on the road to equality of substance, since inequalities still persist which manifest themselves in a sneaky and inexorable way in the silences and discomfort of the poverty of couples, in the vulnerability of the weakest categories of women. , in the painful renunciation of the most basic prospects of life, even if these are the latter legitimate aspirations of individuals and the obligation of any institutional charter that respects itself. It is therefore a moral obligation to encourage a change of mentality, prohibiting any form of discrimination which, when not curbed, emphasises rather than protects the difficulties and precariousness linked to disability, motherhood, childhood, work and the care of older women.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by All just people are fighting discrimination against women, but this report is not about discriminating against women, it is not about duly remunerating women who have devoted themselves entirely to working from home, to have the same pensions, good pension rights. It's about social engineering, it's about a society without mom and dad. It's a society where mom and dad replace individuals without identities, it's about ideological attrition. And it is also about hitting the right of the human person to life, which has been the foundation of legal civilization since the time of Rome.  I would like to thank many Members, including members from outside my club, members of the European People's Party, for their voice in defence of the civilization of life.  Finally, it is a report that deprives Member States of the right to act where they have the right to act. And this is not an alibi, it is the principle of subsidiarity that must be respected.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: Mr. President, I want to emphasize right from the beginning that we are all equal. We are all equal and we are born equal. We were born free. But then something happens to us, so we're not free anymore and we're not equal anymore.  That's why I'm surprised and surprised by the appearances of some of our colleagues here, because we were born free and equal. You can read more about this in the Bible, in those words that Jesus used.  And today we here make a distinction between a man and a woman. It really doesn't make any sense. That is why I invite you to support this report, because I am deeply convinced that only our equality, gender and any other makes sense during our lifetime.

name: Ángela Vallina (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, I wanted to make very clear the position of the GUE/NGL Group, because as little as I finish my speech, some Members of this House have begun to disseminate over the networks that the GUE/NGL Group's position had been contrary to abortion (the decision-making power of women and the free decision). Nothing further from reality. I do not know whether it has been due to a misinterpretation of translation or has other causes, but I want to make it very clear that both the position of the GUE/NGL Group and that of my party or my own are in favour of free abortion and the fundamental capacity and right of decision of women in this regard.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank you for your discussion, which gave me a lot of inspiration for our work. I was already clear at the beginning that my team and I are very committed to supporting a strong policy promoting equality and equal opportunities. I also support the ideas contained in the Tarabella report because it contains innovative ways and innovative solutions. I mean that in this aspect we are very coherent because we also want to bring new policy supporting equal opportunities. I would also like to draw your attention to the new figures we published last week which show that not much progress has been achieved in the last year. I also wanted to add that we are aware that not only legislation can help but also very strong campaigning and strong promotion in the media and in other sources where we can push this policy forward. As for innovative solutions, we want to support the idea of entrepreneurship and of strong women getting the chance in the economy. I want to say that, after the crisis, we can see in the figures from sources other than from the Commission that women used the crisis as a chance and we have a very high percentage of new companies established by women. I also think this is something we need to encourage in our policy, not only by means of quotas which was criticised here but also by means of other incentives. I myself wish that Mr Tarabella’s report be adopted tomorrow and I am convinced that this will support our common efforts in the field of the policy of equality.

name: Marc Tarabella
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, first of all I would like to say to Mr Chauprade, who has already left, that I am not French like him, as he said. I am not offended that people say I am French, but I am a Belgian elected official. I am one of the 40% of Belgians whose French is my mother tongue. But more seriously in relation to this debate: two particular points, often mentioned, and a general observation. First, quotas. It has been talked about many times, and the first to do so was Mrs Atkinson who said, "We do not need quotas. In fact, at home, Ukip, we are a good example." I notice that she does not know how to calculate, because Ukip is 6 women out of 23 elected, i.e. 30%. This is less than the average of many political groups. In this regard, in his political group, I would like to salute the Movimento 5 Stelle, which includes 8 out of 17 women. In other words, almost half of the elected officials are elected.  On quotas, I would like to pay tribute to one man: it is a European conservative named Ansgar Gabrielsen, Norwegian Minister for Industry and Economy. In 2001, he found that in 1993 there were 3% women on the boards of large corporations in Norway. When he became a minister, he said, "That has to change." He introduced quotas to the general criticism, especially from the Conservatives, and what happened? In 2008, there were 43% women on the boards of large corporations in Norway. It is the highest rate in the world. We had to have quotas. They are a necessary evil, but they can no longer be questioned, since society is not evolving as quickly as it should.  Secondly, the principle of subsidiarity, often mentioned. This is not where we are starting it, it is a report of initiative. So we are not going to change the laws in the Member States, we are not going into their domestic policy, in their competence. However, it is normal that when we talk about women's rights, and therefore inequality, we can address all rights and take stock at European level. If we do not talk about this issue in this chamber, we will not talk about it anywhere.  General observation: I thank all the colleagues who generally appreciated the report. I hope it will be voted on tomorrow, because it is a matter of talking and focusing on equality between women and men, and especially on inequality, trying to reduce them more quickly than is the case today.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place on Tuesday 10 March 2015. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. Equality between men and women should be one of the pillars of any society that wants to be modern. The Tarabella report on progress on equality between women and men in the European Union in 2013 addresses exactly this issue, exploring not only educational and role-perception aspects, but also purely economic aspects. These are, in fact, the most pragmatic dimension of the problem, in addition to the aspects, which have been found to be highly divisive, relating to the protection of sexual and reproductive rights.  Easy access to contraception and abortion guarantee the free choice of each individual in relation to his body and the 5 Star Movement has therefore voted in favour of the text, confirming the will expressed by the Italians during two different referendums.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. – Every year we discuss a report on progress towards equality between women and men in the European Union, and every year, unfortunately, we find that progress is slow and we need to continue to insist on key issues such as the fight against gender-based violence, which is the most widespread human rights violation in the world and which affects all strata of society; the incorporation of women into the equal labour market, without discrimination of any kind; the wage gap, which remains stable at an average of 16.4% in the EU and has even increased in some countries such as Spain; sexual and reproductive health rights, including the right to abortion under safe legal and health conditions; the difficult reconciliation of family and work life, which prevents many women from doing full-time jobs and even forces them to leave the labour market; the situation of vulnerable groups of women, such as disabled women or women in rural areas; or the poor representation of women in political and economic decision-making. There's a lot to do, but together we'll make it.

name: Adam Gierek (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Work-life balance is needed in order not to increase the impoverishment of families. National and local authorities need to be integrated into childcare in order to ensure the care and education of pre-school children. The priority is to establish parental leave so that it can be used by men.  Statistics show that women earn around 15% less than men in equivalent positions. About 70% of men sit in national parliaments and more than 80% on the boards of large companies. The crisis affects the employment rate of women, who mostly work in low-paid public services. More than 90% of single parents are women who are not in employment or part-time, which reduces their material status and family standard of living. Women's pensions are about 40% lower than for men, and a third of women in Europe do not receive a pension at all!  Violence against women and the family is a serious problem. Women's access to sexual and reproductive health services is also limited. In conclusion, gender equality issues need to be integrated into policy-making procedures so that EU funds are used more efficiently. The most urgent need is to enforce Directive 2006/54/EC and the objectives of the EUROPE 2020 strategy in order to combat stereotypes and vertical and horizontal occupational segregation.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. –  In gender equality, the widest gaps tend to be in the areas of ʽtimeʼ and ʽpowerʼ. We see this everyday – women are still under-represented in politics. While 36.9 % of MEPs are female, every day we see male dominated committees and meetings. In the UK, the Labour Party has pledged that half of the Cabinet will be female. Meanwhile, the Tory/Liberal Democrat front bench is a sea of suits and ties – vastly dominated by men. UKIP has announced that it intends to abolish the position of Minister for Women and Equalities and halve maternity pay if elected in May. We need to strive for gender equality right across Europe to tackle the many problems faced by women – equal pay, violence against women, the level of women on boards, etc. This report and the monitoring done by the European Institute for Gender Equality are invaluable – they point out to us the work that still needs to be done and how to tackle gender inequality.

name: Филиз Хюсменова (ALDE)
text: in writing. – Dear Mr President, the European Parliament, the EC, the Council, the Member States and all of us, as EU citizens, must work towards the realisation of gender equality not only as political declarations, but also in the daily practical activities we carry out. The Strategy for Equality between Women and Men 2010-2015 failed to meet its objectives. The economic disparities between women and men are increasing, there remains a significant difference in their participation in the labour market - in the pay of their work, in pension payments. In order to achieve the europe 2020 objectives, we need to join forces to advance the horizontal equality policy. It is necessary for all Member States to effectively implement the Directive on the application of the principle of equal opportunities and equal treatment of men and women in employment and occupation, as well as updating the Maternity Leave Directive 1992. Progress on gender equality policy remains insufficient. I believe that women's equality will contribute to achieving sustainable growth in Europe, and I call for systematic and consistent gender mainstreaming in all our activities, structures, policies and priorities.

name: Benedek Jávor (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. – According to a 2014 report by the Fundamental Rights Agency, one third of women in the EU suffer violence, with an estimated 3-400 000 women and their children living in the hell of domestic violence in Hungary. The decision of the Hungarian Parliament last Tuesday that the Fidesz-Jobbik coalition rejected the proposal for a resolution by Zsuzsanna Szelényi, who called for the ratification of the Istanbul Convention, is a sad topicality. Although my country signed the Convention at the beginning of 2014, its ratification, or real transposition, was not urgent for the right! To justify the refusal, we have come to know from the mouth of a right-wing congresswoman such blushing, born-written arguments that it is the fault of the Convention that it does not cover abortion, even though, in her view, it is also a form of domestic violence. And fidesz is sunny, and the topic is visibly embarrassing even for the party of blind comondors. I sincerely hope that my fellow Member, Ildikó Pelczné Gáll, as an alternate member of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, will be able to better promote and adopt with her hungarian party colleagues european values that do not include the rejection of the Convention and the snuffing out of the issue of violence against women. Dear Colleagues, Let us do our uts to ensure that the Istanbul Convention is ratified as soon as possible, that new opportunities in the Convention in the fight against violence against women can be taken into action.

name: Georg Mayer (NI)
text: Writing. – Apart from the gross violation of the principle of subsidiarity, it must be said that all the bourgeois values on which the European Union ultimately is built are also being trampled underfoot. The member states should be imposed on gender mainstreaming, unverifiable grounds for asylum and the human right to abortion, while the classic model of a family is likely to be pushed out of society. The points dealt with in the report under the guise of supposed equality between women and men are not only in favour of a quota system in all areas, but also explicitly in favour of a human right to abortion. It is also worth questioning why such an important issue as equality between women and men has been mixed up with the other issues that have already been mentioned in this report.

name: Péter Niedermüller (S&D)
text: Writing. – On the basis of this report, we can say firmly that we still have a great deal of work to do in the area of gender equality. This Parliament, the Council or the Commission does not have a magic wand to remove these problems in one fell swoon. But it is our duty to do what is in their power as soon as possible.  For this reason, this Parliament rightly calls on the Commission to encourage the ratification of the Istanbul Convention by the Member States and the introduction of common policies based on it to combat violence against women and domestic violence; (a) the Council to address the merits of the Maternity Leave Directive and the proposal for measures to improve the gender ratio in the management of listed companies; and Member States to extend EU rules protecting women to migrants.  There are those in Europe and in this Parliament who imagine that, in the name of some ideal family model they envision, they have the right to tell women how they should live. What kind of family should they have, what careers they can pursue, when to have children. Moreover, they are not even ashamed to invoke the interests of women or their respect for women. This is simply verbal oppression and shameful hypocrisy. Ensuring each other's freedom, whether women or men, is the only way to create a democratic and just society.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. - The European Union's single action to end violence against women is very important. All EU Member States must accede to the Istanbul Convention on the Prevention and Prevention of Violence against Women and Domestic Violence of the Council of Europe. Accession to the Convention provides the basis for close international cooperation in combating violence against women.  The treatment of women in war zones remains a major problem. Unfortunately, violence against women is often used as a weapon in military conflicts. This is a shameful violation of human rights and the international community has an important role to play in ending it.  In addition to combating violence against women, gender equality must also focus on reducing the pay gap and increasing women's economic independence.

name: Julia Pitera (PPE)
text: in writing. – One of the conditions for effective EU policy is that the Union and the Member States determine rules and conditions under which services of general economic interest for promoting social and territorial cohesion will function. Parliament and the Council establish those rules and specify conditions while taking care not to impinge upon the competences of the Member States. Matters of conscience certainly belong to those competences. The report by Marc Tarabella on ʽProgress on Equality between Women and Men in the EU in 2013ʼ is not controversial. On the contrary, it elicited positive opinions. Points 44 and 45 are therefore surprising in this context. The inclusion in the report of these two points, which do not have any value, can only be a politically-motivated manoeuvre: it devalues the essence of the document and diverts the course of the discussion. The vital points of substance that it raises are obscured by what should be matters of conscience. The European Unionʼs motto is ʽUnity in Diversityʼ. This means that to provide peace and prosperity, as well as preserve the wealth of cultures, traditions and languages in Europe, Europeans should act together. Is the trap concealed in this report truly in the spirit of this idea?

name: Laurențiu Rebega (S&D)
text: in writing. – I believe that this clear approach to equality between men and women, especially in the labour market, is not only a fair approach, but also absolutely necessary. The need to formulate tangible proposals to reconcile work and family life, which does not penalise women's position in society, is a mandatory action, which the EU institutions must follow up on. A more balanced division of occupational, family and social responsibilities between women and men could bridge the gap in women's active participation in the labour market. I believe that the Member States must support paid paternity leave, not only to balance the social mechanism, but also for the education of children, which can be done by both sides.

name: Yana Toom (ALDE)
text: in writing. – In spite of European integration and harmonisation of national legislation with EU law, the situation of Eastern European women on the labour market is characterised by systemic discrimination. This is reflected in lower income, lack of representation at the highest levels of the career ladder and concentration in the less prestigious and less profitable sectors of the economy. Particularly vulnerable are women of childbearing age. The UN Committee on the Elimination of Discrimination against Women has also repeatedly expressed its concerns about the persistence in many Eastern European countries of stereotypes concerning the roles and responsibilities of women and men in the family and in society, which overemphasise the traditional roles of women as mothers and spouses, undermine women’s social status, and hamper their equal participation in political and economic life. Authorities of all countries should also continue their efforts to solve the problem of domestic violence.

name: Ελισσάβετ Βόζεμπεργκ (
text: PPE), in writing. – Abortion and women's reproductive rights have always been sensitive social issues, which still concern societies and people of all ages, regardless of gender. This is because they are directly linked to the coming into the world of a new life, around which key ethical, legal and medical issues are directed, which are the subject of conflicting theories.  This explains the differences in the laws of the Member States on this issue, which demonstrates the dependence of legislation on the issue in many cases on established social and religious views. What we need to understand, in any case, is that in this area it is not just black or white, so all different views seem to have their own social, moral or legal basis. It is our responsibility to focus on the progress of race equality and all the individual issues related to it.  Personally, as a woman but also as a lawyer, who is particularly concerned with family and criminal law in Greece, where abortion is allowed under certain strict conditions, I believe that the gap between free access to abortion and the protection of the rights of pregnant women can be bridged by careful legislative study, taking into account serious medical factors.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the report by Morten Messerschmidt, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the annual report on EU competition policy (2014/2158(INI)) (A8-0019/2015).

name: Morten Messerschmidt
text: Rapporteur. Mr President! I have been looking forward to this debate, it is great that, although the time is a little long, we can achieve everything that is on the agenda.  Competition policy is an extremely important element of the internal market. It is like the traffic rules on the roads: if you do not agree on when to respect a red light, when to drive, etc., then there will be total chaos. That is why it is of course also a pleasure to be able to work with the Danish Commissioner, Margrethe Vestager, in relation to competition policy. Equally pleasure, however, has been to work with the rapporteurs from the various groups, and I am extremely pleased with the compromise reached in committee, which I am sure will also be voted through tomorrow in this Chamber. There are a number of new elements that we have not seen before in Parliament's own-initiative reports on competition policy, and I would like to highlight them here in my introductory remark.  First of all, that the European Parliament is now taking seriously the real-world challenges of social dumping. And not only does it take them seriously, so that it is mentioned in the various committees and committees that are around the house here, but that it becomes a horizontal approach so that, whatever kind of policy we are talking about – for example, as today with competition policy – it becomes a natural element. We are currently seeing, in the field of aviation, for example, how, in several EU countries, not to say in all EU countries, we are being challenged fiercely, how employees are being pushed to the limit and sometimes beyond what is acceptable. I am glad that in such a sensitive area we have nevertheless been able to find a formulation that all groups can live with, and I expect that to be the case tomorrow.  Another element, of course, which has not been dealt with before, all the while it has not existed before, is what has gradually become a vernacular: Luxleaks. In other words, the whole question of how certain Member States have used tax policy to attract businesses and thus tax dollars. For me, as rapporteur, it is important to stress that this issue is very important, but that it is also a theme that can be dealt with in the field of competition policy, which must be manageable in the field of competition policy! When we vote tomorrow, I know that this is something that can divide the house a bit: should we use it as leverage for a common harmonised tax policy that some groups want, or is it something that we can deal with within state aid rules? In my mind, it's the last. I clearly believe that using your tax policy to discriminate against competing companies is a breach of state aid rules.  A third element which is important to mention and which I believe plays a major role in many of our countries also in the election campaign is the question of how we use the structural funds. When companies are supported by the EU, it should be on improving conditions where businesses are located, not moving jobs out.  I welcome the fact that all these elements have been addressed in this report, just as I welcome the fact that many of the areas where citizens expect more proactive action have also been clarified in relation to the need to implement the third energy liberalisation directive, otherwise it makes no sense to talk at all about an energy union and the benefits that lies in it, within the economic potential of building a digital single market. In this context, I would also like to thank Kaja Kallas very much for the enormous contribution she and the IMCO have made to this report. And now that we are at the digital, it is clear that there is one digital player in particular that has played a very special role: Google. I would like to thank everyone, not least Ramon Tremosa in Balcells, for his constructive approach to this particular issue, and I am pleased that a compromise has been reached. And then I would like to stress one thing: in this report it is not Google that is, as such, on trial. What we are concerned about is that we have now negotiated – or have seen the negotiations run for four years, that we have seen the Commission make one move after another and that the matter has still not been resolved. So what is really on trial here is the Commission's confidence that we can continue to trust that the Commission will handle such cases within a reasonable period of time and in a proper way. I hope that tomorrow we will be able to put an end to and, by a large majority, to be contented in this report.

name: Margrethe Vestager
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur, the shadow rapporteurs and Mrs Kallas, who have drawn up the opinion for the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. I think this is a very solid piece of work. It reiterates the values and the very solid platform of our competition policy, but it also points to some of the very important sectors that we have been discussing in recent years. On the values, the basics and the platform of our competition policy, I think it is very important that it stresses how competition is part of our democracy, and this prevents great concentration on capital and ensures that those who have the talent and the initiative who want to make their case can actually do that in an open market.  I think it is very important to stress – as is done in the report – that, in times of crisis, competition rules should not be relaxed. On the contrary, we need to keep our markets open to give everyone a fair chance. As the rapporteur mentioned just now, competition policy is a very important tool in achieving a number of goals, namely an energy union and digital single markets as well as capital markets. We have plenty of knowledge to share. I very much look forward to the debate today and also to standing by my promise from the hearing to listen to, and work with, Parliament when it comes to the way forward. I will say just a few words on three very high priority areas: firstly, an energy union. The aims are relatively simple: independent, secure, cheap and sustainable supply. It is very important that we implement the legislation that we already have. Then we have a solid platform on which to build our energy union. The role of competition policy is, among other things, to keep an eye on energy companies that re-erect barriers to the internal market to ensure that companies cannot shield themselves from competition. On the digital single market, it is quite obvious that we need a single market because we have very national markets today and it is, of course, consumers and small businesses who pay the price. We need to make sure that we have full-blown competition and to make sure that new technologies can actually reach the citizen. Competition helps our small companies to challenge large and dominant players. Last, but not least, as was mentioned, tax fairness and transparency. To work with tax, with competition tools, is not a question of using the back door. It is straightforward and out in the open. We need the transparency to make sure that we do not use tax policy to create unfair competition. I am very much looking forward to the debate today and I think it is part of the working relationship between Parliament and Commission.

name: Kaja Kallas
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. – Mr President, I am very glad that the Commissioner addressed the values that the competition policy is based on: freedom and a level playing field for all. These are often forgotten. I also thank the rapporteur for an excellent report. As rapporteur for the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection (IMCO) opinion, I am happy that the important elements from my report are here: fair competition in the public procurement markets and access for SMEs, but also completion of the digital single market and guarantees of net neutrality are vital to boost competition and foster innovation. As a Liberal I am, however, disappointed that this report focuses too much on more regulation: more regulation, for instance, for the sharing economy, for the internet economy, which is actually one of the few sectors that still grew during the economic crisis. We seem to forget that we are representatives of millions of consumers but also of millions of business owners who rely on the EU competition policy to have the necessary confidence to start and run businesses. EU competition policy needs to contribute to building the right environment for innovative businesses to grow. What we need is a strong European competition authority which is proactive in adapting to the new, challenging and fast-moving markets of the digital economy. What we certainly do not need is to replace it with more regulation that will eventually only harm our most innovative businesses. I strongly hope that our Liberal Competition Commissioner shares these views and I hope that colleagues in this House do so also.

name: Werner Langen
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner, rapporteur, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her work on this report. In this report, we are dealing with 2013, that was Mr Almunia's time, and you, Mrs Vestager, are now facing the debate here for the first time. I think it is important to note that, according to all the treaties, the European Union is committed to an economic policy with an open market economy with free competition. We have to keep this in mind time when we are debating here. And the European Commission has extensive rights in merger control, in the prohibition of cartels, in illicit price fixing, in the control of state aid in order to enforce the four freedoms of the internal market for goods, goods, persons and capital and services. What is missing – and this was also our request in the hearing – is the democratic legitimacy of many foundations, guidelines and regulations. So far, this is not in the codecision procedure. And that is a problem with the power that the EU Commission has in these matters: individual fines of up to EUR 1 billion to Microsoft! Given the plethora of these competences, the guidelines must be democratically approved. That is one of the demands that we face. I believe that the European Commission has been too hesitant in the final years of Mr Almunia's term of office. Market shares have been defined in the telecommunications sector, but Google has been delayed for many years. Unfair tax competition has already been mentioned – also a difficult issue. Then there is the question of the extent to which national authorities are responsible for recovering state aid. I just want to mention the keyword Nürburgring, you know that. They trusted the data of the Member States concerned and not an independent review. I would therefore ask you to pay more attention to these aspects in your work in the future.

name: Tibor Szanyi
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Thank you very much for the opportunity, Madam President. I would like to thank the competition policy reporter, Mr Messerschmidt, and the shadow reporting colleagues for the progress we have made in our work together. We started from very distant points, but I believe that we have managed to reach a point of compromise in almost every respect. On behalf of the S&D group, I would also like to express my delight, for just a few examples, that the report in its present form is already emphatically about the importance of services of general economic interest and the benefits these services can bring to citizens.  I would particularly like to thank the IMCO Commission for its strong and very important contribution to strengthening the digital internal market, as we believe that this growth in Europe is one of the most important tools for job creation and innovation.  I would also like to thank you for the fact that, as a result of the amendments and compromises, the report has come much closer to the compatibility of competition expectations with social aspects. That is why I find it particularly sad that the Group of the European People's Party now wishes to weed out the social aspects from the report. All that today protects the social interests of workers and European citizens in general. This is completely unacceptable to us.  However, we continue to have problems with paragraph 85 of the report, which is not sufficiently elaborated and misinterpreted and misinterpreted. It implys, inter alia, the possibility and obligation to liberalise the rail transport sector. Our group cannot support this in any way. We will fight against this liberal initiative, and we will fight it in tomorrow's vote.  Finally, allow me to underline once again that our group does not consider it fortunate to mention a specific company in paragraph 45. Thank you very much!

name: Marek Józef Gróbarczyk
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab At the outset, I would like to congratulate Mr Messerschmidt very warmly on drawing up a very good report. Competitiveness is an essential part of Europe's economic development. This is essential in relation to energy prices affecting the economic development of the Union.  In this respect, we are extremely far from competition and, above all, from energy prices compared to the United States. Electricity in Europe is on average twice as expensive as in the US. By contrast, the price of gas increased 2.5-fold against the U.S. price. But there are countries in the European Union – even mine, Poland – where the price of gas is 5 times higher than the American price. This is the main brake on economic growth, exacerbating Europe's economic crisis.  The Union's approach to climate policy, which is treated as an ideology, leaves little room for competitiveness. Without a change in existing policy, it is erless to talk about the competitiveness of the European Union.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, competition is one of the fields where the Commission really has a chance to make a difference in the fight against oligopolistic practices. I welcome the work of the rapporteur, Mr Morten Messerschmidt, who did a great job in collecting a lot of good ideas to improve the report and negotiating with all the shadow rapporteurs to have this final and good report. In the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs this competition report got 51 votes in favour and only 2 against, so I hope that this huge vote will be confirmed tomorrow with a very broad majority and, as we did last year, that Parliament will send a very strong message to the Commission. Commissioner, if we want to avoid new regulation, the antitrust tool must act faster. Regarding the Google antitrust case, I welcome your meetings with all the complainants, including Google last week, to get a fresh look into the case. Nevertheless, time is not unlimited. I hope the Commission’s decisions will be announced soon, possibly today in this debate. In the Google antitrust case, a lot of people forget that among the dozens of complainants there are several US companies. Some of them, like here, have no problem going public. Others do not want to attack Google openly because they fear retaliation measures such as demotion or exclusion by Google. We met several US companies, victims of these practices, which explained how they simply disappeared from a Google search for several days, with a huge economic impact for them. I want to stress once again that this is not a European versus American company war. I am not ideological against Google or any other US company: I am simply against monopolies. Google has a 90% market share in some European countries and is de facto a gatekeeper of the Internet for European SMEs and European consumers. The preferential treatment of Google-owned services is not a fair practice. Google does not always have the best and the more pertinent choices for consumers. To conclude, I am convinced that Google only will move with the threat of a fine or with the threat of an amending regulation so, Ms Vestager, will you call for a statement of objections in the Google antitrust case? If you want to be credible in the digital agenda you need to solve the Google case. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Madam President, I would like to ask our colleague if he agrees with the inclusion in this report of the private attacks on Google?

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE)
text: blue-card answer. – It is not a question of attacks or taxation; I am not asking for taxes. We are just asking for a level playing field on the European market.  In America there are other companies like Yahoo which can compete on an equal footing with Google, but that is not the case in Europe where many European companies are suffering from the bad practices of Google. If we do nothing, Google will be the only enterprise in the market in the coming years. So it is not a question of taxation – if I have understood you correctly – it is a question of a level playing field, and the fact that this is not the case in Europe.  Another question: Microsoft. In 2004, in 2007 and in 2009 the Commission imposed some fines on Microsoft. Why has this not been the case in the last four years for Google?

name: Paloma López Bermejo
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, we value the positive points set out in this report. We believe that it points to very important criticisms and priorities when implementing and re-guiding competition policy: denouncing abuses against smallholder farmers, condemning banking aid and tax advantages to large companies, investigating social dumping in sectors such as transport, etc. However, we maintain reservations about aspects that have not been integrated into the report, such as the importance of considering the objective of a high level of employment, as the Treaties point out. Our abstention is because the report should go further and denounce that competition policy cannot be the battering ram with which public services are dismantled or industrial development in poorer regions is prevented. With its widening application of the principles of competition, the Commission contributes to the destruction of thousands of jobs, while ignoring the massive business concentration of which Europe is a victim and, especially, certain countries, such as Spain. We have tabled amendments in Parliament's plenary, among other issues, because we want to give Europeans the opportunity to know whether or not majority parties give priority to employment, public services, what the position is before investment arbitration courts or the theft of preferred ones. But our position is clear: competition policy must protect public services, SMEs and workers from abuses by large private groups.

name: Michel Reimon
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Commissioner, thank you for listening to us here. First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Messerschmidt, for his very fair work, and Also to thank the other shadow rapporteurs. Given the extent of the differences in content, these were very fair negotiations with a good result. I would like to single out three points of this, which are perhaps even more important for the future than for the past, when we drafted the report for 2013. The first is that we are in favour of investigating aggressive tax competition. It is a bizarre twist that we are discussing this report here on the day that the Luxleaks Committee meets for the first time at 9 p.m. I wonder whether such a special committee, rather than a committee of inquiry, as we actually wanted it – at least a quarter of the House has signed for it – which then starts at 9 p.m., really corresponds to the intention that we are adopting here when we demand an investigation into aggressive tax competition. I do not believe that this is enough. On the subject of net neutrality, this report says that it is of the utmost importance that there is no discrimination on the network and on data traffic. This is especially important for start-ups mentioned in connection with Google. If we create a network in which we can buy a lot of priority, it is particularly important for small European start-ups, and it is a particular burden. If your colleague, Commissioner, now refers to the defenders of net neutrality as the Taliban, it is a foretaste of the fact that, perhaps in the next few years, the Commission will not be moving in the direction of net neutrality. I would ask you to work in this direction. Perhaps you will still have the opportunity to give an opinion on this now. The third issue is energy. We are in favour of promoting renewable energies, of taking sustainability into account. How can this be reconciled with the approval of the support for the Hinkley Point nuclear power station, which is far above what renewable energy can receive in Europe? This is a massive distortion of competition, approved by your predecessor, Mr Almunia, who, in his last appearance before this House, told Parliament the untruth in this regard. Here, too, more decisive action must be taken. It is now a Russian decision. I hope, however, that you will engage politically in this direction.

name: Steven Woolfe
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, Europe is dying. Its people are struggling. All across this wonderful continent there are families who are finding it difficult to eat. One sees the unemployment, and one sees their children leaving, trying to find a life for themselves in a pressurised world. Competition is an essential part of small and medium-sized businesses for those people to try and find work, for them to be able to have enough money in their pockets to pay their gas and electricity bills and feed their families, and so it is always welcome when you see a report undertaken by an individual like Mr Messerschmidt who, I know, cares about issues such as this.  But unfortunately, in this Chamber, in this institution, such reports will always fall on deaf ears and have no capability to achieve the goals that people want, because at the end of the day this Chamber and the people working within it have rules that are effectively run by the corporations. They have the power and the influence to have preferential access to the Commissioners and the parliamentarians.  I have seen them swan across these buildings, both here and in Brussels, where they have access to MEPs and put their ideas forward. They can put rules and regulations in an unelected Chamber that bring in high barriers of entry for small and medium—sized businesses. It encourages corporatism, not capitalism; it encourages greed, not selflessness; it encourages the ability of people already earning millions in bonuses and large salaries to put the cost upon those who are struggling to make ends meet.  This is a dangerous place where competition fails at all points, and no report such as this will achieve the goal that we need, which is to relieve the people of the poverty they are suffering in Europe. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Mr. Woolfe, except that when you speak, and I agree with you, with people who are barely making ends meet, you don't keep your hands in your pocket and respect this home and those people, I want to ask you something else an after all. I want to ask you, as a free man, as an MP, that you can fall under any influence or do you still decide for yourself? This is where lobbyists come in, but I believe everyone here, we decide for ourselves. I hope you do the right, too.

name: Steven Woolfe (EFDD)
text: blue-card answer. – Sir, I am grateful that you have a free mind and I am grateful that I have a free mind, but what I have seen in this Chamber is large parties, such as the PPE and the Socialists, voting en bloc, sometimes together but always en bloc. Decisions are made by one’s party élite, and those party élites are governed by the corporates that are talking to them and their politicians back home. Freedom, yes, but not freedom within one’s party.

name: Barbara Kappel (NI).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, rapporteur, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her work on this report. Competitiveness is certainly the key driver of economic growth and employment in Europe. Both parameters, which are today the great challenges of this House and of the whole of Europe. Both parameters, which are not at their best in Europe at the moment. Europe is losing competitiveness in the global context. Let me give you a few examples. Europe now has twice as high an unemployment rate as the US. In the last five years, 6 million jobs have been lost in Europe, and only 1 million jobs in the UNITED States and Japan combined. As has already been said today, energy prices in Europe are twice as high for electricity, three to four times higher in the gas sector than in the USA, India or Russia. The average tax burden relative to GDP is 50% higher in Europe than in the US, 30% higher than in Japan. I am certainly not surprised if I tell you that there is also a huge deal of support in the area of research and development between Europe and the United States, namely USD 100 billion every year. Europe is lagging behind in direct investment, we have seen a huge decline over the last fifteen years, as well as access to finance and the efficiency of public administration. The rapporteur has therefore identified some very good points in his report, namely strategic priorities for this parliamentary term. These are: fair and clear competition rules, respect for subsidiarity and respect for national court decisions, the fight against cartels and monopolies, clear rules against market abuse, reform of state aid regulation and a coherent, pro-competitive tax policy. Stakeholders must be involved. In this way, we will be able to formulate a competition policy that strengthens entrepreneurship, inspires innovation and creates benefits for consumers.

name: Esther de Lange (PPE).
text: Mr President, the European Union's competition policy is not an end in itself, of course, but must contribute to a fair economy with equal opportunities for entrepreneurs and also protection of consumers and citizens. It is good that the European Commission is keeping its finger on the pulse, especially when you see that in economically difficult times Member States still tend to give state aid and to create barriers between Member States. And, in response to what Mr Woolfe said, I am pleased to have a European Commission that can monitor this.
