The first to suffer from the departure of a Member State from the European Union are small businesses, small and medium-sized enterprises, which no longer have access to fair rules in the large single European market. And then of course you have to keep up with the times, so also in the digital market you have to guarantee fair competition and tackle fragmentation. Enough has been said about it. At the moment, it seems that Member States are more important to the financial interests of a number of large companies than net neutrality and fair access for citizens and consumers to the Internet for all.  Another point of attention to be mentioned in this debate is the new economy of sharing that those who see it emerge. If I jump into an Uber taxi in one city, I'm completely fine, if I do that in another city I'm doing it illegally and in most cities in Europe I don't really know what grey area I'm in. I therefore think it is also important for the European Commission to look at this kind of new development critically and thoroughly, but to draw conclusions from it for new policies. In short, abuses that you have to address. There is nothing wrong with a bit of healthy competition, but the power of the market must always be at the service of society and I expect this Commission to watch over it.

name: Anneliese Dodds (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for being here this evening. It is often said that competition policy should lead to a level playing field for companies, regardless of their size and regardless of their country of origin, so I am pleased this report recognises that there can be no level playing field when some firms are able to evade or aggressively avoid paying their taxes.  The Lux Leaks scandal showed how some multinational firms were able to reduce the rates of tax they paid to almost nothing. These firms are not necessarily more efficient, but they were able to bring down their costs through purely artificial means. Competition here, I would suggest, is like a 100 metre race where one competitor has to wade through treacle while the other sits in a Formula One racing car. We have to take action against these impediments to competition. I am also very pleased that this report recognises where liberalisation and competition may not always be appropriate. Governments must be able to provide infrastructure that is essential for growth, whether that is in education or healthcare, or indeed in quality social housing where the market has failed to deliver. There is, after all, no point in having a level playing field if all the grass on it has been torn up. Finally, governments must have the freedom to act against the biggest civil challenge of our time: climate change. So I am pleased that this report will preserve governments’ ability to promote green energy projects because, frankly, there is no point in having a level playing field if the playing field is ten feet underwater. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Janice Atkinson (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – Mrs Dodds, why are you actually supporting Mr Juncker here, who wants a cohesive programme against tax evasion, under which he wants to unify everything? Also, what we are talking about here is the Transatlantic Trade Partnership. We are also talking about press freedom. The Guardian actually has off-shore trusts. Do you support that? Would you support The Guardian having a free press or falling under these proposals?

name: Anneliese Dodds (S&D)
text: blue-card answer. – It is good to see you in the Chamber, Janice, as someone else from the South East. I would say, first of all, that perhaps there is some confusion here. This report is produced by Parliament, it is not produced by the Commission, so this is Parliament’s voice on what we think about competition. I do not know about you, but certainly I visit the small and medium—sized enterprises in our constituency very regularly and they say to me frequently that they are concerned by the practices of those multinational firms which engage in profit—shifting and, indeed, firms which engage in shifting their profits to offshore tax havens, so I hope that your party might be changing its policy in that regard as well.

name: Morten Helveg Petersen (ALDE).
text: Madam President! I would like to start by congratulating the rapporteur on a very very exciting report. Competition policy is, after all, one of the eu's absolute core areas. It is at the heart of EU cooperation, it is at the heart of the new Commission, not least by the commissioner responsible in this area, Margrethe Vestager.  Competition policy, as I said earlier, is one of the many many areas in which EU cooperation brings positive and visible benefits for individual citizens, all of us. It is therefore also so positive that the rapporteur writes so clearly in the report here that the Commission must have more powers over the Member States, and it is positive that the rapporteur stresses that the Commission must have the financial resources to carry out these key and essential tasks. I am very pleased that the rapporteur emphasises the important role of the European Parliament and even that the European Parliament should be given even more powers. It is quite clear in the report in paragraph 104 that this democratic deficit cannot and must not be tolerated. I'd like to acknowledge that. So when the rapporteur argues that the Commission should have more powers over the Member States, that the Commission should have more resources and that the European Parliament should have more powers, Then I fully agree, because it all represents more Europe and not less europe. We must then bear in the fact that this is miles away from the rapporteur's previous positions on European cooperation. I certainly congratulate the rapporteur on this very positive report, which I look forward to voting for along with – I believe – the whole House. Congratulations on the report, Mr Rapporteur. It's great to see.

name: Marco Valli (EFDD).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, having heard what some of my fellow Members have said, I believe that very often this Parliament does good things and also writes good laws, but then the problem is that then those who really have executive power in this European Union, namely the Council and the Commission, who should issue good directives, very often do not listen to the guidelines that come from this Parliament. I therefore ask myself the questions: why, I wonder, are we with Claude Juncker, for example, as President of the Commission, the one who has made fiscal dumping his country's fortune for more than fifteen years, who could do good things tomorrow, because he knows exactly what tax avoidance is, and instead we are creating a committee that should advise those who know all the elusive practices? The fundamental point is this: Parliament may be working well, but unfortunately the Commission and the Council, which are at the mercy of lobbies, as my colleague Mr Woolfe said, very often do not in the interests of the citizens but in the interests of big business. , with unfair competition, in which multinationals establish tax headquarters in all countries of their convenience. Something must therefore be done to stop this trend, otherwise we will have to return to protectionism!

name: Markus Ferber (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Competition is one of the core elements of our economic form. That is why it is right that, since the Treaty of Rome, we have a competition authority at European level to ensure that competition in the European Union can also take place fairly. That is the honourable task that you, Mrs Vestager, have now taken on. I wish you a happy hand when it comes to developing rules of the game and ensuring that these rules are respected by all market participants. That is what we can expect from competition policy. We have very big challenges, for example in the area of tax law. We have set up a special committee and we are, of course, pleased that the Commission has also opened investigations against a number of Member States. Faced with a change in the digital age with completely new challenges, because it is no longer easy to assign where value creation takes place, which rules of the game must be adhered to. You have a very great responsibility here. I want to mention not only the example of Google, but the overall challenge of digital work. And, of course, we must also ensure that we in Europe do not weaken ourselves with a misunderstood competition law. I sometimes wonder whether it is wise, in many places, to weaken companies that are engaged by means of competition rules, so that they can no longer compete in international competition. I could give you examples from aviation, telecommunications and other areas. These are all issues that we have to deal with during this parliamentary term. Our report tackles these problems. I therefore hope that the Commission will take up the many points that we will be adopting here tomorrow.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, competition policy and competitiveness, as you have pointed out, are fundamental values for the success and functioning of the European Union as a whole; they have always been an essential instrument for removing obstacles to the free movement of goods, services, persons and capital and for promoting the completion of the single market and the protection of European consumers. Unfortunately, we have to note that in many areas there are still inexplicable technical and regulatory barriers, which in fact prevent the proper functioning of a dynamic, efficient and innovative internal market capable of stimulating economic growth and the creation of new jobs.  I would particularly like to stress, however, the important role played by the European Parliament in recent years in this area, and I believe that the competition plans must in future be drawn up and adopted in close cooperation with Parliament, through its formal involvement, and I am referring to a possible extension of the codecision procedure, with a view to strengthening its democratic legitimacy. I believe that the democratic deficit is unacceptable in this area and I propose that it be overcome as soon as possible by means of interinstitutional agreements on competition policy. There is no competition unless transparency is guaranteed, and that is why Parliament must be kept informed of the progress of investigations into the practices of the Member States' tax arrangements that the Commission promotes.

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I fully support the proposals in the report, which call on the European Commission to consider possible infringements of competition and state aid rules in those situations where letters of tax comfort have been granted to certain transnational companies in some Member States. I know that the European Commission has already addressed this subject and we look forward to the conclusions. At the same time, I raise to the European Commission the issue of large price differences in the same types of medicines between the Member States of the European Union. Such large price differences can hide abusive practices by both manufacturers and distributors of medicinal products. Certainly, such large price differences show a fragmented market for medicines. That is why I believe that an analysis by the European Commission on the problem of the medicines market in Europe is necessary in order to be able to identify possible market dominant positions so that we can prevent these abuses and exaggerated rents.

name: Jeppe Kofod (S&D).
text: Madam President! Commissioner! Free and fair competition is essential for us as consumers to get the best products at the cheapest price. This is particularly true when it comes to the mobile and telecommunications markets. Let me therefore start by thanking you for your clear statement in an article in the Financial Times on the wave of telecompanies facing Europe. In fact, the Commission states here that low prices for consumers are essential when it comes to assessing whether mergers are acceptable to the Commission. In Denmark, two telecommunications companies have joined forces in matrimonies, and I know that their application is currently on the Commissioner's desk. I would therefore like to ask the Commissioner how much market share the Commission thinks two companies can have before a duopoly-like state occurs? And how will the Commissioner ensure that allowing the two companies to merge does not lead to worse competition and higher prices for the consumer?  To the rapporteur for the report, I would like to thank the rapporteur for an intriguing report, Morten Messerschmidt, and I, like others, am surprised by the very pro-EU tone of the report, including the fact that the rapporteur wants more power for the European Parliament. A European Parliament such as the rapporteur, Morten Messerschmidt, has argued strongly in the past against the abolition! How this is related can of course be speculated, but I thank you for the good report by Morten Messerschmidt.

name: Γεώργιος Κύρτσος (
text: PPE). Madam President, I think we all know that there is no perfect market and that there must be interventions to reduce malfunctions. I believe that both Mr Messerschmidt's report and the Commissioner are moving in the right direction. I would like to point out as a Greek MEP that the structure of the internal market plays a huge role in the final economic outcome. But, of course, not everything is the responsibility of the European Union, governments and societies themselves must be interested.  I believe that, according to the experts' estimates, one of the reasons Greece failed to get out of the adjustment programme so well, so quickly and with the same success as Ireland and Portugal, which had their own programmes, was the problems in the structure of the internal market. In other words, many sacrifices were made, wages fell, but inflation remained at a level of 2.5% for 2010-2014, despite the fact that nominal labour costs fell by around 12% and Gross Domestic Product fell by 20%.  It is therefore of enormous importance how each economy works, how we limit its dysfunctions. So the question is whether, from the right political initiatives we take, we will be able to become concrete. For example: why is Russian natural gas imported into Greece one of the most expensive in the European Union? Why is the reduction in energy costs not shown in the public electricity company's tariffs? If we can solve these specific issues, I think we'll do much better.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I am very pleased with the outcome of the negotiations on this report. I would like to underline the remarkable result of defending public services from being subject to a policy of competition. The possibility for the Member States to organise public services according to their own needs is a crucial point for our Socialist and Democratic Group within this Parliament.  In the amendments, I proposed and defended a stronger role for Parliament in shaping our competition policy, with the goal of increasing the level of market transparency, stability and growth. By means of this report we are closer to achieving fundamental goals like ensuring fair competition and combating social dumping on the labour market, subjecting services of general economic interest to the rules of competition, tackling fragmentation and anti-trust behaviour in the EUʼs digital market, ending state-aid regimes to banks, and ending tax evasion and illegal corporate tax practices. Although I do not agree with the inclusion of the private attacks on Google, since the idea of the report was to put forward general rules, I support the adoption of this report in the plenary session.
