name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Competition policy is undoubtedly one of the cornerstones of the single market in the European Union. In the absence of activity at Community level, we would constantly face restrictive measures and even trade wars between Member States. Not only consumers, but also the European economy as a whole would be affected, and the new Commission's statement on this area is to be welcomed. We must bear in mind that companies will use all available means to strengthen their position on the market. However, the past year has highlighted the problem of tax havens, including in particular the financial policies of some Member States. The LuxLeaks scandal has shown that some governments are individualising tax law in order to attract investors, thereby avoiding taxation. When you look at the list of companies that have taken advantage of the opportunities offered by Luxembourg, you can see that they were companies with hundreds of millions of euros in profit. The offer created by that State therefore amounted to a real tax loss for a number of Member States.  I agree with the rapporteur that transparency of tax law is an important element of competitiveness and that the European Commission should be equipped with instruments to identify unfair practices.  I also wanted to draw attention to the mechanism that distorts competition in the single market, which I missed in this report. In recent days, information has emerged about the huge price different prices of Russian gas for individual Member States. We need to realise that fair competition between companies is not possible if some pay $308 per 1000 cubic metres of gas and others 26% more. It should be borne in mind that this price is not based on any objective reasons, but is merely a derivative of the Kremlin's political will. I am therefore surprised by me talking about so-called social dumping that they did not raise the issue of energy dumping during the recent debate on the Energy Union.

name: Bernard Monot (NI).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, if we judge a policy by its results, the least that can be said is that the European competition policy has failed. First of all, because some monopolies have disappeared in order to better sell public services to private interests. Collectivisation of burdens, privatisation of profits, this is what is still likely to happen with the Juncker plan, combined with your new guidelines, particularly in the fields of energy and transport.  The European banking sector, which has benefited from almost EUR 2 trillion in five years, continues to fail to finance the real economy. In the field of new technologies, European justice is bogged down without any effective sanctions being taken, as is the case with Google. SMEs are still the big forgotten, deprived of access to the most important public markets and put under pressure by large groups as well as in the mass market.  Last but not, because of the Commission's control over public aid, it is not possible for a sovereign state to pursue a policy of economic patriotism by supporting its strategic industries. I will simply cite, in France, the example of SNCM, which was ordered last year to repay 400 million euros - at the behest of Brussels - and which had to file for bankruptcy.  You have a dogma, that the free play of the market free from barriers to competition is a guarantee of prosperity and efficiency. The reality is that it only results in the same capture of wealth by a few at the expense of the general interest of the peoples.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE).
text: – We all know that competition policy is essential in economic recovery, especially today, when we also have a number of trade agreements with other countries ahead, and let me, of course, point out in particular the most important one: the trade agreement between the European Union and the United States. We will be able to make competition policy – this policy will best protect our consumers, thus also enabling a fair environment for all small businesses, which, as we always say, are the driver of the European economy. I am pleased that the Commission regularly monitors developments in the area of this policy and that this policy is not an end in itself, but also reports with concrete results and consequences.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, first of all I want to thank the rapporteurs and appreciate that this is a balanced report. The issue I want to raise for the Commissioner is this: of course we need competition policies, but we need fair competition in the market. My question is, Commissioner, whether in two directions you have thought of anything for the period ahead. One direction is that of real policies that practically make efficiency in terms of how SMEs are treated in the global market. And, as a former entrepreneur, I was able to see that, in fact, there is in fact no equal competition between big companies and SMEs in the European Union. Secondly, if you have thought of regulating something also in terms of entering the European Union market from non-European countries, because we are dealing with great competition and unfair competition with unsupervised products. If these two things could be resolved, I think we can rejoice and say that we have policies with practical effects in the future.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: – I would like to commend Mr Messersmith for the tremendous work he has done. The report is extremely accurate and objective. The positive thing is that Mr Messersmith pays great attention to protecting small and medium-sized enterprises from the competition of large companies and cartels. However, these small and medium-sized enterprises employ more than 65 % of all employees in the European Union, as well as over 55 % of the gross Community value added. It is rightly noted that in most cases small and medium-sized enterprises are unequal to large consortia. Of course, some omissions and inaccuracies can be admitted in such work, but they are not essential. The Commission needs to address the issues of different levels of interest on loans, not only for companies but also for individuals. In Bulgaria, interest and servicing costs of loans can reach up to 50%, while in countries such as Germany they are no more than 15%.  As regards social dumping and cabotage, I believe that these issues will be resolved when Europe ceases to move at two speeds and the division of small and large is eliminated. And once again, I congratulate Mr. Messersmith on the work done.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, freedom of competition and fair competition are really the foundations of our politics and our economy.  However, this report shows, after all, that the more Europe in those areas we need – the better for us, because we have problems with competition. First of all, I am talking about the single energy market and the digital single market.  One of those absurdities that my esteemed colleague in our group talked about is the issue of Google and its market position, and it's really something amazing. We are entering the Digital Single Market, entering the digital age, which for me should become one of the fifth freedoms, digital freedom in Europe – we enter objectively with a monopoly.  And we really need to take concrete measures here, because that definitely won't be good for our market in the long run.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, it is appropriate to remember here that it was in the name of the sacrosanct principle of free competition that justified the liberalisation and privatisation of strategic sectors of the economy and the advancement of the market on growing spheres of social life. Everyone would win, we were told. It's seeing the results.  In the electricity sector, the liberalisation and the end of vertical integration of production and distribution in public companies has brought increases in energy bills for companies and households, to the extent that the profits of monopolies – previously public, today private – have also increased, holders of these companies. In transport, liberalisation has been causing monopolistic concentration on a European scale in less than half a dozen large multinational companies, which dominate both passenger transport and cargo. They're just two examples. This is not, nor could it be, in this report.  At the same time, serious sprains of competition, for example in the field of agriculture, are still still being tackled, especially as a result of the current common agricultural policy, in which national production is destroyed. In essence, creating difficulties for the intervention of states and benefiting large transnational groups are the objectives and practical results of this competition policy.

name: Margrethe Vestager
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first of all thank you for the debates. I think it has shown the depth and the commitment of Parliament when it comes to our competition policy and the rules in the Treaty. And we do have rules in the Treaty. I very much appreciate the point made by Mr Werner Langen that according to the Treaty there is no co—legislation with this Parliament. I am firm though in my commitment that as long as we have that Treaty we will work by its rules but I will also work as much as possible with Parliament taking things forward both in cases that were closed in the debate about competition policy and, of course, in cases where we may move forward on some of the proposals that are being debated right now. Second, as was said by Mr Morten Petersen, this is a crucial competence for the European Union. Yet again it also highlights the fact that we need to cooperate very closely with national authorities because in that interrelationship we can solve things that can otherwise not be solved. For instance, regarding foods, where national authorities play a crucial role but may not have any reasonable tools when it comes to large corporations. And that, of course, is one of the things that has been mentioned in the debate over and over again tonight: whether or not competition policy is strong enough to enable small and medium-sized companies actually to make their case, to use their talent, to use their competences to be in the market. I think that is a very good point because it sort of highlights the goals of competition policy, not just to enforce because of enforcement but to enforce in order to enable people to make their choices and for their businesses to thrive. On the question of the differences in drug prices: we made a sector enquiry, or the previous Commission did, regarding the rules in that sector and how things were handled when it came to patent. Some of the price differences actually may be ascribed to the differences among Member States in how drugs are subsidised. Of course, we will be happy to follow up on that as we do with our sector enquiry in patents – we do follow-up reports every year. Tax has been another issue which has been at the centre of our debate tonight. I will of course do my best to use the competition tools to get into the cases where we see fiscal aid and where tax rulings are being used to enable unfair competition because we think that is against the basis of our competition values. When it comes to energy a number of commitments have been made which has made, I think, the desirable effort to open up our markets. Last but not least, also in this area, we have imbalances between the competences of the Member State and the competences of our common Union. For instance, when it comes to the energy mix, we may have differences in how we view nuclear power for instance. But it is within the scope of the Member State to decide their energy mix. What we are doing when it comes to state aid is of course to make sure that there is no overcompensation and that taxpayers’ money is not overspent. And as the last and most important thing, and I hope it will be appreciated in a Parliament working so hard on transparency, that with state aid modernisation we get a much larger degree of transparency with regard to how taxpayers’ money is used so that not only the media but also the citizen can follow their money in order to make their politicians accountable. I think we will come back to the digital market also of course when we start to debate the digital single market and the proposal that the Commission will put forward relatively soon. Thank you very much for this debate. I think it is a very good platform for our future cooperation.

name: Morten Messerschmidt
text: Rapporteur. Madam President! Not least, thank you for the many comments made during the debate, most politically, a few polemics, which I naturally appreciate. Let me just respond to the controversy first. One thing is that we have not been part of the negotiations and therefore do not know the content of the reports that have been produced. That's fair enough! I am talking here to my two Danish colleagues, but at least one might have taken the trouble to find out who is tabling which amendments. Well, that's the way it is! At least one of the two gentlemen would like to welcome the fact that I can reason as an answer, and then perhaps even I am a little annoyed that I do not have the opportunity to return the kindness, the controversy that the two gentlemen have given me this evening, because neither of them has ever committed themselves to writing a report. I certainly haven't seen any work going on like this.  Well, let me say something about the political content here, because I think most of the comments have been friendly, welcoming and in the spirit in which the negotiations here have taken place. And I welcome that, and I welcome the content of the report on which we have agreed, which raises a large number of important points that are critical but also constructive. For example, I have no recollection of the fact that any report from this House has said in such detail what it takes to build a digital single market. What we need in relation to privacy rules, e-payments, interoperability, etc. This is something that points forward, hopefully with a perspective on growth, but it is above all something that points to you, Commissioner. We expect an initiative in this area and in all the other areas that this report seeks to raise. It's about trust, and it's about "commitment" (for which I don't remember the Danish word). In this spirit, I am sure that tomorrow we will be able to conclude this work in a good and constructive way. Not so - and I say this to Tibor Szanyi - that we all necessarily love the compromise that exists, but so that we can all at least live with it and in this way work with the Commissioner, civil society and everyone else.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 10.  March, held. Written declarations (Article 162 OF the CRP)

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. – The European Union probably has one last chance to demonstrate to the citizens of the Member States that it is capable of taking effective action to combat the economic and financial crisis and to increase its importance worldwide. I therefore welcome the commitments made by the Commissioner regarding the relationship with the European Parliament, the fight against cartels, the investigation of companies in a dominant position, so that they do not use their market power disproportionately, but also open and transparent proceedings with external stakeholders. The new European Commission must find the right answers in the fight against high unemployment, low growth, while at the same time finding a way to increase investment and increase competitiveness. The European Union must make full use of the competitive advantages in the area of production, such as highly qualified workers, a high share of domestic production in exports and high quality products. I therefore think it is right that we want to follow the path of constant investment in the competitiveness of European industry, because only the necessary investments can ensure its high level. We must try to remove the uncertainty that European companies are in contact with the public administration in order to improve their growth prospects. We must remove all barriers that have a negative impact on competitiveness, which undoubtedly include high electricity and gas prices, which we have higher in the European Union than in other advanced economies.

name: Alfred Sant (S&D)
text: in writing. – State aid rules under the EU’s competition policies are being taken to extremes in the case of transport systems available to communities living in peripheral islands. Insisting that such connections should survive on the basis of supply and demand in compliance with state aid rules undermines the welfare of communities. Relevant transport services to such communities, even when subsidised appropriately, have no impact on the competitive environment of the EU as a whole. The demise of Cyprus Airways recently is a case in point. One asks what socio-economic benefits resulted from it at European or island level. The same applies to the case of Air Malta and to the sea connections between Malta and the island of Gozo. Air Malta needed and still needs to implement reforms. But making these fit the strait jacket of EU competition policy is distorting and sometimes blocking the path to recovery. Yet, the volume of Air Malta’s business is in no way significant compared to EU air traffic in the Mediterranean. Gozo suffers from a double insularity, with huge diseconomies of scale when maintaining its communications infrastructure. Subjecting sea transport between Malta and Gozo to overall competition rules amounts to nonsense.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: in writing. – The single market cannot function without a sound competition policy and effective enforcement of their rules. I consider the protection of consumer interests, the principle of non-discrimination and equal access to goods and services to be fundamental principles from the point of view of consumers. It is not possible for consumers not to have access to the most advantageous offers or even a particular type of goods when purchasing goods or services within the single market. In my view, such practices are incompatible with the proper functioning of the internal market, distort competition and harm consumers and honest traders. I am therefore glad that the report calls on the Commission to continue to focus on the practices of international car rental companies, which set different prices and contractual terms for consumers on the basis of their residence or place of residence. I firmly believe that the Commission will also take into account the principle of non-discrimination in the forthcoming digital market strategy.

name: Renato Soru (S&D)
text: in writing. I believe that, in order for a union to be defined as such, we need rules that place all members on the same level, especially in a sensitive area such as competition. It is now more necessary than ever to prevent distortions within the common market, both for the historic moment when we are faced with a crisis from which we can emerge only through common policies, and on the basis of the principles of the Union, whose economic dimension is defined in the Treaties as an 'open market economy with free competition'. We must not forget that public confidence in the European Union itself has also been greatly reduced due to market constraints, both common and in individual Member States.  For these reasons, and taking into account the ideas concerning the centrality of the digital single market, which is now also a fundamental issue in the field of work and, above all, competition, I believe that this report can be a good starting point, in order to guarantee a thriving economy, in which the rules of competition apply to everyone and serve to improve the lives of citizens.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Competition policy is crucial for the EU as a whole and, consequently, for all its citizens. It has brought numerous benefits in terms of consumer welfare and is an essential tool for removing obstacles to the free movement of goods, services, persons and capital. Competition policy plays a strategic role in strengthening a holistic approach to the single market to address europe's current economic, social and environmental challenges. Competition policy instruments should be used in such a way as to contribute to economic growth and job creation. Of particular importance is the effective control of the conduct of dominant companies and the rapid response to infringements. The rules on antitrust, State aid and merger control should therefore be strengthened with a view to achieving a well-functioning internal market and social progress. Bearing in mind that efforts to promote a competitive EU must always be carried out in the public interest. Through an effective competition policy, we can strengthen and enhance the EU's international relevance. However, it should not be forgotten that, in an age of globalisation, international cooperation and the promotion of an innovative culture of competition on a global scale are essential for the effective application of the principles of competition law.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the oral question to the Commission on criteria for recording endocrine disruptors by Nicola Caputo, Pavel Poc, Jo Leinen, Michele Rivasi, Bart Staes, Soledad Cabezan Ruiz, Renata Briano, Elena Gentile, Pina Picierno, Renato Soru, Giulia Moi, Dario Tamburrano, Eleonora Evi, Marco Affronte, Rosa D'Amato, Barbara Kappel, Eric Andrieu, Nicolas Bay, Maite Pagazaurtunda Ruiz, Fabio Massimo Castaldo, Laura Agea, Laura Ferrara, Isabella Adinolf, Tiziana Beghin, Marco Zullo, Marco Valli, Ignazio Corrao, Fredrick Federley, Jana 'it'ansk', Jean-Luc Schaffhauser, Patricija 'ulin, Daciana Octavia Sérbu, Tibor Szanyi, Ricardo Ser Santos, Christel Schaldemose, Marc Tarabella, Maria Arena, Nessa Childers, Biljana Borzan, José Blanco Lopez, Iratxe Garcia Pérez, Matt Carthy, Kostas Chrysogonos, Lynn Boylan, Anja Hazekamp , Paloma Lopez Bermejo, Enrico Gasbarra, Alessia Maria Mosca, Mercedes Bresso, Anneli Jäätteenmäki, Martin Häusling, Karin Kadenbach, Sylvie Goddyn, Mireille D'Ornano, Ivan Jakovic, Pascal Durand, Diane James, Molly Scott Cato, Margrete Auken, Rolandas Paksas, Valentinas Mazuronis, Benedek J'vor, Yannick Jadot, Claudiu Ciprian T'n'sescu (O-000017/2015 - B8-0107/2015) (2015/2605(RSP)).

name: Nicola Caputo
text: Author. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the oral question tabled with the support and consent of many of my fellow Members, whom I thank, is inspired by the article on endocrine disruptors published by the British newspaper The Guardian on 2 February. The article denounces the European Commission's cover-up of the proposal that DG Environment had prepared in 2013 and which would have led to the development of criteria for classifying a substance as endocrine disruptor, thus initiating a new strategy in this area. With this proposal, DG Environment, in accordance with Article 5 of the Eu ropean Union Regulation on the placing on the market and use of biocidal products, bound the Commission to define the criteria for the identification of substances with endocrine disrupting properties by 13 December 2013. However, as a result of external pressure but also from other Directorates-General of the Commission, dg Environment's proposal appears to have been blocked and replaced by an impact assessment, which unfortunately will not be finalised before 2016, which therefore appears instrumentally aimed at circumventing the obligation to submit the criteria. In addition, there are further critical issues regarding the roadmap prepared for the impact assessment. In it, the Commission has included an option concerning the introduction of socio-economic derogations for the placing on the market of substances containing endocrine disruptors, thus leaving open ground, for example, to the use of pesticides.  In view of the fact that in its report of January 2013 Parliament strongly argued that the authorisation of substances containing endocrine disruptors should be restricted, I would ask the Commission why and who authorised the derogations for the placing on the market of these substances. The Guardian article argued that as many as thirty-one pesticides could be banned, causing obvious and significant negative economic spillovers to the industry. It is easy to see how the development of criteria for defining endocrine disruptors would have had economic consequences not only on the pesticide sector but on a very wide range of other products with which we impact in our daily lives and which contain endocrine disruptors: packaging, skincare products, cosmetics, building materials, electronic equipment, furniture and floors. What are the costs of not drawing up criteria for the health of European citizens? They seem to be very high. In fact, it has been shown that in the last twenty years the increase in cancer, infertility, early puberty, cardiovascular diseases and fetal and genital abnormalities may be associated in some way with exposure to chemicals that act as endocrine disruptors. Costs in terms of health costs and lower productivity at Community level are also affected by the failure to develop the criteria. According to a recent study, they amount to one hundred and fifty-seven billion euros. It goes without saying that the presentation of the criteria could therefore bring important benefits both for the health of citizens and for the European health system. How, then, does the Commission intend to take account of the potential benefits that the introduction of the criteria could have in its impact assessment? Furthermore, does the Commission intend to carry out further studies on the benefits of introducing these criteria? In view of the fact that the criteria will not be drawn up quickly, I would like to know whether the Commission intends at least to raise public awareness of endocrine disruptors, for example by making recommendations to citizens to reduce exposure to them. Indeed, I believe that, while waiting for the criteria to be drawn up, guidelines should be developed at European level as soon as possible to deal with this silent pollution, which is too little considered by public opinion and citizens, who do not currently have sufficient information to protect their health. I myself, moreover, expressed these demands for clarity, awareness and protection in my question in October 2014, in which I expressed my deep concern at the presence of endocrine disrupting phthalates linked to alarming health problems, including in toys and children's articles, in order to improve their flexibility, modelability and durability. They also have very extensive applications and are present in cosmetics as fixers, in the health and pharmaceutical industries and in numerous other industrial applications. Finally, recent research on bisphenol A has shown the need for greater coordination in programmes dedicated to endocrine disruptors. Indeed, I find it difficult to understand how it is possible that the national agency French for food safety presented alarming studies on this substance between 2013 and 2014, and European experts have recently established that exposure to bisphenol A does not present any risk to people. Therefore, for all of the above, does the Commission not consider it necessary to set up a research centre on endocrine disruptors in order to carry out research into these substances and to coordinate knowledge on the subject at Eu ropean Union level, as Parliament proposed in its 2013 resolution?

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, honourable Members, I am pleased to attend this plenary session today to discuss with you the issue of endocrine disruptors. I would like to start by quoting Article 168 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU. ‘A high level of human health protection shall be ensured in the definition and implementation of all Union policies and activities.’ This is a fundamental rule applicable to all our policies. The issue of endocrine disruptors reaches to the core of this principle. Therefore, I would like to assure you that, as Commissioner for Health and Food Safety and all the more as a medical doctor, I will only make decisions which respect this very principle; there can be no compromises on health. Now let us turn to your question. Endocrine disruptors are a highly complex issue. The decision that we take will have a significant impact on health, the environment, agriculture, trade and on a wide range of other sectors. Therefore, this is a priority file for me and my services. I would like to start by clarifying the current situation and its genesis as regards endocrine disruptors, rather than commenting on an article in The Guardian which refers to some so-called EU paper, on which I cannot respond. To date, the Commission has not adopted or published any official Commission document on the issue of defining endocrine-disrupting chemicals. I would like to present the work that I have been doing since the beginning of my mandate, which started four months ago, as well as explain my intentions for the future. Back in June 2014, the Commission defined a road map for the development of the criteria for endocrine disruptors. The road map, which I need to respect and follow, describes the legislative background and policy options that will be evaluated for the endocrine disruptors in the disruptors criteria. The road map also makes provision for an impact assessment. The work for it started already in 2013 under the joint responsibility of DG Environment and DG SANCO. As of November 2014, it was placed under my full responsibility. Let me briefly explain the reasons for carrying out an impact assessment. Many countries have raised concerns regarding endocrine disruptors but in terms of transposition of the concerns into legislation we, the European Union, are pioneers and world leaders. The EU co-legislators have already set interim criteria which ensure protection of human health and the environment until a permanent decision is taken. The precautionary principle of this approach, which they followed, is one I support. Our future decision will set an example, and therefore it must be made in full knowledge of the facts. Yet endocrine disruption is quite a recent way of looking at the toxicity of chemicals. We see divergent views amongst scientists and regulators worldwide. There are studies being published every day. Just last week new scientific information on the potential high cost to human health and society caused by hormone-disrupting chemicals was published in the press. We monitor these developments and take them into consideration. The new criteria will also affect several other pieces of EU legislation and different kinds of regulatory actions will be triggered. All these reasons objectively justify the need for the impact assessment. I would also recall that the seventh environmental action plan adopted by the European Parliament in 2013 asks the Union to develop harmonised results-based criteria for the identification of endocrine disruptors, which means criteria applicable to all chemical legislation. This is yet another reason for us to undertake an impact assessment in such a sensitive and complex situation. The assessment, which will evaluate different scenarios to define the endocrine disruptors, is already on trial. The first phase of external studies was launched in November 2014. The Joint Research Centre Institute for Health and Consumer Protection is developing a methodology for the criteria to identify the endocrine disruptors. The second phase of the study has already started and will be done by an external contractor. I understand that it will take some time until we complete all the actions set in the road map, but we need to make informed decisions and make them in full transparency. We have organised a public consultation and received 27 000 contributions. They are public and already available via a website. My services are working hard summarising their input. Speaking about transparency, a website dedicated to the issue of endocrine disruptors will be made available very shortly. Additionally, I will be holding a round-table public conference very soon to discuss the outcome of the public consultation. In preparation for this conference we will also hold preparatory meetings with the main stakeholders, Members of the European Parliament and NGOs. If need be, I will organise more than one public meeting on the issue. I am committed to do my job seriously and in full transparency. In parallel, since the beginning of my mandate, I have discussed the issue of endocrine disruptors with a number of Members of the European Parliament and a wide range of stakeholders. I have encouraged European ministers to formulate their approach to the question of endocrine disruptors. Just last week I met the French Minister and discussed the issues with her. It is a complex, difficult file and the Members’ questions show their concern. I invite Members to cooperate with me, to exchange views with me and my services, and to participate in the debate and future events that I mentioned earlier. Meanwhile I am active on this issue. I will do my job in full transparency and will make no compromise on health.

name: Jens Gieseke
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner Andriukaitis, ladies and gentlemen. Friday 13 December 2013 was not a good day for Europe. That was the day by which the Commission should have developed criteria for endocrine disruptors. This mandate has been given to the Commission by Parliament. However, a glance at the calendar shows that this deadline has simply not been met. It is precisely from the point of view of the citizens, who have to comply precisely with deadlines with regard to the administration, that such a delay is unacceptable. I would like to make it quite clear at this point that there is a clear potential for improvement in the Commission's compliance with deadlines. For far too long, different directions have been worked within the Commission. Valuable time was wasted. The action now being brought against the Commission will certainly be successful on this issue. However, as legislators, we should not be right. We are called upon to make sensible and balanced legislative proposals. However, the differences of opinion within the Commission services and also in the scientific community show how controversial the issue of endocrine disruptors is. As you have just mentioned, Commissioner, there are no simple solutions, and that is why we need a comprehensive impact assessment. The Commission's decision to carry out such an impact assessment should certainly have been taken sooner, that is clear. Our hormonal system is extremely complex and neither the Commission nor science nor industry has a simple solution. If we as a Parliament want to be taken seriously, we must support the Commission in drawing up the impact assessment. We need the impact assessment for good legislation. We should not now make the mistake of having ideological debates and outdoing ourselves with blanket recriminations to the Commission, science or industry. The Commission is on the right track, albeit with considerable delay. Let us continue along this path together. Then we will be able to pass laws that actually deserve the predicate of better regulation.

name: Gilles Pargneaux
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D. - Madam President, Commissioner, I believe we are dealing with one of the biggest health and economic scandals. I have heard your proposal for evaluation, then transparency and public debate. I take note of that. I know you, Commissioner. I know your drive, your probity and your will to succeed. At the same time, it is clear that in 2009, right here, one of your predecessors made the same proposal for evaluation, transparency and public debate. Then, finally, nothing! Nothing more except to see a real sea snake concerning this issue which is not only - as I said - a health scandal but also an economic scandal. It is worth remembering, as the author of the oral question, Mr Caputo, said: decline in male fertility, early puberty, obesity, diabetes, birth defects, breast cancer, it is more than 157 billion euros, or about 1.23% of the gross domestic product of the European Union, that are involved with these endocrine disruptors. Until recently, observers and scientists indicated that 31 pesticides should have been banned in the European Union. A few days ago, in France, it was said that apple cultivation, which is intensive in a number of European countries, would have serious health consequences, including for our children, who eat these apples in our school canteens, all over Europe. Therefore, I have confidence, Commissioner, and at the same time you can have my support. But it will have to, I say, to restore confidence ... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Julie Girling
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, I did not sign this oral question. I thought about it very carefully, and one of the reasons is that it presupposes that the criteria for classification of substances as endocrine disruptors is a simple scientific decision that everyone in the scientific community can agree with. Well it is not. The author of the question attested just tonight that if the criteria for EDCs had been published, the entire issue of endocrine disrupters would have been solved, and this is clearly not the case. It is simply not the case. I have just come from the meeting of the Committee on the Environment where Mr Timmermans has been extolling the virtues of impact assessments, with seemingly the majority of Members agreeing with him, so I can assume that the signatories are not against impact assessments per se. I can only conclude that it is part of the ongoing campaign to oversimplify this issue by ignoring the safeguards that are already in place, not least through legislation such as REACH.  So what is this all about? The wording asserting that 31 substances would be banned if a blocked EU paper on hormone—mimicking chemicals had been acted upon comes straight from a document produced by the NGO Pesticide Action Network. This pan—analysis has been challenged by many scientists. This will always be the case. Sometimes scientific consensus emerges, but very rarely complete agreement. This is an ongoing discussion in the scientific community, which is divided on how best to identify and regulate endocrine—disrupters.  The World Health Organization has acknowledged that existing data are not able to demonstrate a causal link between exposure to EDs and adverse health effects. They quite clearly say that. The issue is further complicated by the different regulatory processes that exist in different pieces of sectoral legislation – a hazard—based approach in plant protection products and a risk—based approach in biocides – so we cannot even get that right.  I think the Commission is taking a sensible approach to this very difficult issue. I have been contacted by constituents in my region expressing concern about the potential socio—economic effects, and I do not think that those should be ignored. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Margrete Auken (Verts/ALE)
text: Blue card question. Madam President! I would just like to ask Julie Girling whether she is not aware that the study launched by Catherine Day was solely about what the industry came to pay, and now we have similar figures – most recently today from Le Monde – which say that we have 1.27% of EU GDP, which is caused by damage from endocrine disruptors. However, it is quite bold to say that you have adversive when what you have – the conflict – is the interests of industry in the face of human health. The economy is much harder for society when it is human health than when it is the suffering of industry.

name: Julie Girling (ECR)
text: blue-card answer. – Madam President, unlike Mrs Auken, I think industry is part of the European economy and part of our European society. Industry has its views, I have my views and she has her views. They will not always be the same and clearly sometimes they conflict. Many studies are available on endocrine disrupters. They have been funded in many different ways and they all come up with the same conclusion, bar one or two minor studies – namely that there is no causal link. That does not mean to say that I do not acknowledge that there may be an issue, but there is – according to the WHO – currently no causal link.

name: Lynn Boylan
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, according to leaks within the European Commission, we have heard that an EU paper on endocrine disruptors was due to propose criteria for categorisations of endocrine—disrupting chemicals which would have led to an EU ban on a range of hazardous substances but, once again, amidst heavy lobbying from the major chemical industry, which stands to lose big profits on these chemicals the report has mysteriously yet to surface. Instead, what we hear is that the European Commission is proposing to release an impact assessment in 2016. It is disheartening to hear yet again another story of the Commission bending to its corporate bedfellows instead of implementing rigorous regulation to protect consumers and the environment.  There is no excuse for any delay. There is plenty of scientific evidence to support the immediate suspension of the use of certain harmful substances, and it is a view which is also held by certain influential Member States. So, given that EDCs are used routinely in everyday household items such as toiletries, cosmetics, food containers, plastics and pesticides to name but a few, it is extremely urgent that the precautionary principle be upheld and that action be postponed as the Commission plans. EDCs have been linked to a wide range of diseases and conditions such as – as we have heard – foetal abnormalities, infertility, autism, diabetes and hormonal cancers. This Frankenstein list of health causes is only compounded when we consider the staggering economic cost of EDC exposure.

name: Bart Staes
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. Mr President, Commissioner, we all know that the health cost of endocrine disrupting substances is enormous. This has already been proven by studies carried out by the World Health Organisation and UNIP, which was proven by the study of Professor Kortekamp, who was requested by the Commission's DG ENVI, and this has also been proven by the study made public last week and referred to by you and Mr Pargneaux. The scientists say very clearly that this cost is at least 157 billion, 1.23 % of gross national product. According to these scientists, endocrine disruptors do indeed provide a lower IQ, more obesity in adults and at least 5% of all cases of autism. The situation is therefore very serious.  The European Parliament has always endorsed Professor Kortekamp's recommendations. There is a need for clarity on the definition of endocrine disruptors. In 2009 and 2011, the Council and Parliament already set provisional criteria, but in 2009 the Commission was also instructed to come up with permanent criteria by the end of December 2013. In the meantime, five years have passed, five years of debate, five years of industry lobbying to the highest circles of the European Commission. As far as endocrine disruptors are concerned, incompetent scientists have caused the sowing of doubt, a tactic that we also know from the tobacco industry. Murder and fire screamed the industry. The Commission's Secretary-General, Mrs Day, first decided to launch an impact study. But that's incredible: an impact study on scientific facts! It's like looking for where the cancer comes from and asking the industry that makes the carcinogens: how is it that that cancer is causing it? No, you have to be with scientists for something like that.  The Commission is therefore failing in many respects. She's not fulfilling her legal obligations. A case is before the Court of Justice initiated by Sweden, supported by Parliament and supported by the Council. Secondly, it does not approach the issue horizontally, as imposed in the Seventh Environmental Action Programme and in the roadmap. The Commission is limited to pesticides and biocides. Thirdly, the Commission is putting lobbying forces ahead of science.  Commissioner, take responsibility, take swift action, make sure that health is ahead of the interests of the industry.

name: Piernicola Pedicini
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, welcome Commissioner. I would like to point out that reach legislation on EU chemistry had decreed a continental-wide ban on the use of pesticides that have an endocrine disrupting effect, and the Commission was called upon to take all necessary measures to protect public health.  However, the previous DG SANCO tried to circumvent, with all the instruments at its disposal, the eu's imminent ban on pesticides acting as endocrine disruptors. It is only superfluous to remember that these substances alter hormonal regulation, causing effects on behavior, reproduction, the incidence of cancer and also on the onset of birth defects. Despite this, instead of providing safety criteria and a detailed list of endocrine disruptors, DG SANCO has been working behind closed doors to circumvent the ban on REACH legislation, with the support of the European Food Safety Agency. That is why, in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, we decided to support Sweden, which is suing the European Union for circumvention of this ban, as a result of which there has then been a certain impact on the fertility of so many young people and girls. However, the question remains of the role played by DG SANCO and also by EFSA, which have not acted to protect public health, thus completely betraying their mandate.  We therefore want to know what measures have been taken to bring out the responsibilities and what measures have been taken to properly penalise those responsible for both DG SANCO and the European Food Safety Authority.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (NI).
text: Mr President, it is not for the Commission to answer a scientific question that has already been decided as to what an endocrine disruptor is. Hundreds of scientific publications are already doing so. Only chemical industry lobbyists pretend to have a definition to avoid spending and preserve their dividends.  However, the dangers of endocrine disruptors are visible to all and are the subject of numerous studies. The most recent, published on 5 March, presents the annual consequences of these chemical molecules on the territory of the Union: 25,000 deaths, 96 new cases of obesity, 618,000 use of medically assisted reproduction. Obesity, diabetes, autism, cancer: lives are at stake.  Deaf to public health issues, perhaps the Commission will hear the economic argument. In the same study, the cost of endocrine disruptors is estimated at up to 269 billion euros per year. And again, this study admits to ignoring all products or all their effects. If the Commission is unable to protect our health and our economies, it must leave member states free of their policies.  Together with my colleagues from the National Front of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, I have therefore asked the public hearing of EFSA to explain its delusional conclusions concerning bisphenol A. Seeing the US chemical industry unions welcome these findings is more than alarming. The time is no longer for impact studies or definitions of bureaucrats, it is for emergency action. It's about everyone's health.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE).
text: – Mr President, a Latin proverb says that 'All people want to have health, but they often do everything against it'. A number of high-profile organizations, such as the World Health Organization or the American Academy of Pediatricians, have drawn attention in recent years to the high danger that endocrine disruptors and other chemicals assimilated to human health pose to human health. Endocrine disruptors are chemicals that, once in the human body, prevent its normal growth and development, bring negative changes to metabolism, leading to various forms of cancer, infertility, obesity or diabetes. The European Union as a whole has a duty to make the health of its citizens a priority. In this respect, I believe that the impact studies launched by the Commission in this area must have as their main objective the potential implications of endocrine disruptors on human health and in no way the economic implications for the industry or trade. We may ask ourselves: what good will a high-productivity high-productivity agriculture do us, but with a sick population. Certainly, we would say, to nothing. I therefore believe that it is necessary to adopt clear rules on combating endocrine disruptors, banning them and replacing them with some substances considered safe, so as to strike a perfect balance in order to ensure the continued protection of human health and the environment and, at the same time, to provide farmers with the plant protection products they need. The European Commission, the Council and the European Parliament must intervene urgently in solving this problem, all the more so since the exposure of the population to these substances generates expenditure of more than EUR 30 billion in the European Union, as is also apparent from the studies carried out by the institutions.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D).
text: – Commissioner, we are working together on this subject, I, as you know, am cooperating with your DG and you have inherited the problem. It's not your problem, you didn't even create it.  In principle, I appreciate the procedure and the fact that your director of DG, Mr Miko, has created a task force to deal with this matter as you inherited it. All my spokesmen here quoted a study by the Endocrinology Society on March 5th, I don't have to do it again. We know how much it costs us, we know what endocrine destructors will do. Physiologist, doctors do not have to explain anything, it would be useless.  What is important is this: the Commission, not you personally, but the Commission as such has breached its obligations and is now being sued by Sweden, and both Parliament and the Council have indeed joined the action. It is the failure, the failure of the Commission, the failure of one person, Secretary-General Catherine Day, who commissioned the study and thus caused the legislation to be delayed.  Why cui bono can be found very easily from a January 16 filing from the United States, which said: 'It is important that the Commission's approach to endocrine disruptors does not foreclose U.S.—EU cooperation to increase transatlantic and global compatibility in the regulation of endocrine disruptors.' So we know why, we know corporations don't like it.  Commissioner, if the Commission is on the side of the citizens in this fight, we will support you, if not, we will fight you.

name: Bolesław G. Piecha (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I rarely do this, but I wanted to express my full support and nod to the Commissioner for his reason. Acting under the influence of the moment, under the influence of press reports, unfortunately carries the hallmarks of populism, not reliable scientific papers. These are very important issues and it is very sensible to act here. They basically cover all sectors of our lives, from agriculture to cosmetics, supplements, diets, etc., etc., including air. I believe that full risks should be assessed above all, not theoretical risks and reports from individual scientific documents. That's not enough. Of course, such threats exist. The World Health Organization also made a mistake at one time. Not so long ago, she recommended all countries to buy a vaccine for all citizens against swine flu. I would like to inform you that 90% of the resources of this vaccine have subsequently been licked.

name: Anja Hazekamp (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, it looks like a common cover-up which would probably have resulted in a vote of no confidence in national politics. The European Commission has hidden away an important report, a report which concludes that 31 types of agricultural poison could – and should be – banned.  Because of this endocrine-disrupting poison, which sprays fruits and vegetables, people are at great risk; foetal abnormalities, changes in the genitals, infertility, a reduction in intelligence and cancer, these are a number of examples. People, animals and our environment are literally being poisoned. Bee colonies disappear, bird populations thin out and frogs are wiped out. These objections do not seem to outweigh the billions of profits made by the industry for the European Commission. In fact, the industry lobby has so much influence that the summit within the European Commission deliberately kept this report under wraps, so that 31 dangerous agricultural poisons are still sprayed on our crops.  I believe that a healthy living environment, healthy food is more important than short-sighted commercial interests, and I am curious to see what the Commissioner thinks. I call on the Commission to publish the report, to ban the substances and to use common sense while it is still possible, because you also know that these substances are affecting intelligence. I also believe that European agricultural subsidies must be stopped.

name: Margrete Auken (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President! And thank you, Commissioner, for answering. I choose to rely on the promise that there will be no compromise on health. We have now documented that these endocrine disruptors damage brain development in unborn children. It creates infertility in young boys and there are a number of other very serious consequences and we also now know the costs to society. You were mentioned here the other day, 5 March, and I mentioned earlier that the figure of some EUR 150 billion came out today in Le Monde. What we now have to ask the Commission is – yes, I cannot ask for Catherine Day to be phased out, I would have liked that, but she asked, having been lobbied by the agrochemical industry and the rest of the chemical industry, to examine only the costs of this for the industry. So now we need to get a Commission that can pack her far away – not in plastic, because it is also filled with endocrine disruptors, so no more plastic there – but make sure that we now go out as a good Commission that actually wants the environment and wants health and can look at the real costs to society and take these consequences into account. , when we now have to do an impact assessment, and not just the agro-industrial complex' concerns. It's in the water, it's all over the place. We need a Commission that dares something now and does not just say small on small things. We don't need that here.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, endocrine-disrupting chemical compounds undermine the future of entire animal populations and man himself, causing, among other things, a reduction in fertility and an increase in neonatal diseases. According to a recent study by 18 of the most eminent scientists in this field, the economic damage caused by endocrine disruptors is estimated at EUR 157 billion per year, or 1.23% of the European Union's GDP. The European Environment Agency, in its most recent report, has shown that the current level of exposure to endocrine disruptors is one of the quality indicators with a negative trend. It is clear from the exchanges of emails between senior officials of the European Commission published by The Guardian newspaper at the beginning of February that the Commission has delayed the application of the criteria identified by dg Environment for the enactment of the appropriate delegated acts. Their adoption would have led to the elimination of 20% of the active ingredients used and would have involved the production of triazoles and dithiocarbammates, which represent 80 % of the fungicide market worth EUR 8-9 billion per year. In total, it is estimated that 31 dangerous pesticides used in agriculture would have been banned if the criteria developed had not been blocked for economic reasons. I therefore believe that, in addition to the delay in issuing the delegated acts assigned to it, the Commission must also explain whether and how it has taken account of the economic damage that the delay in dealing with the problem would have caused to the community.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D).
text: - Mr. President, the debate on endocrine disruptors carries within us an issue that we often face in the European Parliament whether I want to protect the economy or health.  The Commission, in this case, sided with money, namely the chemical industry and agriculture, and that is why it is our obligation to raise our voices on behalf of those who elected us. Research is contradictory but even minimal calculation of the damage that endocrine disruptors from pesticides potentially cause through air, fetal deformities, infertility, decrease in IQ call for action.  The argument that banning pesticides containing these substances would currently harm European agriculture stands. But we as legislators need to think long-term. If one child's endocrine disruptors reduce their IQ, this is a serious family problem. But 100,000 such children is a European problem.  The money that by allowing endocrine disruptors saves today, tomorrow we will spend on repairing the damage they cause, and that's why I'm glad I heard the commissioner's words that they won't do anything that's harmful.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: "Thank you very much for the floor, Mr President. Dear Colleagues, Ladies and Gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. If we were to devote a fraction of our virtues in the fight against smoking to the fight against endocrine agents, I must say that we would be standing elsewhere. There have been reports of tossing for years. The fight against invisible poison, I think, is very important, and I am very pleased with the Commissioner's very firm commitment, and in particular what he said: zero tolerance. We would like to see this as soon as possible in the Commission's actions. But not only in the Commission's actions, but also in the Commission's negotiations. I very much do not want Europe to be lenient in this area in the TTIP negotiations. I also ask for zero tolerance on the part of the Commission. Thank you very much for the opportunity!

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D).
text: Mr President! For every day the Commission hesitates and fails to take action against the chemistry chaos that prevails, it simply costs the health of its citizens, and it is our children in particular who are at risk. It also costs our environment, and it costs a lot of money. So this is completely unacceptable. We're not talking about something that's new. We are talking about a case that we have been discussing for years and where we have had lots of knowledge. I think that the Commission should start listening a little more to the citizens, rather than just listening to industry. Yes, it's complex. There is no doubt about that, but I think we need to think and think about the precautionary principle and at least start by removing the substances from our everyday products that are suspected of being endocrine disruptors. We need to think about what is in the public interest here. The citizens simply cannot understand that we have not acted yet – and to be honest, I cannot actually do that either.

name: Czesław Adam Siekierski (PPE).
text: – We in the European Union attach great importance to the quality, standards, safety of the products we produce. The most important thing, of course, is the health of the consumer and the quality of the products. This applies to a wide range of products, from children's toys to many of the goods we use on the market, through the most important issues when it comes to food that makes a significant contribution to human health.  In this context, a number of criticisms have been made about the plant protection products used. And rightly so. But at the same time, let us also take into account that these changes that are taking place are very significant. It is not enough, we need to monitor it more, to assess it, but the plant protection products industry is already thoroughly testing new products in order to ensure the safety and effectiveness of their use. Of course, we must continue to monitor, control, but this progress is large, visible and worth remembering, because we must maintain – of course health is the first – but we must also maintain the competitiveness of our agriculture vis-à-vis other regions of the world.

name: Karin Kadenbach (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has Do not lose sight of competitiveness – but this will only work if we have healthy Europeans, and this will only succeed if we have a europe that is still fertile, where our young men will no longer become fathers as a result of fertility disorders caused by endocrine disruptors. We can only be a competitive Europe if we have as far as possible healthy people here in this Europe who are not at risk from endocrine disruptors. That sounds so technical. Let us simply say what it is: endocrine disrupting substances, substances that help people in the womb to develop in a healthy way, substances that simply help our young people to no longer have the intelligence they could have if these substances were no longer on the market. Let us not hide constantly behind any economic interests and, in reality, put Europe as a business location at risk! We need the people at the centre, and we need legislation for these people that must come quickly. Mr Andriukaitis, you are not to blame, but you can help to increase this debt or help this Europe to remain healthy, healthier and economically strong.

name: Anthea McIntyre (ECR).
text: – Mr President, the Commission was right to launch an impact assessment into the different options for definitions of endocrine—disrupting chemicals. We now need to ensure that the final definition is proportionate and based on the science.  Not all substances that have an effect on the endocrine system are endocrine disruptors. For example, many plant-based foods such as caffeine in coffee interact with the hormonal system without leading to disruption or harm. Endocrine active substances should be treated like most other substances of potential concern and be subject to risk assessment in which both the hazard and the exposure are considered. Rising world demand for food means that Europe’s farmers are going to have to produce significantly more in the years ahead. With over 850 million people in the world who do not have enough to eat Europe, with its favourable soils and climate, surely has a moral obligation to optimise agricultural output. But this cannot be realised if our farmers do not have access to an adequate range of crop protection products.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: "Mr. President, paracelsus still said, "Every substance is poison. There's not a single substance that's not poison. Only the dose makes the substance a medicine or poison."  Today we know that it is also exposure to a substance. In this case, we are talking about a substance that negatively affects the development of a particularly young man, a child, reproduction, neurology, immune systems. We're really talking about something that's hurting our environment, and that's why I'm all for that so-called precautionary rule. A precautionary rule that means shutting down everything we can rule out immediately because the far-reaching consequences can be tragic for our Europe, especially for younger generations.  In this context, I want this intersectoral problem to be on the agenda of this Parliament as soon as possible and to draw smart conclusions together with the Commission.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, there has been talk here for a long time on the issue of endocrine disruptors and the European Commission has long been asked to take concrete measures to protect public health from the harmful effects of these substances. A necessary step in the creation of legislation against the use of these substances, used in current-use products, is the adoption of criteria that allow their recognition. This would be a necessary step, which should have already been taken by 2013, but which the European Commission has not wanted to take so far, wrapping itself in little or unconvincing explanations, as it has been clearly in sight today once again.  What seems to be at really at stake here is that other values rise and overlap with what should prevail: the public interest, the precautionary principle. This cannot be separated from the ongoing negotiations with the United States on the TTIP, the Free Trade Agreement, despite the Commission's vows to the contrary. It is that we know that in the United States the precautionary principle of nothing is worthit, and what this Treaty is really about is to level down in all fields, to put business ahead of public health.

name: Michèle Rivasi (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, I am speaking to you because you still have a heavy responsibility. We trust you because you are a doctor and you have always said that health is the best for the economy.  But there's an emergency. First, you have seen that the Barroso Commission has not complied with its programme. It was to provide its horizontal criteria on a scientific basis in December 2013. What did she do? This was said by our colleagues, she did a study of the economic impact on industrialists. But between us, it is not the industrialists who will define criteria! We want to know what the economic impact is on the chemical industry. So I'm asking you, how are you going to do it? If you say to us: 'We have to wait for the consultation, the 27,000 answers', this will not correspond to what we expect the Commission to set scientific criteria. So we're really asking you now to tell DG Environment, who has worked on this issue - and who has the criteria - to prioritize health over the economy. That is what we expect from you, Commissioner!

name: Vytenis Povilas Andriukaitis
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I have listened closely to this very interesting debate. I take note of your views and will pass them on to my colleagues for further reflection. I am a medical doctor and I say very clearly that, first and foremost, health is number one. If we speak of impact assessment, we must speak about health, the environment, then agriculture, then complex issues related to all, but in all this complexity health is the number one issue.  The issue of pressure from industry was mentioned. Believe me, this is not correct. I am open and I would like to do my job in a transparent manner. I have 17 meetings with some of you here and with Ministers of Agriculture, Health and the Environment. I have meetings with experts, with the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA), with NGOs, meetings with Green 10 and so on. I am ready to continue to do my job in this way. We have, of course, established a taskforce inviting experts in order to see all the complexity and to establish a good picture, taking in the scientific evidence-based arguments. Some speakers mentioned the issue of delay putting the health of European people at risk. This is not true. EU legislation in force already considers endocrine disruptors. In particular, consumers are protected from endocrine disruptors through European Union legislation on the authorisation of chemical substances to be used as plant protection products, biocidal products or industrial chemicals. We have such rules now and we use these rules to protect our people.  Regarding the possibility of doing this in a transparent manner, I would like to say that I am ready to invite you to our debates and, of course, the website will be ready where we can do it in a transparent manner.
