text: I close the debate. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Nessa Childers (S&D)
text: in writing. – Even though a majority of MEPs and Member States agreed on the need to phase out the use of these kinds of pesticides back in 2011, they all remain in use because the Commission, which is in charge of adopting criteria to classify this kind of hazardous chemicals, has stalled on the matter. The Commission has instead decided to prepare a redundant impact assessment.  This kind of procrastination is very valuable to the chemical industries that sell such products but quite useless and dangerous to our health. We already have strong, scientifically solid criteria that are validated by the WHO and used for the purposes of identifying chemical substances that cause a range of health problems. Banning these is all the more urgent given that very small amounts of these chemicals suffice to seriously disturb the normal functioning of hormones in our bodies.  The Commission had a legal deadline, which expired at the end of 2013, to define which chemicals qualify as endocrine disruptors according to sound scientific criteria. Instead it was circumvented by a strategically timed impact assessment that is not only poorly framed in terms of economic costs, but serves the industryʼs interest in profiting from inaction. This is unacceptable and the Commission must answer for it.

name: Jarosław Kalinowski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Consumer health is paramount, which is why European farmers, processors and food producers are striving to maintain a high bar when it comes to producing food to the highest standards. Research is therefore ongoing and new technologies and products are being tested to further modernise and improve production. This also makes plant protection products better and safer. Unjustified withdrawal of such products from the market would be a disaster for the entire food production system, and European agriculture would lose its full competitiveness on world markets.  I call for prudence so that the exclusion measures are not too hasty, but are based on thorough analyses and indisputable scientific studies that will determine whether a substance has a clearly harmful effect, in this case the endocrine system. Let us not forget, too, that we may be able to exclude plant protection products from the European market, but unfortunately not from the global market. And with current globalisation, we are also unable to completely control what we eat or touch.

name: Sophie Montel (NI)
text: In writing. This is an essential issue as it is directly related to public health. It is therefore surprising, to say the least, that the Commission seems to be asking questions about the proven correlation between the use of certain chemicals and endocrine disorders. Indeed, for years now, many scientists have been warning about this problem. Today' chemical industry lobbyists still pretend to need hard evidence, with the obvious aim of preserving their profits.  And yet, the latest study gives an unseeding assessment of the use of these chemical molecules in the European Union: 25,000 deaths, 618,000 use of medically assisted reproduction, not to mention the 96,000 new cases of obesity. This is the reality, chemicals can lead to serious and fatal diseases: cancers, obesity, diabetes...  If the public health argument is not one for some, perhaps they will be more sensitive to the economic argument. For 269 billion euros a year is spent on treating and treating patients who are victims of chemicals.  The time is no longer for studies, for analysis, but for action. But is the Union also capable of protecting?

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question to the Commission by Michael Cramer, on behalf of the Committee on Transport, on the impact of Russian restrictions on international road hauliers (O-000005/2015 - B8-0105/2015).

name: Michael Cramer
text: Author. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. As Chairman of the Committee on Transport and Tourism, I put the following questions to the Commission on the impact of Russia's restrictions on foreign road hauliers and would like to justify them as follows: on 7 August 2014, the Russian Federation issued a ban on imports of certain food and agricultural products, including from all EU Member States. For the transport sector, the embargo means a ban on the entry of vehicles transporting agricultural products and foodstuffs, thus a significant loss of contracts. The Russian Federation is also hindering the transit of food and agricultural products to which the embargo applies via its territory to third countries, for.B exampleby requiring escorts for such transports, increasing the price of guarantees for companies transporting goods affected by the embargo by ten times, and even by preventing such transits altogether. The Russian market is economically attractive for EU international freight companies, especially those based in Russia's neighbouring countries, due to proximity, size and development potential. The Commission has already responded to these restrictions on Russia by introducing short-term market support measures worth well over EUR 155 million to address market surplus problems for fruit, vegetables and dairy products. However, the impact on the market for the transport of these products has so far been neglected. It should be noted that the goods imported by the Russian Federation, mainly food and industrial products, are mainly transported by land. For hauliers who specialize in the transport of food and have invested in appropriate fleets and refrigerated vehicles, Russia's embargo means the loss of most of their contracts. At the last meeting of the Road Transport Group of the International Transport Forum, which was held on 25 May.  and 26 September 2014 in Paris, a Russian representative also announced that Russia would further restrict cross-border road freight transport on its territory by reducing the number of ECVM permits valid on Russian territory from 67 to 16 from 1 January 2015.  Therefore, my questions: 1. In this context, is the Commission aware of the seriousness of the current situation and is it aware of all the consequences that these Restrictions on Russian Road Transport Companies have for EU hauliers? 2. Can the Commission provide precise information on the losses to the EU economy as a result of these restrictions on Russia, particularly in the transport sector? 3. What measures does the new Commission intend to take to prevent a further deterioration of the situation for EU hauliers? 4. Given the impact of these restrictions on the EU economy as a whole, in particular in the transport sector, how does the new Commission intend to act in the light of the impact of these restrictions on the EU economy as a whole? 5. Does the Commission intend to take measures in the Trade Policy Committee to prepare a complaint against Russia in the WTO? Thank you for your attention and I look forward to the answers.

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the Russian ban on the import of certain agricultural goods from the EU and from some other countries has had an impact not only on the agricultural sector but also on specialised road transport operations in the EU, in particular in countries with a high volume of agriculture exports to Russia. Before the import ban took affect, Russia was, after the US, the second biggest importer of agricultural goods from the EU.  In terms of value, almost half of the agricultural exports from the EU to Russia, worth EUR 5.1 billion, are affected by the Russian import ban. Above all, this concerns meat and meat products, fish and seafood, milk and dairy products, and prepared fruits and vegetables. In addition, the transit of the banned products through Russia to markets in Central Asia or the Caucasus is also severely restricted, which effectively extends the ban to EU exports of the products concerned of these countries. Road is the main mode of transport for getting EU exports to Russia. More than 80% of all agricultural exports from the EU to Russia go by road, in both value and volume terms.  In addition to the producers of agricultural goods, it is above all road transport operators who are suffering because of the Russian import ban. I and my team are fully aware of this. Just how much they suffer is a question that is difficult to answer and that depends on individual circumstances. It is clear that many of the banned goods which would have gone to Russia are now redirected and sold on other markets.  In some areas, the price of the banned goods in local markets has fallen significantly due to the oversupply that has been created. In particular, road transport operators specialised in the export of agricultural products to Russia and who invested in equipment such as refrigerated vehicles may face real difficulties in the wake of the Russian import ban, but again this depends on how much they were able to redeploy their transport fleet.  How can we help the road hauliers most severely affected by the Russian import ban? Let me be clear. There is not much in terms of direct financial assistance we can offer at EU level. Unlike my colleague in charge of agriculture, I do not have an emergency fund for transport operators. At a national level, however, road hauliers in need may benefit from some state aid.  De minimus rules allow state aid for road freight transport companies of up to EUR 100 000 over a period of three years. There are some conditions attached but such aid does not have to be notified to the Commission. State aid above this limit can only be considered under very strict conditions and would have to be notified to the Commission. Road transport relations between the EU and Russia are still largely governed by bilateral agreements between Russia and individual Member States of the EU. It is therefore in the hands of Member States to see what they can do on the basis of their bilateral agreements. There is no EU-Russia road transport agreement, nor a corresponding policy dialogue. This issue can only be addressed with Russia in the context of our overall EU external policy towards Russia. In the context of the EU external trade policy, the Commission is monitoring the WTO compatibility of the various restrictions applied by Russia very closely, including the restriction on the transit of the banned products through Russia.

name: Elżbieta Katarzyna Łukacijewska
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by The introduction by the Russian Federation of a ban on imports of a certain catalogue of agri-food products from the European Union has resulted in a significant deterioration of the situation of many companies in the commercial, processing, livestock and agricultural industries, as well as to a large extent transport. The entry ban on vehicles carrying these articles results in the inability of any cargo to pass through Russian territory, resulting in millions of losses and often causing the bankruptcy of many companies operating in the transport sector.  It should be borne in mind that, in addition to factors considered in purely economic terms, social factors must also be taken into account. This is the specter of unemployment for many people who will sooner or later require social support, if only in the form of benefits. This is a great misfortune and uncertainty for a number of entities producing goods exported to Russia and many owners of transport companies, employees and their families. These problems do not apply only to companies Polish, although to a large extent these losses are generated by companies from my country. I therefore believe that it is important that we, in solidarity as the European Union, take action to find solutions that will effectively protect the interests of economic operators with regard to the introduction of restrictions. The lack of mechanisms to counteract the negative effects of the embargo may disrupt the functioning of the European Union's transport market as well as other markets, given the strong links between transport and other industries. At the 2014 Transport Council meeting, Poland proposed to implement concrete solutions to support transport companies affected by the Russian embargo, such as the use of a higher permitted state aid rate or support for those who decide to withdraw part of their rolling stock due to environmental factors.  I am pleased that the European Commission is aware of the problems with the introduction of the embargo, but I would like to ask the Commissioner what specific solutions the Commission is proposing, what support is it proposing? Entrepreneurs, companies are waiting for this, and employees who may lose their jobs are waiting for it.

name: Claudia Tapardel
text: on behalf of the S&D group – Mr President, Commissioner, in a globalised economy, goods have unprecedented mobility and supply chains are becoming increasingly complex and spread over a much larger geographical area. The embargo imposed by the Russian Government on agri-food products from the European Union gives us a clear picture of the impact that a political decision can have on many European economic sectors. I join my colleagues in the Committee on Transport and Tourism who draw attention to the effects of these restrictions on the market for international road hauliers of agri-food products. We cannot understand the seriousness of the situation if we neglect the economic loss caused by supply contracts concluded and lost by European carriers operating on the Russian export market. The cumulative impact of oversupply of agri-food products on the internal market, the loss of these contracts and the significant increase in the cost of transport in transit to third countries affect the entire European economy, not just one sector of it. The Central and Eastern European states are most affected by this situation and, due to the sources of the internal market, the effect is felt throughout the EU. I call on the European Commission to provide Parliament with sufficient data on the impact of the embargo, and I also call on us, together, to find an appropriate solution to this problem.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for Thank you very much for the opportunity to speak and to speak on this important issue, because I think that, as we all sit here, we will agree that the Russian embargo on products, agri-food products is hitting the European market very hard, I stress – in the European transport industry and is causing serious disruption to the international transport market. This is not just a single country problem, it is not just a local problem, it is a European problem and countries such as Lithuania, Latvia, Slovakia, the Czech Republic or Bulgaria, or Greece, or finally my country, Poland, are losing a lot of money on this embargo.  Suffice it to say that since August 2014, when the embargo was introduced, the losses of the Polish transport sector amounted to EUR 22 million, and in November they have already increased to EUR 48 million. The Russian side makes it difficult or completely impossible to transit agri-food products to other countries, and I would also like to draw your attention here to a certain asymmetry in the treatment of transport between the European Union and Russia, because if European transport companies are embargoed, they are controlled in detail, this is not the case with Russian companies. It would certainly be worth considering what to do to ensure that this asymmetry in these relations between Russia and the European Union in this area disappears. Finally, it is very important. European carriers have been taking ticks for several months now, because on the one hand, the minimum wage in Germany, which is hitting transport companies in Europe significantly, and on the other hand, the Russian embargo. I would therefore like to appeal here and ask the Commissioner – and I am pleased that you have said very openly here that she is aware of these problems – but I would like to call on the Commissioner, however, to consider a compensation scheme or, for example, to relax the rules for supporting road hauliers in the context of de minimis aid for the restructuring of credit or leasing obligations.

name: Gesine Meissner
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ALDE Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner Bulc, you have basically already given the answer, namely that it is difficult at the moment to do something on your part. It is very important for me to point out on this issue that this is not about us not depriving the sanctions to be right. We will now discuss again on Wednesday what this looks like, especially after the assassination of Boris Nemtsov, which must be done in order to maintain further sanctions. The problem is that in this case we are affected by certain sectors. We have already discussed the concern of the agricultural sector and compensation payments there. Commissioner, you yourself have said that there is a crisis pot, and that there is no such thing in the transport sector. A quarter of all EU agricultural exports are affected. These are all exports that are transported in refrigerated trucks. You can't necessarily just repurpose these refrigerated trucks for anything else. Attempts are already being made to find new markets for agricultural products, and in some cases to sell more in the EU. But that is not the same from now on. And if they are new markets, then the question arises as to whether it is of any benefit to Russia's most affected neighbours. It is indeed the case that Lithuania, for example, affects 40% of exports, which is a huge figure. The Baltic States, Poland and Finland are generally the most affected. Of course, we need to think about what can be done. Commissioner, you pointed out that nothing can be expected of the EU, because we do not have a pot for it, that must go through the Member States themselves. Sure, that's one thing. Since we have a European transport market, an internal market, we are also considering how we can perhaps act in solidarity here, because we also share the sanctions against Russia. You yourself said that the data is not yet fully available. Perhaps we can gather even more and then try to find a solution on how to strike a balance together, and not just leave it to the Member States. For example, to have Lithuania compensated alone with 40% would be unfair if you look at the whole of the EU. So there is a certain helplessness here. But I think it would be a good thing if we could find a solution for the transport sector.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, the question from the European Parliament's Committee on Transport to the Commission - which we are debating today - shows that there is a selective memory in this Chamber. Our committee is talking about the measures to restrict imports and transport of agricultural products taken by Russia on 7 August 2014, forgetting that these were a response to European sanctions against Russia in connection with the Ukrainian crisis a few days earlier, on 31 July.  It is also typical that colleagues in the Committee on Transport are now also calling for restrictions on the movement of goods within the World Trade Organisation. But if anyone has violated the Agency's regulations first, it is the European Union, since Regulation 833 of 2014 on sanctions against Russia does not even mention specific and even essential security interests of the Union or its members affected by Russia's actions in the Ukrainian crisis to justify the imposition of sanctions.  The bottom line is that sanctions have proved ineffective in influencing Russian politics and the only result of the trade war is to harm European producers and carriers. Therefore, either the measures should be mutually lifted or else the European Union must pay full compensation to those affected for as long as Regulation 833 of 2014 remains in force.

name: Peter Lundgren
text: On the other: The EFDD Group. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr This is, of course, a major problem that affects ordinary people in the long run, who do not have their transport of food catered for. But we should also be perfectly clear what it is. This is a result of the arc being strained by the EU against Russia. Russia's side, of course, responds with this embargo, it is not terribly difficult to figure out. I can also understand that Member States that have a haulage company operating on Russia are concerned about this, but at the same time I find it difficult to believe that we in the European Union will be able to change this, as the Commissioner also confirms to some extent. Another thing i am also thinking about: it is the case that these hauliers who have been affected have invested a lot of money in special vehicles adapted for refrigerated and cold transport. The Russian embargo will then also have the effect of losing the majority of its transports. That is exactly what is happening in my country. Now we are talking about the inside of the EU, where Swedish hauliers have invested a lot of money in what they call "megatrucks" here. Then you get out-of-competition by cars from other Member States that drive for half the costs. If we cannot get the internal market in Europe in order, I find it very difficult to see that we will be able to solve the problem that has arisen with Russia.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Cramer's question is sure to surprise me.  The Russian embargo on European food products was introduced on 6 August 2014, while the first economic sanctions by the European Union against Russia date from 17 March 2014. They were then extended by Brussels six times until 31 July 2014. The National Front opposed the sanctions in March, deeming them inappropriate, ineffective and dangerous to the economies of the EU Member States.  This question shows that the National Front was right to oppose it, since the Russian embargo was only the direct and legitimate response to the sanctions imposed by the European Union. Road hauliers in the European Union are therefore the first victims of the absurd sanctions imposed by Brussels. Rather than complaining about their consequences, as Mr Cramer does, I would rather ask the Commission to lift these sanctions. And, I take the gamble, the Russian embargo will be lifted in turn. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

text: Author, question about the procedure of the "blue card". Are you aware that I spoke as chairman of the committee and that this was a consensual statement by the committee and not my personal one? This violated all the laws, and then came the sanctions. So if you look back in history, please come from the beginning!

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (NI)

name: Wim van de Camp (PPE).
text: Mr President, I am delighted to speak after my Colleague from the Front National, because then we can immediately mark the differences. At the moment, Europe and, in fact, the whole world is suffering from the conflict between Russia and Ukraine. We have chosen in Europe to combat this conflict with sanctions. It hurts. Many different sectors of the economy in Europe are noticing the adverse effects of these sanctions. But, as Mr Cramer also says, we must comply with the international treaties, and we cannot do that without pain.  Of course, the Commissioner is right: agriculture has its own emergency fund. There are several entrepreneurs who can make use of this, and I welcome them to do the same. But we are dealing here with the transport sector and, in particular, the transport sector of our Polish colleagues is suffering enormously from these sanctions. I regret that the Commissioner does not go beyond listing the facts because it does not yet offer any solutions.  That is why I have three questions for her: what are the contacts between her and Mrs Mogherini? The EU has a lot of emergency funds, Mrs Mogherini in particular. Can't the Polish transport sector take advantage of that? We have the globalisation fund, which contains a lot of money and which is used for industrial reorientation. Can the transport sector make use of this? And indeed, Mr Cramer's important question: what is the EU doing at the WTO? Is there going to be an official complaint against Russia?

name: Μιλτιάδης Κύρκος (
text: S&D). Mr President, Commissioner, the fair imposition of the embargo on Russia because of the events in Crimea and the rest of Ukraine and Russia's response has created the known major problems in trade, especially agricultural products, both in Greece and in many other European countries. What is less well known to citizens is the huge problem that has been created in the transport sector.  For Greece alone, we estimate 10 million euros, on an annual basis, the lost profits. You understand that in the enormous economic crisis that Greece is going through and in conditions of, many times, unfair competition, this situation can be the final blow. The Commission's response in December 2014, which refuses all assistance and urges the industry to adapt to a different business model, sounds like a mockery. Of course that is what people do, but the loss of income due to a political decision - the whole of the Union - must somehow be compensated, otherwise we are pushing people to take our policies negatively.

name: Roberts Zīle (ECR).
text: – Mr President, honourable Commissioner, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur on her excellent work. First of all, I would like to say that we are not talking here and not complaining that someone in the Kremlin would be happy about it, or someone would be happy to be sitting here and sympathising with the Kremlin's policies. Finally, these Eastern European hauliers, which have suffered the most from this part, are, however, also under pressure from the so-called social dumping in the road transport sector and from methods that are currently suspended, but which have not necessarily ended, such as the German minimum wage for transit. Thanks, I think it's about this!

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, it is a pleasure to have the Commissioner here tonight. The problems are actually very severe in Lithuania in particular, because we have 5% of the working population working in this sector. So this is a significant problem where we genuinely need your input and ideas. How can we survive when we are taking the brunt of the Russian hit? We are suffering, believe me, we are really suffering! We are coming to you for help, we are coming to you to be creative and find the help that we need.  Furthermore, look at what our European partners are doing. We can name it: Germany has come up with a minimum wage which we cannot implement at the moment because we are not rich enough – we are not as rich as the Germans. The same situation in France and Belgium: they want our drivers to sleep in hotels that do not exist. Let us all unite and at least help each other and not rip each other apart. We are suffering. Let us all be creative, let us unite and stand against Russia together.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, I would like to highlight the impact on trade with the Russian Federation, particularly road transport, caused by the ill thought—out and provocative eastern expansion of the EU. Because haulage companies cannot do meaningful business with Russia they now have to be supported by our taxpayers, with no end to the need for support in sight. We also now have food producers with no market to sell in. Prior to the embargo, 50% of EU exports to Russia were being done using land transport. The impact on huge areas of business cannot be underestimated because the little that is allowed to enter or cross Russia is subject to huge extra costs, increasing the price of goods. The EU is directly responsible for these instabilities. It was a complete folly to provoke Russia by the foolhardy actions of the eastern expansion and this Parliament should regret its actions.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: question posed by raising the blue card. – Dear Madam Advocate, you spoke very badly about countries that entered the European Union after the European Union was founded, and you spoke especially badly about recent entry and countries that are from the so-called Eastern Europe. I ask you, are you not ashamed to talk about these countries like that, about these peoples who have been looking forward to living together in a single Europe?

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, commissioner, thank you for being here late this evening to discuss issues that we really care about. I come from a country which, in relation to the specific problem, has touched less on this question, in the sense that Italy certainly feels the problem of sanctions on the production front but, unlike the eastern countries which have legitimately intervened this evening, it warns it less from the point of view of transport, but we cannot avoid it. I fully share the spirit of this reconstruction which has been proposed by the chairman of my committee, Mr Cramer, and I share the concern expressed by other Members that, in some way, the European Union cannot avoid the need to respond also in the field of transport where, as you rightly pointed out, there are no specific possibilities for action in support of the tragedy endured by entrepreneurs in this sector. Tomorrow, for example, we will be speaking again in this House to discuss the possibility of intervening economically in support of major business crisis situations around Europe, for example in the steel sector, when you were already mentioning the interventions in the agricultural sector. We cannot leave the transport sector out. Someone said: 'Let us find with imagination the way to give answers': it is in fact from these small answers, sometimes even fanciful ones, that we can regenerate that spirit of hope that is the only possibility we have for avoiding sometimes strange discussions, such as those we have heard just now, about the need to find those who have the most fault: who first set the sanctions or who set the embargoes afterwards. No, this is not our debate. Our debate must be aimed at finding answers to those who have a problem in Europe today, and this transport problem is a clear, concrete problem on which we cannot fail to intervene.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Decision of the Russian Federation to introduce import bans on certain agricultural and food products from the European Union is unfortunately causing damage to many sectors. In fact, not only are farmers forced to let thousands of goods go unsold, but the haulage companies that were responsible for getting goods to their destination have also had huge transport contracts cancelled to and from that state.
