text: – Mr President, in this debate I will reserve my opinion on the capacities of sanctions to move wills because after I have seen what happened in Spain with Franco and In Cuba, the truth is that it is unhealthy. However, I will refer to today's subject.  When last August 17th the Russian Federation imposed a ban on the import of certain agricultural products, the news came to me from my region – where we produced excellent peaches and nectarines – because I was told that the trucks were already on the Russian border, and I immediately thought of all the drivers who had been travelling so many kilometres and who had managed to get to the Russian border to be stopped and forced or to look for new markets , new opportunities, or just to lose the load. After that veto on the Russian border, new conditions have been implemented in companies: the need for escorts or the prices of guarantees, that is, a whole series of added difficulties. And you, Commissioner, tell us that what those affected and their products have to do is look for other markets. I wish they could! But countries such as Germany, at the heart of the European Union, are also applying a number of obstacles that also hinder the ability of these truckers to carry out their economic activity. In that you do have the capacity to act and I hope you act.

name: Georgi Pirinski (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to ask the Commissioner to refer to the third question that our Chairman, Mr Cramer, has addressed to her, namely which measures would the new Commission envisage undertaking in order to avoid a further deterioration of the European hauliers situation. I emphasise the new Commission because the point that was made was that this was a Commission working as a team – not in silos, not each Commissioner for himself – so, when a decision is taken by the Union, it has to look at all the consequences of this decision, namely the grave losses that the transport sector is suffering and the indirect disruption to the transport market throughout Europe. It is no good just to tell us to go back home and look for state aid from our governments.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, dar ndóigh aon uair a bhíonn smachtbhannaí ann bíonn grúpaí áirithe thíos leis dá bharr. Bhí a fhios againn go raibh an tionscal talmhaíochta thíos leis go dtí seo, ach anocht chualamar an scéal truamhéalach mar a bhaineann leis an tionscal earraí a iompar agus is trua an scéal é sin. Dúirt an Coimisinéir nach bhfuil aon chiste acu – agus b’fhéidir go bhfuil sé sin fíor – ach ag an am céanna ní dóigh liom gur maith a dhóthain é an méid sin a rá. Ba chóir dúinn, ar a laghad, ciste práinneach a chur le chéile chun cabhrú leis na daoine seo mar taispeánann sé sin go dtuigimid a gcás. Níl sé maith a dhóthain a bheith ag rá gur féidir leo cabhair a fháil ina stát féin. Ba chóir dúinn rud éigin a dhéanamh san Eoraip; cé go bhfuil sé deacair, mar a dúirt an Coimisinéir. Ach dar ndóigh caithfimid seasamh le chéile maidir leis na smachtbhannaí go dtí go gcuireann an Rúis deireadh leis an drochiompar atá acu san Úcráin.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D).
text: – Commissioner, a lot of the problem that is being felt today in the area of transport has been expressed, but I would like to stress that this is not a transport or an economic issue. This is a political issue. This is a question of our solidarity with the European Union. And it is really a little strange to me that today you have nothing concrete and did not give an idea of the new Commission. And I truly sympathise with you personally that you have to work in such a difficult situation. How do you imagine addressing problems not only in the Baltic states, eastern European countries, but also in other countries? I fully agree and understand Italy's problem with the influx of refugees into this country, the sovereignty of other countries, and here is also one of the political issues. Do we in the European Union have some flair and understanding of solidarity and mutual assistance, or will Russia actually continue to pursue its policy of splitting and wielding all of us? Therefore, commissioner, I hope that this issue will indeed be raised to a higher political level. And we all have to find support, not only economic assistance, but also political assistance to those countries.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, the Cold War conflict between the European Union and Russia has caused an adverse effect on the economy of the European south. On 9 August, in my question to the European Parliament, I asked for full compensation, not only for farmers in Greece, but also for Greek transport companies. Greek carriers have already lost more than 10 million euros, as 40% of Greek agricultural products are exported to Russia and transported by trucks.  When the embargo against the former Yugoslavia was lifted in 1992 by Regulation 525, Greek carriers were compensated. I now have a Commission document, Mr President, dated 9.12.2014 informing Greek carriers that they cannot be entitled to compensation from the European Union for the damage they have suffered from the Russian embargo, which was a countermeasure to the restrictive measures imposed by the European Union.  The European Union and the Commission are therefore calling on the Greek carriers to find a solution to their problem on their own. Too bad, gentlemen of the Commission!

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: Mr. President, Dear Madam Commissioner Bulc, I have a concrete proposal.  I think it is very important that the Commission familiarizes this Parliament with the overall consequences of our relations with Russia. Our decision was to impose sanctions. This has been the politics of the majority in this Parliament and the policies of the European Commission and the Council, and I think it is important that we know the overall relationships of this problem. Not just in transport, not only, colleagues and colleagues, in agriculture. Of course there are consequences in other sectors, especially in some countries.  So, I don't think it's good that we only discuss individual sectors, but I think it's very important that we decide how to proceed even if we give up some projects for a while, because maybe the sanctions will last a long time.  So I propose that you be the holder of the Commission's joint appearance towards Parliament on all the overall consequences of these sanctions.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the European road transport operators affected by the sanctions imposed by the European Union on Russia, which have been taken as a response, are also part of what we might call the collateral damage of the European Union's position. An unacceptable position – of confrontation, of instigation, of deepening of the conflict. A position which, in the name of unconfessed political, economic and geostrategic interests, on behalf of these unconfessed interests, has destabilized Ukraine, has promoted the rise to power of nazi-fascist forces, supported and financed by the United States, by the European Union, which now expect them to satisfy their interests.  In this process, European transport operators, such as agricultural producers such as aquaculture and fisheries companies, are such collateral damage to a strategy that sacrifices them to these other interests. The European Commission cannot therefore wash its hands here, as it has come here today. You have direct responsibilities in these damages. You cannot simply throw the costs of any compensation on member states.  (The speaker agrees to answer a question under the blue card procedure in accordance with Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Michael Cramer
text: Author, question about the procedure of the "blue card". – Let me go back to history: Russia has broken the 1994 Budapest Treaty, which was signed by all the victorious powers of the Second World War. They have assured Ukraine of territorial integrity when it withdraws its nuclear weapons. That's what they did. Then Russia annexed Crimea. Do you think that's right or not? If Russia had not broken this treaty and annexed Crimea, we in Europe would not have been talking about sanctions against Russia and everything that comes next. Do you condemn the annexation of Crimea, yes or no?

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: Response according to the "blue card" procedure. "Dear Mr. Cramer, I answer you by returning another question. It's just that you see part of the story, you don't see the whole story. And so I return the following question to you: Do you remember, Mr. Cramer, the statements made by Mrs. Secretary of State, Mrs. Nuland? Do you remember that? Are these about the European Union and the funding that has been made of nazi-fascist forces that have risen to power in Ukraine and which bring to our memory the darkest pages in the history of Europe? It is these forces that came to power through a coup that is now in Ukraine with the support of the European Union and the United States.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE).
text: – Honourable Commissioner, despite the significant losses caused by the sanctions imposed by Russia, the Lithuanian transport and logistics sector has received insufficient attention from the European Commission. On the contrary, France and Belgium have banned weekly rest of drivers in vehicles, and Germany has set a minimum hourly wage. These changes benefit local carriers. Meanwhile, the new requirements for companies in the Baltic states that have suffered the greatest losses due to the embargo are unbearable. I call on the Commission to compensate for the losses suffered by the Baltic carriers and I ask Germany, Belgium and France to withdraw the anti-competitive legislation.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I will no longer repeat here how much the embargo has hit transport companies in the European Union. Costs in sect of millions of euros, and not only for those companies that carried out direct transport to Russia, but also those for which Russia was a transit country. There is no doubt that, in this situation, the European Union should be in solidarity and the European Commission should make efforts to support transport companies from within and within the European Union. I wonder why de minimis aid for road hauliers could not be mitigated in this situation. This is a simple, fast and easy thing to do and would certainly be very helpful for transport companies. It seems to me very important for the Commission to examine.

name: Janusz Wojciechowski (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Of course, the European Union should compensate all the costs that farmers and transport operators incur, and all those who suffer as a result of these necessary sanctions. Necessary, I stress this.  On the other hand, I was amazed at what Mr Ferreira was saying, and I have to react to that. If the Lord says that the cause of all this was neo-fascist actions in Ukraine, Mr President, it means that you completely do not understand what is happening there. You do not understand this, Portugal is far from these events, but really this is a great threat to the whole of Europe, and you are repeating propaganda from the Kremlin. This should not be said, and I regret that such voices are falling in this House.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: And now I will ask the Commissioner to respond to these numerous speeches by members who have demanded reaction and assistance from the European Commission, not to return the ball to the Member States, and have cited precedents from the past when transport companies (and not only) had help from the European Union during sanctions against the Yugoslav Federation.

name: Violeta Bulc
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, I would like to thank Members for all their comments and especially suggestions. I have taken note of all the concerns and I will make sure these are taken into account by the Commission in its current work. I also promise to examine your concrete proposals – there were several of them – in a timely manner. I am fully aware that all these challenges are to be addressed in a horizontal manner. The situation is very sensitive and serious. Allow me to stress our main positions one more time. The Commission fully shares the concerns related to the revenue losses of some EU hauliers due to the Russian import ban and the Commission continues to closely monitor this situation. We expect the analysis to be provided in a timely manner. At this point I have no evidence of severe market disruptions that would go beyond individual cases. Allow me to refer to Members’ comments relating to the Globalisation Fund. The Globalisation Fund is intended to support employees laid off as a consequence of the global market opening. As it stands today, it is not designed to compensate for losses brought about by situations similar to those we are discussing today, especially the Russian embargo. Regarding the fourth point, relief measures at national level are possible but they have to respect the relevant EU law. The Commission is open to assessing possible state aid schemes. I know that this is not a perfect solution but at this point the EU does not have its own budget to manage transport policy. The next point is that in EU road transport the EU has only limited means at its disposal for external policy actions. We therefore have to work closely together with the Member States to try to avert the most serious consequences of actions taken by third countries. A quick and lasting improvement in relations between the EU and Russia would of course be desirable, but at this point I can only hope that the political situation supports us in our efforts as soon as possible. But it is true that we have to do something, so I am willing to work with Parliament and the Member States on this topic to see if there are possible new solutions with the WTO. This will be our first serious step.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the With all due respect for your presidency, it must have been missed that I was in the Chamber throughout the whole discussion, that I also reported correctly and that I would have liked to have spoken as an Austrian whose home country is also very affected by the sanctions. I do not think it is very balanced that you give the floor to many Members but do not give the floor to a non-attached Member. Furthermore, I do not think it is balanced that you are giving the floor to many ladies and gentlemen from your home country. Other countries are also affected! I would like to say that this was not balanced for me. I would ask you to correct this in the future.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: Mr President, i would like to thank you for your comments. I wanted to apologise to you personally. Your name was on the list. It's my fault. I am very sorry. I wanted to apologize to you, your name was on the list, I skipped it, I apologize. I close the debate. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. – One year after Russia applied discriminatory customs procedures at its border to Lithuanian tractors, discriminatory behaviour by Russia against Lithuanian carriers is again repeated. Russia scrutinises Lithuanian cargoes thoroughly, as EU countries transport "embargo" products, i.e. food and agricultural products, to Russia via Lithuania. Russia has gained the opportunity to rely on such a formal but reality-incompatible basis that any EU state can be discriminated against, which has become an advantage for Russia that ceased to enjoy the TIR system more than a year ago. Russia has introduced a separate guarantee system which has not been approved in Europe after refusing to use the TIR system. As early as Last December, I asked the Commission what measures it intends to take to prevent such blatantly discriminatory practices against EU Member States. Because such discriminatory measures cannot be reconciled with Russia's membership of the World Trade Organisation (WTO), which joined in 2012. Russia has made a legally binding commitment not to apply customs procedures against a particular country. I have received a 'worrying' response from the Commission, but it does not provide for any concrete action by the Commission. Furthermore, the Commission did not explain in its reply the basis on which Lithuanian carriers should not be compensated in order to compensate them for the losses suffered as a result of Discriminatory actions by Russia.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. "The restrictions imposed by Russia last August on imports of agricultural products have a clear negative impact not only on EU agriculture, producers, but also on freight companies. There is also one sector that is heavily affected and suffers losses: the logistics sector, as the reduced trade in goods has also reduced the work of warehouses and loaders. These losses mainly affect small and medium-sized enterprises. Although the decrease in imports will result in cheaper domestic products in our stores in the short term. However, the sector must also face the long-term negative consequences of this measure. We must also remember that the Russian market is one of the most important markets, especially for the countries of the Union further east. The embargo will provide a competitive advantage for non-EU Member States. Circumvention of the ban by delivering products through these countries will trigger an increase in the black market and illegal activities (repackaging, re-labelling). The market support measures provided by the Commission to compensate producers in part for the profits that have been made out are welcome. At the same time, it is necessary that not only producers receive eu assistance, but also the transport and logistics sectors. That is why it is very important that we act as unitedly and as quickly as possible, avoiding even greater losses for our businesses. At the same time, it is necessary to find new markets for overproduction. This could be the biggest help from the EU.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. – I fully agree with the concerns raised on the oral question. Indeed, the Commission does not seem to be fully aware of the seriousness of the situation caused by the Russian agricultural embargo. The third round of EU compensation for the mitigation of market damage caused by the Russian agricultural embargo at the end of last year Hungary also omitted, similar to Croatia, Slovenia and Romania.  In Hungary, the volume of preliminary applications received last September was more than 10,000 tonnes, i.e. in order of magnitude higher than the quantity envisaged for the country in the second round. To alleviate this, the free-to-use 3,000-ton frame provided in the second round was Hungary only partially exploited due to the shortness of time. This framework is no longer available to my country, and it would be very justified. The overproduction crisis caused by the Russian embargo continues to cause serious damage to the Hungarian, Croatian, Slovenian and Romanian fruit sectors. Therefore, compensation to producers in these countries is also fully justified, even if their direct export losses were low.  On the basis of the above, on the one hand, I demand that the Commission provide hungarian, Croatian, Slovenian and Romanian farmers with additional compensation in order to reduce their losses caused by the overproduction crisis. You can do this by extending the term of use of the second-round budget or by announcing a new 3,000-ton limit that is free to use.

name: Esther Herranz García (PPE)
text: in writing. – The Russian veto has had absolutely a very serious impact on the fresh fruit and vegetable sector and also on fresh meat, products that are transported to Russia by road. So the damage to the producers must be added to the damage to the carriers. I believe that the European Commission should also note that this is not the first time we have problems with Russia. For example, a few years ago, when the E.coli crisis took place, we also saw the Russian border close without further explanation to fresh Spanish produce and how fruits and vegetables rotted at borders. I believe that the European Commission should be sensitive to these problems and make sure that when this crisis passes trade treaties with the Russian border are also implemented and can be properly implemented.  It is not fair that a geopolitical problem is paid for by fruit and vegetable producers and European carriers.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. – The Russian embargo on our international road transport operators has had a colossal impact on the sector, but also on the export of fresh fruit, vegetables and meat, in particular from peripheral countries, such as Portugal. Road hauliers cannot pay for foreign policy actions. I therefore think it is important for the European Commission to act with the Russian authorities and to implement existing trade agreements. As it has such competence, the Commission must ensure that international road transport takes place without obstacles and discrimination within and outside the Union.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing – Russia is in economic isolation with its policy, and unless it fundamentally changes this position, the current policy will lead to a reduction in economic activities between the EU and Russia. Such a situation will certainly be easier for us than for Russia. At the same time, this challenge means, above all, the development of economic relations with other areas of the world, in particular the deepening of cooperation with the American and Asian continents.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – (20) We are suffering collateral damage resulting from the unacceptable position of confrontation, instigation and deepening of the conflict by the EU, which has destabilized Ukraine and paved the way for the rise to power of nazi-fascist forces. These forces supported and financed by the United States and the European Union now expect them to meet their best interests. In this process, European transport operators, such as agricultural producers such as fisheries and aquaculture companies, among others, are such collateral damage, a strategy that sacrifices them in favour of these other interests. The European Commission cannot therefore wash its hands here, as it has done here today. It has direct responsibility for these losses and must assume these responsibilities, changing policy and offsetting the large losses.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: The next item is one-minute speeches on significant political issues (Article 163 of the Rules of Procedure).

name: David McAllister (PPE).
text: – Mr President, south-eastern Europe was hit hard by last year’s dreadful floods. These had severe consequences for our Member States like Croatia and Romania, and also for Serbia and Bosnia and Herzegovina. I visited Serbia three weeks ago and I was pleased to see the results of the European Union’s efforts to relieve the after-effects of the floods in May last year. Together with Michael Davenport, the Head of our EU delegation to Serbia, I visited the town of Svilajnac, which was heavily affected by the floods. We reopened a renovated kindergarten and we also handed over keys for private houses which were rebuilt with the aid of EU funding. This visit firmly convinced me that the solidarity of the European Union with the citizens of Serbia was money well spent for a noble cause. The European Union is the biggest donor of assistance for flood relief in Serbia, with the EU funding more than 1 000 private houses that have been built, reconstructed and supplied with all that is necessary. But now we need to turn forwards towards flood prevention, and in that respect the European Union has secured an additional EUR 62 million, of which EUR 19 million will go towards prevention. I think this effort and action will be equally important, if not even more important, since we should all work together to prevent a similar catastrophe occurring in the future.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the updated statistics on early childhood care and education services have been published in recent weeks, starting with the end of maternity leave and paid parental leave, and it has emerged that only seven states in the European Union guarantee good quality of maternity leave.  Quality services are affected in many countries by the lack of adequate resources and the lack of pedagogical guidance. This involves creating or deepening social inequalities and prevents the elimination of the gender gap, because it is women who mostly look after children in the absence of services and are penalised in professional life. That is why we are calling on the European Union to ensure that all its citizens are provided with quality services that are accessible to all, together with other measures that help to reduce all forms of discrimination, such as the upward standardisation of European legislation on parental leave and the promotion of flexible working methods, such as smart working, which allow not only women but all workers to better reconcile family needs with an active working life.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Tomorrow, there will be another talk in this House about abortion. It has already been said on several occasions that abortion is not a competence of the European Union. We are not being paid to talk here about things that are not, of course, the responsibility of this House – I am talking about the Tarabella report. In Germany, for example, abortion is a criminal offence. That may not be known. In Germany, abortion carries a prison sentence of up to three years. The Tarabella report now does not just want to make abortion unpunished, it wants to make it a human right – abortion as a human right – on the same level as the right to freedom, the right to freedom of expression and the right to life! We should leave our hands on this, and we should stop talking about things that do not belong in this House.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: - Mr. President, one of the main policies of the European Union is to fight climate change. Of course, our environmental policy builds on this, and our goal of decarbonising the European economy is certainly added to this.  Unfortunately, we are witnessing that a coal-fired Plomin 3 thermal power plant is being built in Istria soon, which will certainly not contribute to decarbonization, environmental protection and our climate change policy. I especially say this because there is also a national Croatian project nearby, which is also involved in European projects, the construction of lng terminals on the island of Krk.  That is why I call on the Commission and everyone involved to bring these projects together. Let's build a gas-powered Plomin 3 thermal power plant and use the LNG terminal that's near Plomin, and it needs to be really used to the end.

name: Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, to me, one day after the celebration of 8 March, International Women's Day, I would like to bring to this forum the realization that austerity policies are having a much greater impact on women. Cuts affect feminized sectors, such as education, health, or public services. Austerity is also eliminating measures to support conciliation, which places even more on women domestic work, the care of children and the elderly. In addition, cuts are affecting measures to combat sexist violence. At the job level, wages remain much lower for women. In Galicia, women charge 24% less than men; but, moreover, in the field of agricultural and family exploitation, women still do not have recognized our professional rights. Finally, poverty also has a woman's face. 70% of non-contributory pensioners ... (The Chair withdrew the floor to the speaker)

name: Ernest Maragall (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, let's talk about Catalonia, that is, let's talk about Europe. In Catalonia we live an extraordinary process of self-determination, peaceful and high democratic quality: 2.3 million votes on November 9, two million participants on September 11, more than one and a half million signatures of an express statement to that effect. But the Spanish state refuses time and time again the open dialogue that this process calls for. When acting in relation to Catalonia, the Spanish state violates the same rules of the rule of law that we require of countries that want to join the European Union. Today's Spain, I fear, in that sense would not exceed that basic requirement. Three examples of recent weeks: the recusal of the Catalan Foreign Action Law, the practice of disabling our ombudsman, and the suspension of a Catalan judge just by freely expressing his political options as a citizen. The undemocratic nature of these three decisions does not support interpretation. It is a frontal attack on the institutions and basic rights of Catalonia and Catalans.  You be clear: Catalonia is part of the best European hope in contrast to the growing risk of state nationalisms, including that of the Spanish state.

name: Rosa D'Amato (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, as a member of the Committee on Regional Development, I would like to express my deep concern about the number of regional operational programmes, as many as three hundred, or 47% of all programmes, which need to be reviewed in the multiannual financial framework; this is so as not to lose the resources allocated in 2014. I therefore welcome the proposal to revise the multiannual financial framework, which will, among other things, be brought to the attention of this House at subsequent part-sessions.  For the future, however, in order to avoid the same problems in the next programming period, I would like to see greater cooperation and coordination between the European Commission, between the Member States, between regional and local authorities, precisely in the light of that shared management that is, or rather should be, the key principle of cohesion policy. However, I must point out – and this is a bitter note, my own – that, at least in my country, there have been delays, as for decades now, especially in the southern regions. I therefore call for more attention and, above all, for us to be explained why it is always the regions themselves, with the exception of a few new entries, that have these problems.

name: Franz Obermayr (NI).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the In 2013, some 120,000 asylum seekers from North Africa and the Middle East entered the Union. How many of them are sympathizers of Islamist movements, or even belong to them themselves, could be statistically extrapolated with a simple computer program. But European policy obviously does not want to see that an ever-increasing Islamist time bomb is ticking here. It is therefore no wonder that people and groups closely associated with the Islamists are courted and even supported by the official EU side, such as .B the chairman of the Al-Muntada Foundation, who was invited to the last annual meeting of the European Commission for Humanitarian Aid and Civil Protection and whose foundation is presumed to be one of The Financiers of Boko Haram. I therefore call on the EU bodies mentioned to be a little more critical of Islamism, to stop offering the Islamists a stage and not to make Islamists acceptable through the back door in our Parliament out of ignorance or even out of stupidity.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: - The European Union deals with all rights. Today we have heard several statements on different rights, but they do not deal with important rights. One of those rights is the right to a private life.  More and more people are getting into a situation where they are unable to maintain a marriage for professional or other reasons. We all know it around us, families are falling apart. We are also in a situation where more and more women are unwilling to say who the father of their child is. Even though they have this information in many cases. Fathers are thus denied their right to care for their children. Not only women, but also men, are discriminated against in the European Union, and therefore we should not close our eyes to this problem. One of the cases is the case of Czech Jan Puda, who cannot undergo paternity tests and prove that he is the father of his children. He lost all opportunity to prove it in the Czech courts.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (
text: S&D). Mr President, children do not know about political purposes, so we must listen to them. So I will soon convey to you a letter given to me by the children of a Primary School in Nicosia and I convey to you their anxieties. He's only eight years old. They wonder why they should live and grow up in a divided homeland, where a third are held by foreign Turkish troops. They wonder why these children, within the European Union, do not have the right to freedom of their own country.  But also in relation to the economic crisis they wonder why they should not have food to eat and clothes to wear, why there should be children unhappy in our country within the European Union. It is the one-sided austerity policies that are to blame. And they end with a phrase and a suggestion for all of us: "Respect Cyprus, it is also a country of the European Union"!

name: Janusz Wojciechowski (ECR).
text: – In 2008, as Russian tanks approached the Georgian capital Tbilisi, President Polish Lech Kaczynski, who was defending Georgia at the time, said that today – Georgia, tomorrow – Ukraine, the day after tomorrow – the Baltic States and then Poland. President Lech Kaczynski was killed in an unexplained disaster to this day, and Russia, under President Putin, is implementing this scenario. It's "today – Ukraine": we all see what's going on there. I would like to recommend the words of The President of Ukraine Petr Poroshenko, who said that Russia's imperial aspirations go further than the size of Ukraine. And I wanted to point out that the Russian Empire, which Vladimir Putin is rebuilding, did not end in Ukraine, did not end in Poland, but reached the center of Germany, Berlin and the Coma. I recommend this reflection especially to German politicians.

name: Lynn Boylan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, in April 2016 Ireland will transpose three new procurement directives into national law and previous guidelines from the Commission give scope for the government of Ireland to use procurement as a positive instrument to achieve gender equality and sustainable development, and to realise social goals such as its national anti—poverty targets. In order to ensure real public accountability, labour rights, equality and environmental considerations should be explicitly referred to at all stages of procurement processes. The right to organise collective bargaining and gender equality, as set out by the ILO standards, must also be complied with and monitored on an ongoing basis.  Given that my country, Ireland, is second in the OECD for low pay – and women are particularly vulnerable in this area – the living wage should always be included when applying the best price-quality ratio. The directives do not oblige Ireland to contract out services that they wish to provide themselves, and they should therefore remain in public control. Community and voluntary services must also be protected and not disadvantaged by a move from a grant—based funding model to one of tendering.

name: Giulia Moi (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is surprising that, in the run-up to the Milan Expo, derogations have been granted for the import of food from third countries, while the pavilions will remain closed to certain excellences in our territories, such as sardinian piglet and all derived products. Valuing the extraordinary fruits of the earth that come from our continent should be in everyone's interest. On this point, I have already called on the Commission on several occasions to ensure that this accident, which will penalise the farmers and breeders of Sardinia in particular, is not consumed in two months' time. Above all, however, we must thank the sardinian local politicians and their respective parties who, since 1978, that is to say in thirty years, instead of solving the problem, have only been able to shout at the emergency and strike a single blow, the only one I know: to increase the salaries and expenses of their parasitic maintenance borne by Sardinian and Italian taxpayers, borne by public money. We also thank them if today entire Italian production sectors risk missing a great opportunity to better promote the image of our products. Expo 2015 was already born under a bad star: I hope it does not become a continuous exercise in theft and scams.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE). Mr President, today I have to raise before the European Parliament a very important issue that has to do with Cypriot shipping, but by extension with European shipping. For years Turkey has, in a pirated, illegal, arbitrary and cynical way, imposed a maritime embargo on ships flying the Cypriot flag and, by extension, imposed an embargo on European ships. It is unacceptable and inconceivable that Turkey should remain undisturbed and unpunished from violating the Ankara Protocol - which it signed and which had to date essentially recognised the Republic of Cyprus and opened the ports and skies - and thus to insult and substantially challenge the European Union itself.  We, as Cyprus, have enormous maritime and economic costs. This cost is also already being already in place. Did you imagine, Mr President, in conclusion, what would happen to this European Parliament or to the European Commission if Turkey banned ships flying the British, French or Italian flags from entering its ports?

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Mr President, on 25 February 2015, the Commissioner responsible for Economic and Monetary Affairs announced Romania's inclusion in the macroeconomic imbalance and monitoring procedure. The Commission's arguments on this approach are very vague. The application of this monitoring entails, under European Union law, exceeding critical thresholds in terms of: the current account balance, the actual change in the exchange rate, the external financial position, the change in the market share of exports, the consolidated debt of the public and private sector, the unemployment rate and the change in liabilities of the financial sector. None of these indicators have reached the critical threshold in my country, so they need to be included in the monitoring.  Romania is in its fourth year of economic growth, has stability on course, has one of the smallest deficits, has export growth, has no bank failures and there are institutional reforms under way. Can we conclude that the romanian government's decision not to extend the agreement with the Monetary Fund may be the cause of Romania's inclusion on the monitoring list?  I consider it unjustified to place Romania on the macroeconomic imbalance list and I believe that the Commission is obliged to present the concrete arguments that led to its inclusion in this list. This affects the country's image and decreases credibility with investors.

name: Philippe Loiseau (NI).
text: Mr President, despite the criticisms of the European peoples on the enlargement of the European Union, you expect that other countries will still be able to join, taking advantage of the financial windfall promised to them, while other peoples suffer from your 'Euro-austerity'. It is through the pre-accession aid instrument, which has a budget of more than EUR 11 billion, that these countries are preparing for their entry into the European Union. Again, we note the lack of democratic respect, because among these countries we are surprised to see Turkey, whose eventual accession raises many questions among our compatriots, but which has benefited from a budgetary envelope of almost 5 billion euros. But if I speak on this subject, it is to talk about agriculture, which is one of the sectors financed by this pre-accession aid instrument. The European Union is therefore involved in the development and modernization of the agriculture of these countries, preparing the introduction of their production - I am thinking of Turkish fruits and vegetables for example - on our market. These productions will thus compete even more with the agriculture of the other Member States, which is already in very bad shape, as I see in France, where I unfortunately meet more and more farmers in difficulty.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE).
text: – Mr President, last week some of the relatives of ETA criminals integrated into the Etxerat organisation have been walking around the European Parliament. And we've seen how these relatives of ETA's killers are used, once again, as the terrorist gang's co-parents. These relatives of the killers do not seek forgiveness for the murders committed by their relatives, imprisoned fairly, nor do they ask ETA to dissolve and disappear, nor do they ask the Etharra terrorist mafia to surrender its weaponry. No, ladies and gentlemen. They don't, because Etxerat makes the game for ETA. Because they're a part of ETA's fabric. Etxerat has approached the European Parliament to try to deceive some with the pathetic victimism of the relatives of ETA's killers. That is, the victimism of the executioners, who are hurtful to the real victims, who are the victims of terrorism, to whom their relatives, etharra criminals, have taken their lives. And the difference is that while ETA relatives have the ability to visit, see and talk to murderers, relatives of victims of terrorism can only go to cemeteries, see the stone shillings of their loved ones' graves and niches. And this is the true story of this matter and what Etxerat, that organization linked to ETA, means.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D).
text: – According to Eurostat, food expenditure accounts for around 14%, and in some EU countries more than 20% of the household budget.  The food chain affects every consumer every day. But its functioning is also important for the economy as a whole. Producers, often SMEs, point to increasing differences between the supply price of food and the resulting price in shops. Margins are estimated to make food up to twice as expensive.  Already in 2009, a food price monitoring tool was introduced with the aim of increasing market transparency in the food chain. However, the Commission still does not have statistics on retail food margins across the Union.  In addition to combating unfair commercial practices, the Commission should focus on analysing indeed all the aspects that affect the final price paid by the consumer, i.e. the margin. Not only the end customer could benefit from this, but the entire food chain.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, táimse ar fheachtas teanga na laethanta seo chun mo theanga dhúchais a chur chun cinn toisc go bhfuil Seachtain na Gaeilge ar siúl againn ag an mbaile.  Ba mhaith liom freisin aitheantas a thabhairt don Aontas Eorpach as ucht an méid atá á dhéanamh aige ar son mionteangacha cosúil le mo theanga féin. Mar shampla, is féidir liom labhairt as Gaeilge anseo anois mar tá seirbhís ateangaireachta thuas ansin ag míniú daoibh cad atá á rá agam, agus amach anseo beidh a lán daoine fostaithe mar aistritheoirí chun ár ndoiciméid Eorpacha a aistriú.  An tseachtain seo chugainn beidh lá mór na nGael againn, Lá Fhéile Pádraig, agus beidh mé ag eagrú fáiltiú sa Pharlaimint don lá sin. Beidh fáilte roimh chách. Ach iarraim oraibh focal amháin a rá as Gaelainn: in ionad cheers nó bon appétit a rá, abair ‘sláinte’ –sin é an téarma Gaelainne. Dá bhrí sin, a Uachtaráin, ‘sláinte’.

name: Jude Kirton-Darling (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Beamish is one of Europe’s largest open air museums which annually entertains 650 000 visitors. It is a key local employer and a unique selling point for my constituency. In my region, the Northeast of England, the cultural industry, such as Beamish, employs thousands in decent jobs and offers training and volunteer opportunities to thousands more, including many disadvantaged social groups. They are a key component of our local economy. The Northeast Cultural Partnership is trying to build on these existing successes, in part using EU ERDF funding; but our UK government has blocked access to EU funding for not-for-profit cultural enterprises. This brutal blow ignores the social and economic benefits offered by Europe for cultural industries, at a time when our constituencies can ill afford to turn down the opportunities for jobs and growth available.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE).
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. It has been three weeks since the desecrated Statue of Liberty in Arad, which commemorates the thirteen martyrs, has been desecrated by unpunished offenders. This is a serious act, since the Statue of Liberty is not only one of the outstanding works of art of Hungarians, but for more than a decade it has been a worthy eloqueness of the symbolic square that has been called the Park of Reconciliation in order to proclaim the message of historical reconciliation between Hungary and Romania. I strongly condemn the desecration of statues in Arad here in the lobby of the European Parliament in Strasbourg, the capital of Franco-German reconciliation. The historic city of Arad, on the western border of Romania, cannot be a city of interethnic strife! Like Strasbourg, Arad must be the capital of Hungarian-Romanian reconciliation, setting an example of mutual respect, tolerance, rejection of extremism and extremism.

name: Inés Ayala Sender (S&D).
text: – Mr President, when there was severe flooding in central Europe years ago, European solidarity was able to create the European Union's Disaster Solidarity Fund, which for these next few years foresees up to 500 million, and the truth is that this week I have felt enormous envy because in my region — Aragon — and other adjoining ones, the Ebro River — the most flowing in Spain , and the one who normally carries wealth — has been overflowing for more than a week, affecting more than 28,000 hectares of arable land and 4,000 farms, killing 10,000 animals, with entire villages such as Boquiñeni affected and their population evacuated several times at night, in the early hours, roads destroyed and homes, furniture and equipment day after day underwater.  It is one of the most damaging avenues that are remembered. In view of this, moreover, the regional and national governments of the People's Party have first underestimated the level of the catastrophe and then the aid they have raised is so far insufficient. Everything that could go wrong went wrong. It was not prepared well, the populations were not well warned and the current situation is of absolute despair. Hence, my request for solidarity from the European Union for the Aragonese region and all Aragonese.

name: Eduard Kukan (PPE) –
text: The European population is ageing. This is a fact for which we must strategically prepare for the real impacts. Europeans will work longer and retire at an older age. We must think about this now that we are deciding on investments in the future, this must be seen not only as a challenge, but above all as an opportunity. This topic should get into the mainstream of our policies, we need to support the so-called silver economy, which can be an economic opportunity for small and medium-sized enterprises, science and research, and professional care geared towards an ageing population. It's a way to further stimulate our economy. At the same time, we need to place emphasis on reforming health systems in our Member States. We should make sure that European seniors are self-sufficient and can live healthier and better lives.

name: Damian Drăghici (S&D).
text: – Mr President, on 3 March, during the Italian TV talkshow ‘Piazzapulita’, the Vice-President of the Federation ʽRom e Sinti Insiemeʼ, Diana Pavlovic, was subjected to a violent racist attack by an Italian MEP, Gianluca Buonanno. For me, as a Roma MEP and as a citizen of Romania and of the European Union, such public behaviour is intolerable nowadays. Because the political family that I belong to, the Socialists, across 28 European Member States, decided to support me in becoming a Member of this prestigious institution, they will not support the voice of discrimination against those who are disrespected. If you have any doubt about who they are and whom I am speaking on behalf of, let me remind you: the Roma.  Gianluca Buonanno, as a Member of the European Parliament, should be reminded that, when any of us takes a discriminatory attitude or a racist public stance, this institution does not allow such public behaviour. More than this, the situation calls for such attitudes to be condemned and penalised and for a stand to be taken against such deviant behaviour. So I call on Parliament to take a stand and publicly condemn and penalise attitudes like these when they appear.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE).
text: – Mr. President, due to lack of good economic governance, a regulated system of timely treatment and clear rules of operation, citizens of the European Union are often at a loss.  We must prevent situations where flood risks since the summer of 2014 have not been disposed of and live in containers and funds from the European Union Solidarity Fund have not been used; that some industries are affected by the crisis, workers are laid off and applications are not sent to the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund; that every other young person is out of work, and the means of guarantee for young people are used with a reek; investments are falling and EU funds are not used.  Because of these cases, for the protection of our citizens to whom we guarantee security and solidarity, we must insist on the adoption and implementation of the rules of good economic and financial management at all levels.

name: Esther Herranz García (PPE).
text: – Mr President, on behalf of the Spanish delegation of the Popular Party, and especially my colleagues Pablo Zalba of Navarra and Veronica López Fontagné of Aragon, who have not been able to intervene, we stand in solidarity with all the citizens of the Ebro basin who have been affected by the four great consecutive avenues of these weeks. More than twenty-eight thousand hectares have been flooded, houses flooded, hundreds of head of cattle and shattered crops, and irrigation systems, leaving hundreds of families living off agriculture and livestock very committed. We appreciate the work carried out by the regional governments, such as La Rioja or Aragon and, of course, we recognize the actions of the Government of Spain with a royal decree to cover the damage that has occurred so far and that can be discovered from now on. We would not be as we are if, during seven years of government of the Socialist Party in Spain, the infrastructure works that were ongoing in this area of the Ebro had not been paralyzed. We have to bet on hydraulic infrastructure, because they are necessary to serve the population, for the environment and to prevent flooding like these days.
